essay:div.essay:p: A GUIDE TO THE BANFF DISCUSSIONS FOREWORD The purpose of this paper is to restate for the benefit of those who will attend the Fifth Conference of the Institute of Pacific Relations to be held at Banff August 14 to 28s 1933, and particularly for those who will on that occasion participate in the Institute's activities for the first time, the purposes, characteristics and methods of the Institute. It is also the intention of this paper to focus these general remarks upon the subjects to be discussed at Banff so as to furnish not only an intro¬ duction to the Institute but also to the particular topics to be considered at the forthcoming Conference. I. INTRODUCTION The agenda for the Banff Conference was, in its main outline and points of emphasis, determined at the close of the Shanghai Conference held in the autumn of 1931. Each National Council thereupon set about the task of preparing the papers necessary to document the discussions of these sub¬ jects, and, concurrently, each Council and members of the International Secretariat and Program Committee began to refine and develop the agenda. Developments along both lines, data paper preparation and discussion agenda, may be traced through successive reports and announcements issued by the Central Secretariat during this biennial period. The implications and purposes of the selection of the particular sub¬ jects contained in the Banff agenda cannot be understood in the light merely of the period subsequent to the Shanghai Conference (1931). The Institute does not carry on its activities by two-year periods; it does not jump suddenly from one area of concentration, either geographically or topically, to another in each biennium. On the contrary, there has been marked continuity in the pursuit of its researches, studies and discussions. The deliberations of one Conference have determined the subjects to be discussed at the next. The findings of research have pointed to the necessity for further investigations. Conferences and research, moreover, have mutually influenced the subsequent program of the other. There has been, in short, a consistent and continuous search for comprehension of the affairs of the Pacific area. In consequence, the discussions at Banff must be viewed on a back¬ ground, not merely of the months which have elapsed since the close of the Shanghai Conference, but on a background of the eight years since the organization of the Institute in 1925. It is of special importance that the realms to be explored at Banff be described in the total perspective of the Institute's activities because of the different personnel invited to each Conference. There will be at Banff a large number of individuals who have never before participated in an Institute Conference and who have had only casual contact with the organization's work in past years. A changing personnel at each Conference is regarded as essential in order constantly to bring new minds and new experiences to bear on the problems of the Pacific area, but if this resulted in repetition of similar discussions

every two years it would hardly fulfill the purposes of the organization. The institute has the more difficult task of drawing together new individuals to proceed not from the point of departure of the first Conference in 1925, but from the point reached after an accumulation of years of study and thought• II. AEEAS OF CONCENTRATION Certain characteristics of Institute Conferences have repeatedly re¬ vealed themselves. Mention of them may serve the twofold purpose of suggest¬ ing: the objectives and methods of the Institute and especially of the Banff Conference and of introducing the subjects selected for this year's considera¬ tion. In describing these characteristics it may, first of all, be useful to locate the areas of thought and matter in which Institute discussions are concerned. a. Areas of Conflict Conferences have always concentrated on areas of conflict. Whether in the highly charged fields of political controversy or in the ^eos «mo*x«a- al, but nevertheless troublesome, region of economic conflict the discussions It™ invariably invaded dangerous territory. This has not amen as h re¬ sult of an excited pursuit of the "hot spots" of international relations, but from the assumption that controversial areas require most study and that they serve, moreover, as the most practical entering wedge to a comprehension of the more normal behavior among nations. From this emphasis on controversial matters, the danger of distor- tion, that is of undue emphasis on conflict itself, has always been present. If all the affairs of the Pacific area were in some miraculous way tabulated it would undoubtedly be found that both from quantitative and qualitative points of view far more of these affairs proceeded normally and peacefully than in an irregular or antagonistic manner. It would be found that the broad pattern of international relations forms a coherent and correlated design marked by the unfortunate execution of certain details. But just as in this figure of a vast design, so in the actual political, social, ana economic relations of the area the errors in detail may, and often do, destroy the effect of a sound structure. Concentration on areas of conflict may bring distortion from another point of view. Attention may be so attracted by these areas that it will dwell too much on the details of the conflict itself, and too little on the origins which usually lie elsewhere - in organisations, customs, or policies initiated thousands of miles away and in categories of thought far removed from the current manifestation of conflict. The Institute Conferences, then, by concentrating on areas of con¬ flict run into these dangers of distortion. The point is here recorded so that by calling it to the attention of those who will participate m tne Banff discussions the correct perspective may be retained.

b. International Affairs of the Pacifio The Institute focuses its attention in two further directions. Geographically it limits its scope to the Pacific area, and within that area to international rather than domestic affairs. Both restrictions how¬ ever must be qualified• From many points of view the Pacific area is a false category; it is not capable of being isolated from the rest of the world. It is self-sufficient neither with respect to food, raw materials, trade, capital, ideas, or policies. An attempt to discuss any of the af¬ fairs of the area as though they were wholly peculiar to it would be a serious falsification of reality. The Institute, in its deliberations, consequently, emphasizes the area without regarding it as exclusive. The discussion at Banff, for instance, will be documented by illustrations drawn entirely from the Pacific, but the discussions themselves will doubtless lead to numerous world-wide implications of Pacific problems. No more successfully can international affairs be divorced from the domestic conditions out of which they arose. Although emphasis may be placed on the external relations of nations, and the understanding of these affairs may be the Institute*s primary endeavor, oftentimes they have no reality in themselves and cannot be comprehended except on the background of the internal affairs of which they are merely an external manifestation. It is to be anticipated, therefore, that at Banff, as at Shanghai, Kyoto and Honolulu, the discussions will frequently lead back to domestic conditions in order that the international aspects of the matter under consideration may be understood. o» Area of the Social Sciences The concern of the Institute lies, moreover, within the area of human relations. But within these limits it is no more possible to isolate economics from sociology or sociology from political science than it is, as we have seen, to separate the international from the domestic aspects of questions or the Pacific area from the rest of the world. Once more, the Institute merely shifts emphasis from one Conference to another. At Banff, the agenda calls primarily for a discussion of economic matters, but the fact that the agenda also provides for a consideration of the political and educational problems arising out of the economic is recognition of the fact that in practical affairs the disciplines merge imperceptibly into one an¬ other. Matters of trade lead back to industrialization; industrialization leads back to wages, trade unions, standard of living, labor supply.^ These, in turn, lead to government policy, to custom, tradition, to the heritage of a people. Social organization is a factor in trade just as surely as the relation of food supply to population or the extent of mineral resources* While at Banff emphasis will be placed on the more purely economic factors; it is to be expected that the term "economic" will be most liberally con¬ strued.

d. Technique of Unofficial Discussion The discussion technique practiced by the Institute will be expounded in another document to be issued by the Central Secretariat especially for the guidance of round table chairmen. Certain general characteristics^will be mentioned here in order to complete this attempt to orient from various points of view the Institute's Conference. The phrase "discussion technique" is used advisedly. The round tables organized by the Institute are not haphazard gatherings of individuals of diverse experience assembled to dis¬ cuss a vaguely-phrased problem of the moment in whatever fashion may appeal to the participants. They are on the contrary carefully planned discussions of subjects arising logically out of a coherent long-term scheme of study, each one of whioh is as accurately and fully documented as possible, in which the participants are selected for qualifications of expertness, experi¬ ence or representative character, and during the conduct of which a^ scienti¬ fically determined procedure of discussion is employed. The essential pur¬ pose of the round table is the comprehension by analysis of the matter at hand and the thorough exploration of the possibilities of resolving the problem through the concentrated effort of many minds experienced in differ¬ ent activities and conditioned in diverse environments. This purpose implies a discussion that develops; it denies the constant reiteration of points of view already expressed and either recorded or discarded; it precludes the procedure of debate whereby opinions are defended on the basis of a prior judgment irrespective of new evidence introduced during the session. It implies a continual change of mind on the part of each participant as the fusion of experiences develops the question under consideration. In order to avoid the"awkward situation wherein an individual who commands wide public attention finds it necessary to "stand pat" on a much publicized position, no publicity is given individuals during their participation m round table discussions. The method is reliable insurance against the pos¬ sibility of participants giving or taking offense. The dispassionate and objective atmosphere of a round table is an environment unfavorable to the breeding of ill-feeling. By its unofficial nature, furthermore, the Institute is able to avoid the handicaps and "red-tape" of officialdom. Individuals participate in these Conferences; industries, corporations, organizations, and governments do not. The fact that the Institute is composed of national and territorial units is a matter of expediency; it is not a provision for national or group representation at Conferences. For administrative purposes the basic unit of"the Institute is a national council, although this unit does not in every case correspond to a nationally sovereign unit in the political sense. In fact, the constitution of the Institute expressly provides for the organiza¬ tion of councils in regions having a certain degree of racial or territorial independence from their sovereign states — the Philippines being a case in point. The geographical unit, moreover, is the most suitable one for^the administration of research and for carrying out the educational functions oi the Institute. The fact that this organizational unit has persisted in con¬ nection with Conferences, to which members from the same area are naturally likely to travel together, and during which each unit is likely to hold fre¬ quent meetings for administrative purposes, has led to some confusion as to the purpose of this unit. There has been a tendency, quite contrary to the methods of the Institute, for certain groups to use the administrative unit^ to formulate and advocate group opinions on matters under discussion. inis

has resulted not only in hampering the development of the Institute's technique of discussion by forming national blocs, but also in placing the members of such groups in an entirely different relation to the dis¬ cussions from the members of other groups participating solely in their individual capacities. It is hoped that at Banff this tendency will be checked, if the practice is not altogether discarded, and that every group will limit its group functions to administrative and informational matters. "While its non-representative character prevents the Institute from speaking with official authority, it enables it to speak with the authority of unbiased information. The Institute is not engaged in seeking patch¬ work remedies for international maladjustments; it is not concerned with immediate results and therefore by its own constitution prohibits the pass¬ ing of resolutions or the making of recommendations in the field of public affairs by the organization as such. It is engaged, rather, in the long- term work of searching for patterns of relationships in the Pacific area and in disseminating what knowledge it unearths as widely as possible. What the Institute loses in academic remoteness from immediate burning issues, it gains by a more basic and consequently sounder method of procedure, III. TRENDS OF INSTITUTE CONFERENCES The foregoing are certain of the characteristics of Institute Confer¬ ences which serve to locate the place of its discussions in contemporary affairs and in the international methods of instruments for dealing with them. It may next be profitable to introduce the forthcoming discussions with further remarks designed to indicate the trends of Institute Conferences, trends culminating in the agenda outlined for Banff. Broadly, the discernible trends in the Conferences have been these: (l) from undocumented discussion to discussion fully supported by long-term research and briefs especially pre¬ pared for the particular disoussion; (2) from the more cultural aspects of international relations and therefore from those less susceptible to scientific study to the more economic and analyzable aspects; (3) from a concentration on the affairs of the Far East and especially China to an emphasis on problems underlying the affairs of the whole Pacific area; (4) from emotionally-charged and disputable categories, such as, sovereignty, nationality, rights, duties, obligations, or "face," to the more fundamental and real categories of trade, finance, education, standard of living, or in¬ dustrialization; and, lastly, (5) from a consideration of the purely external affairs of nations to the total domestic and foreign situation of which external activities are merely a part. Each of these trends will be briefly discussed. a. Towards Fully Documental Discussion The first Conference, held in Honolulu in 1925, in round tables and public forums undertook to consider a wide range of topics from national points of view towards Pacific problems to the effects of industrialization and the export of capital. Most time, however, was devoted to migrations and the missionary movement. It was found that accurate information ms lacking, thereby greatly handicapping the possibilities of intelligent discussion. Ihe papers which were issued to the Conference were presentations of a variety

of opinions rather than of the facts from whioh opinions could be formulated^ It is to the credit of those who participated in this initial Conference and in the subsequent one held in 1927 that this lack was recognized and that plans were laid for a program of long-term research to be conducted under^ the auspices of national research committees coordinated with an internation¬ al research oommittee administered by the Central Secretariat. From this point forward a well-planned program of research was undertaken, itself providing substantial documentation for subsequent Conferences and indirect¬ ly furnishing important sources of information for the data papers or briefs prepared especially for each Conference. The development of the Institute's program of research will be con¬ sidered in a separate report and it is necessary in the present document only to call attention to the trend in the relation of research to the Con¬ ferences and particularly to the Banff discussions. The tendency to docu¬ ment the Conferences more and more adequately has made it possible this year to expect the fulfillment of two desiderata: first, that each major subject of discussion will be adequately supported by data drawn from each of the areas in which the Institute has organized groups; and, second, that data from each area will be comparable to those from each other area. An unfortunate by-product of this trend has been the ever growing volume of material presented to Conference members shortly before the open¬ ing of the first session, a mass too great to digest in a short space of^ time, especially inasmuch as that period is taken up with other matters in¬ cident to the Conference. The Institute has attempted to overcome this in two ways. The first, and most obvious, has been to lengthen the period dur¬ ing which documents may be studied by endeavoring to issue the papers well in advance. Administrative obstacles have heretofore prevented the realiza¬ tion of this objective, although a decided improvement in this direction is anticipated for Banff. The second method has been the preparation of syllabi which serve as summaries of what is more elaborately contained in the numer¬ ous data papers. It is intended for Banff that these syllabi, in addition to providing summaries such as those presented for the Shanghai Conference, shall provide guides or indexes to the Conference documentation with topical page references. A further measure is planned for the forthcoming meeting in the form of numerous wall maps and charts for the purpose of illustrating visually the data contained in the documents. Not only, therefore, may the discussions be expected to be more adequately documented than before, but several methods will be further developed whereby the data may be more readily utilized. b» Towards Economic Questions A trend away from the more cultural and towards the more economic aspects of questions has been noted. Two factors, perhaps, account for this shift in emphasis. In spite of the active participation of experts on the cultures of the different civilizations involved, there has been a conspicuous lack of success in analyzing these cultural elements in a way suitable for either research or discussion. Cultural factors have remained elusive, protected by a vagueness that has so far defied attempts to break down the larger cefcegory into the elements which compose it. On the other hand, the more sociological and the more economic aspects of the relations

of the people of the Pacific have more easily succumbed to scientific in¬ vestigation. Wliereas such a topic as the Maohine Age and Traditional Cul¬ ture, which was essayed at the Kyoto Conference, remained baffling, a topic such as Industrialization in the Pacifio Area has been subjected to statis¬ tical analysis in a dozen forms and the sub-categories readily ascertained by experts. A counter tendency is at present apparent in the desire ex¬ pressed by several groups, that at the 1935 Conference the emphasis be shifted away from the economic conditions at present under consideration to matters of education. It is to be hoped that if this counter tendency is realized an entering wedge will successfully have been made to the analysis of cultural problems. In approaching cultural matters the Institute may have relied too much on persons merely having familiarity with traditional culture but lacking scientific training in the analysis of culture. A number of scientifically trained persons, associated with the Institute, are now directing their attention to the dissection of cultural matters for purposes of research and discussion. This effort, coupled with the interest in educa¬ tion noted above, promises to place these heretofore elusive problems on a footing with the more materialistic aspects of the affairs of the Pacific. The movement towards eoonomic questions has a more fundamental ex¬ planation in contemporary affairs. Successive post-war crises, not only in Europe but also in the Far East, although often political in their superficial aspects, have been primarily of an eoonomic nature. Security, that all- inclusive category so prominent in current international jargon, is essential¬ ly oomposed of a number of economic factors — whether in France or Japan. The modern form of the Monroe Doctrine just as much as Japan's Right to Live Dootrine is made up of elements primarily economic. The current world-wide economic crisis, announced by the New York stock market crash just as the Kyoto Conference was beginning, reinforced this tendency in the Institute's activities $ and the Japanese occupation of Manchuria, which began just before the Shanghai discussions, furthered the movement. The mandate, indeed, for the Banff agenda is given by the recurrent and intense international conflict in the last two decades whioh, though political in form, has been economic in content. o. Towards Wider Geographical Area "— " ■ .'■ ' ii i. 'i ■■..... ......... ............I..I. A third trend has been noted, from concentration on the affairs of the Far East to a wider geographical area. Much of the conflict in this part of the world has apparently been centered in China, and more particularly in China's treaty ports and foreign settlements and in Manchuria — in places, in other words, where the dynamic expansionism of modern economic countries met China's ancient methods and forms of society and economy. Whether over the rights of extraterritoriality and the attendent problems of administering justic«# over thm ganotity and validity of treaties, over the operation of foreign»finanoed railways, or over the official attitude towards missionary schools, most of th* irritating matters seemed concentrated on Chinese soil. In consequence of this apparent fact the first three, and even four, Confer¬ ences devoted special attention to a searching examination of China. The superficiality of this view became evident only when experience had demonstrated the importance of investigating deeper than the surface mani¬ festations of conflict. It then appeared that the extraterritorial privileges and the social, legal and economic obstacles under which foreigners operated

in China were no different in kind, but only different in degree, from the status of aliens in any country. The problem of aliens was thereafter view¬ ed as one common to all the countries of the Pacific, a problem acute in the United States in the period around 1924 and acute in China, for quite other reasons, over the entire decade0 Nor, has it appeared, could the problem involved in the importation of large quantities of foreign capital by China be approached without reference to somewhat analagous situations prevailing at different periods in the United States, Canada, Japan and Australia. If for no other reason than better to understand affairs in China, therefore, the Institute would have been obliged to consider a wider area. The basio problems of the Pacific area cannot be explored success¬ fully in a single nation. In order to comprehend the modern phenomenon of expansionism from more to less highly organized economic areas, all of its ascertainable characteristics must be studied. The phenomenon manifests it¬ self quite otherwise in Indo-China than it does in Hawaii, or as carried on by the Germans in China in contrast to the methods employed there by the Japanesec Although the effects of expansionism vary greatly, the process seems to have elements in common regardless of the impelling force behind it. It is by means of the export of manufactured goods and capital and entire industries, and the import of raw and semi-manufactured materials and the accompanying phenomena of struggle for the control of communications, tariffs, exchange restrictions, and immigration legislation — a complex process which we have called expansionism — that different nations come . into contact. It is this whole process which the Banff Conference intends to explore. Behind the dynamics of expansionism is the organization of society, or the method of economy, we term capitalism; before it is the semi- feudal or semi-primitive organization of colonial or otherwise dominated territoriesc A study of the process, itself, of expansionism premises an analysis of its areas of origin and destination as well. And thus it is, that, coincident'with a shift to the more economic aspects of the affairs of the Pacific area, there is a corresponding shift to a more inclusive geo¬ graphical base. The analysis of the causes of and remedies for the world-wide economic depression support this trend to a wider area of concentration. Almost simultaneously, in every important country in the world, with the exception of the U.SoSoR.* indexes of economic welfare tumbled to unpre¬ cedented lows. There are those who attribute to international factors first place in causing the orash, and who see in the correction of these external factors the appropriate remedies* Others have discerned a parallel disinte¬ gration of various highly organized domestic economies towards the breakdown of which international factors were only an accompanying incident. To persons holding the latter view corrections must first be applied to internal condi¬ tions and only secondarily to international ones. Regardless of which of these positions, or the countless intermediate ones, is adhered to, it is patent that the crisis must be studied with reference to a large area and with reference to both domestic and international factors within it, rather than in a single country. In describing this trend, the term "Pacific Area" has been used loosely. The Pacific Ocean extends from the Bering Sea to the waters of the South Pole:

bordered on the West by Siberia, the Japanese Empire, China, Australia, and New Zealand; and on the East by Alaska, Canada, the United States, Mexico, Central America, and the western countries of South America; and containing the large island groups'of Polynesia, Micronesia.-, Melanesia, and Indonesia. The Institute has never, and is not yeti? concerned with a large section of the eastern boundary of the ocean. To date neither Alaska, Mexico, Central or South America has been prominent in its studies or discussions. These large areas have not applied for membership because, comparatively, they do not figure in the international affairs of the Pacific to the extent that do the regions included in the Institute's present scope. It has been felt that the growth of the organization should proceed from a nucleus of the regions and powers figuring most prominently in the Pacific and that areas on the fringe of these affairs should only gradually be absorbed. Thus it was not until the 1929 Conference that the islands of the southern Pacific were brought into the Institute's field of research, and it was only two years ago that contact was definitely established with groups in the U.S.S.R. It may be anticipated that because of the growing economic relations of Japan with nations of South America, the Institute may soon endeavor to form cor¬ responding groups there. It may also hapoen that the relations between Mexico and the United States and the Orient will become of sufficient concern to the area as a whole to point out the wisdom of drawing that region into the Institute's view. For the present, however, the countries mentioned are on the periphery of the "Pacific Area" as the term is broadly used in this paper. d. Towards Real Categories The approach to international problems by way of the complex of realities which compose them rather than by way of the generalities whioh serve to keep their true nature hidden, has been suggested as a further trend in the Institute's work. Viewed in one way, the question of extra¬ territoriality in China is a problem of constant irritation in which matters of prestige, honor, so-called racial and national characteristics, odious comparisons of superiority and inferiority, and similar vague concepts dis¬ tort the true picture. In actuality, the system of extraterritoriality is for the most part concerned with strictly defineable commercial and legal matters somewhat colored one way or another by a shifting political scene. If a discussion approaches the problem through the political end, one may confidently predict that it will exaggerate all the emotional prejudices of the participants and become hopelessly involved in a maze of meaningless^ generalities. If, on the other hand, the approach is through the realities of discernable economic and sociological factors, the main substance of extra¬ territoriality will have been comprehended before the more difficult and delicate political fringe of the system is reached. On the basis of a com¬ prehension of the core of the problem, it is reasonable to expect a more successful dissection of the periphery. The point is well illustrated by the Institute's experience with the problems of Manchuria. It would be an unwarranted claim to assert that the Institute has materially altered the affairs of that area one way or another. With respect to immediate events the Institute's part in affecting their^ course could be discerned only with a microscope. But this is not to maintain that by long attention the Institute has not developed a sound and practical

method of approaching the troublesome problems of Manchuria; or that in the course of learning this method it has not produced studies and held discus¬ sions which may in the long run prove influential; or that its members who have participated in this work have not gained considerable insight into the nature of these problems* The Institute has learned this much: that the Manchurian question cannot be approached as such, that it must be broken up into its component parts: that these parts are not fundamentally questions of doctrines or rights or duties, nor questions of treaties or sovereignty, nor liberalism versus oonservatism versus radicalism; that essentially the Manchurian question is composed of realities lying behind policies, treaties, or eoonomic or political creeds — realities such as the relation of popula¬ tion to arable land and food supply, the relation of industrialization to sources of raw materials and fuels and markets, and the allied matters of tariffs, monetary and credit systems, exchange, the standard of living in relation to the distribution of wealth, minority factions and general wel¬ fare, communications via water, air, or land, and a host of comparable factors. It is not claimed that the Institute is alone in developing this method of approach to otherwise'baffling international difficulties. Certain phases of the work of the League of Nations have broken ground towards the same objective. It is pertinent to note how closely the topics of the special studies made by the staff associated with the Lytton Commission of Inquiry parallels the categories under which the Institute has been studying the same problems. The special studies of experts of the Commission were: Memorandum on Railway Questions; What is the Economic Importance of Manchuria for Japan?; Chinese Migration to Manchuria; Memorandum on Public Finance in Manchuria Prior to and'after September 18, 1931; The Currencies of the Northeastern Provinces, with a Supplement on the Central Bank of Manchukuo; Manchuria's Trade with China Proper and with Foreign Countries; Chinese, Japanese and Other Foreign Investments in Manchuria; Memorandum on Boycotts and Japanese Interests in China; Korean Problems in Manchuria as Factors in the Sino-Japanese Dispute. A glance at the Institute's list of published studies on Manchuria will indicate the common recognition on the part of these two bodies of the realities of the situation. To close students of international affairs these remarks may be com¬ monplace. It is necessary therefore, to point out that in the main the oonduct of international relations is seldom conducted by close students of international affairs. Qualified persons have eloquently pleaded that the League Council and Assembly approach the Manchurian conflict by the same method as its own Commission did and in the way developed over several years by the Institute of Pacific Relations. They have pointed out that despite the experiences of these groups, the League's deliberative bodies haye per¬ sisted in entering into the controversy by way of concepts of sovereignty and "face". And it can be maintained that the latter is the usual approach. It is the approach too often employed in schools, universities and associa¬ tions for adult education or public information* It may be recorded parenthetically that it is the approach so far employed by the Institute it¬ self in the study of cultural relations, and it seems likely that until the Institute considers the larger category in terms of the many real categories that make it up, substantial success will not be attained.

Towards Comprehensive Point of "View There remains to be described one more trend: from a consideration of the purely external affairs of nations to their total domestic and foreign"activity in which the latter plays the less important role. The relevance of certain domestic factors, such as the relation of food supply, population and land utilization, and population policies to ££»*J™b affairs has been recognized from the beginning of the Institute's activities. Land utilization was made one of the first subjects of long-term investiga¬ tion by the International Research Committee and allied subjects of iood and population were discussed in the early Conferences. A trend, however, has been noticeable in the realization of the fundamental unity of all human activity and the recognition of the fact that no problem ^ inter¬ national relations can be divorced from the domestic situations which gave rise to it. While there remains considerable room for theoretical dispute as to the relative weight of international and domestic factors in the determination of any given episode and in regard to the order of Parity to be assigned the more materialistic and the more cultural factors, there can be little disagreement with the statement that, viewed comprehensively, the activities of modern societies originate in several economic and social nuclei which more or less correspond to the political boundaries of coun¬ tries. From these nuclei, in so far as they are dynamic proceed movements of expansion which meet in the external area of international affairs. The external contact may be of a compensatory or a conflicting nature, but in any case it oan be understood only in the light of the entire situation of which it usually forms the smaller part, and the internal or domestic factors the larger part. The agenda prepared for the Banff Conference is the result of this trend towards recognition of the underlying unity of all activity and ^ important position of domestic factors in determining and conditioning inter¬ national relations. Whether the discussions will point to a further emphasis on the domestic structure, which forms the core of world affairs, «'»?*»*■ a matter for conjecture. It may be anticipated, however, that they will marK a decisive point in the Institute's study of the problems of the ^cJf^ area, a point marking a comprehensive approach to the affairs of that region reached through successive years of exploration into fragments. It may further be prophesied that once this point has been reached the fundamental comprehensive view will be retained and future discussions will proceed according to a systematic investigation of certain aspects of the entire problem. IV. BANFF AGENDA The Banff agenda has been throughout this paper described as a cul¬ mination of eight years of experience in the study of the affairs of the Pacific area through a mutually supporting process of discussion and re¬ search. In view of the contemplated attendance of many who have had no more than casual contact with the Institute, it was thought useful to pro¬ duce the Banff Conference by a survey of the characteristics and trends^oi the organization during its brief period of activity. The survey contained in the foregoing pages has repeatedly reached back into the Institute s history to trace developments leading up to the forthcoming discussions.

The subjects to be dealt with at Banff have not been directly considered. On the contrary, the purpose has been to describe the intellectual setting of the Conference, in the attempted fulfillment of which, frequent mention has been made of the subjects suggested in the agenda. The Banff Conference will consider controversial, troublesome fea¬ tures of economic relations in the Pacific area, and political and educa¬ tional problems arising out of these economic factors. The discussions will be conducted according to a technique, as yet imperfect, but marking a considerable advance over haphazard methods of debate and without the handicaps of official responsibility. They will be documented by papers prepared especially for the purpose by each of the Instituted National Councils and by syllabi and charts prepared by the Central Secretariat. Por the most part, these documents will be sent to members well in advance of the opening session. The agenda which follows is designed to explore the economic con¬ tacts which form so much of the main structure of the international rela¬ tions of the Pacific Area. Upon this structure is a superstructure of political and cultural factors, which for the most part appear to be deter¬ mined by the economic basis but which in turn condition the operation of economic forces. It is with the origin, nature and results of these economic foroes that the Banff Conference will be concerned. A diagnosis of the af¬ fairs of the Pacific will be essayed in order to determine the part played by economic factors, the possibility of controlling or eradicating those which produce conflict and of supporting those which make for general wel¬ fare. The whole subject is viewed, in the following agenda, first, in terms of trends to or away from economic self-sufficiency together with quantita¬ tive and qualitative evaluations of the trends; second, in relation to the governmental and industrial set-up which, operating upon geographical and social premises, produces economic forces and policies; and, third, with respect to the political and educational implications of the foregoing. 1. ECONOMIC CONFLICT AND CONTROL General Theme: Trends of economic dependence or interdependence in regard to food and population, raw materials, manufactured goods, oapital movements, and means of communication. A. Analysis of the tendencies toward an organized economic self-suffi¬ ciency in certain Pacific regions and their effect on commercial rela¬ tions. The discussion of this general question will involve considera¬ tion of the more specific economic elements which make it up, such as: 1. access to raw materials and markets, 2. commodity trade, 5. movements of capital, 4, tariffs, 5. communications.

The economic elements will be considered in such questions for discussion as: (a) to what extent has it been found necessary to dominate or control sources of raw materials and foreign market politically? (b) to what extent have political (e.g., national) or economic (e.ge, tariff) barriers to trade forced the utilization and arti¬ ficial stimulation of marginal resources and markets? (o) how far has the process of expansionism justified itself in the economic sense — e„g«, the U.S. and the Philippines, France and Indo-China, Great Britain and the Pacific Dominions, Japan and its colonies and areas of special influence? How far has it brought permanent economic benefits to industrial nations? How far has it improved the economic status of the non- industrialized regions affected by it? (d) to what extent have political considerations determined move¬ ments of capital? (e) what has been the trend in the relations between creditor and debtor nations? (f) have the tariff policies of Pacific countries justified them¬ selves in an economic sense? This question should be considered from the point of view both of the nation imposing the tariff and from that of all those affected by it. Each of the foregoing subdivisions would appear to involve con¬ sideration of the relations of particular areas or groups either exist¬ ing or in process of forming, e.g., the British Commonwealth, the U.S.A., the U.S.S.R., the Japanese Empire, etc. What is the effect of existing government systems and business methods on the use of the resources of the Pacific? The discussion of this general question will^involve consideration of the more specific economic elements which make it up, such as: 1. tariffs and measures of administrative control, 2. migration policies and administrative procedure, 5, foreign loan policies, 4. commercial policies, 5. communications. These economic elements will be considered in such questions for discussion as: (a) how have tariffs, migration policies, foreign loan policies, commercial policies and the development of communications hindered or facilitated the best use of the resources of the Pacific? In this connection other governmental and business forces such as chambers of commerce, export asso-

ciations, patriotic societies, governmental trade promotion, Otoe, should be considered in the same light, (b) to what extent and in what ways do governments control private enterorises involved in external relations? To what extent and in what ways do these private enterprises in¬ fluence governments? (c) how have governments and private enterprises planned their external operations? To what extent have these plans been effective in achieving the ends desired? To what extent do these plans represent the aims and interests of the people they directly or indirectly affect? Each of the foregoing subdivisions should be considered with reference to particular nations or groups of nations. C. What proposals can be made for a more harmonious disposition of the resources of the Pacific area or for introducing into the existing methods discussed above improvements in the general interest? The course of the discussion under A and B should determine the topics and course of discussion under C. II. INSTRUMENTS FOR INTERNATIONAL ADJUSTMENT 1, What instruments for international negotiation and consultation and adjustments are necessary to meet Pacific problems? 2. Wherein is existing machinery inadequate for these purposes? 3. Any other points germane to the foregoing, including similar questions which may arise in the course of the discussion. The Secretariat recommends that the foregoing questions would probably be most effectively discussed if timed to come during the second week of the conference after substantial progress had been made with the general economic discussions. It is suggested that whoever is responsible for opening up the discussion of these questions should bear in mind the desirability of exploring, among others, the following questions: (a) To ff*™™ should domestic policies determining the external ^havior of nat ions be internationally controlled, and by what methods; (b) To what extent should national units be used as the basis for representation in inter¬ national consultation and action; (c) To what extent is functional responsibility possible and desirable? HI. PROBLEMS OF EDUCATION Some of the educational questions likely to come up during the dis¬ cussion of the economic and political factors are as follows:-

In what ways and to what extent are economic maladjustments in the Pacific area aggravated by eduoational systems and methods that fail to take into account both national and international needs? Specifically, (a) how do the school curricula and policies of vocational guidance relate to the economic opportunities of different areas and regions? (b) what relation is there between the national aspirations expressed in educational objectives and the conflicting demands of sectional self-sufficiency on the one hand and of the possibilities of inter¬ national trade on the other? (c) by what means are traditional skills and social and technical heritages of importance to the livelihood of peoples capable of being preserved, protected, or readapted to present-day require¬ ments? (d) to what extent do educational systems and methods contribute to raise or stabilize standards of living j and what is the effect of such influences on the interchange of commodities and services? What is the experience with active educational measures for birth control as a means of lessening population pressure? What part does educational effort play in protecting Pacific peoples against the competition of immigrants with lower standards of living? What part does migration, both temporary and permanent, play in the reevaluation of cultural standards; and by what educational or other measures may increased international contact be freed from disruptive effects on the social and economic life of native peoples? What, on the other hand, is the probability that the effect of the present depression in diminishing international contact and exchange will lead to a permanent reorientation of economic effort, and what changes in the educational system are needed: (a) to provide new opportunities for talents denied free access to other countries or regions, (b) to readapt social habits and mores to a more self-centered economic situation? What does a planned economy, whether national or in part inter¬ nationally cooperative, involve with respect to new educational objectives?
