essay:div.essay:p: THE PURPOSE AND CONDUCT OF ROUND TABLES FOREWORD In A Guide to the Banff Discussions the Secretariat has endeavored to describe the purposes and methods of the Institute of Pacific Relations, relating these matters particularly to the forthcoming Banff Conference. An elaboration of a certain part of the Institute's activities, Conference round tables, is contained in the following pages. The Institute has de¬ veloped round table discussions as a method especially suited to group study of the comprehensive problems of the Pacific area. In the course of the four preceding Conferences this method has been continually developed so that it may now be regarded as a well-defined technique designed to fulfil desirable aims. This pamphlet is intended primarily for those who will participate in an Institute Conference for the first time at Banff. As indicated by its title, it attempts to reveal what part round table discussions play in the study of the affairs of the Pacific and precisely what the round table method is. Members who have attended previous Conferences are already familiar with much that is contained in the following pages; they are urged, nevertheless, to glance through this recapitulation in order to refresh their memories. I. THE PURPOSE OF ROUND TABLES Round table discussions are the principal mechanism and activity of the biennial Conferences of the Institute of Pacific Relations. The Conferences, however, comprise neither the whole nor the most important part of the Institute's activities; they are merely one of several steps which cannot be evaluated in terms of relative importance, but all of which taken together aim to fulfil the purpose of the organization. This purpose is described in most general terms in the Institute's Constitution as the "study of the conditions of the Pacific peoples with a view to the improve¬ ment of their mutual relations." It is assumed that through study, and through the implied correlated activity of dispersing the results of study, improvement in the relations of the people of this area will result. In the process of study, round tables play an essential role. The inseparable relation among the Institute's continuous activities makes it impossible to assign primary importance to any one. In the in¬ terval between Conferences and during these biennial gatherings, the In¬ stitute's researches and the complicated process of spreading the results thus obtained together with other information on the affairs of the Pacific area continue. Both activities in part arise from Conference discussions and in part produce these discussions. The topics for study are often de¬ fined by Conferences, and, in turn, the subjects for discussion are in large measure determined by previous research. Similarly, the spreading of information is greatly facilitated through, and directed by round table discussions; but this educational work also imparts the data necessary for successful discussion.

In attempting to state the purpose of the round tables, therefore, this paper cannot ignore the indivisibility of the Institute's total ac¬ tivity of which discussion forms but one important segment. Round Tables and the Study of Pacif ic J^eoplej^ A premise to the whole idea of an Institute of Pacific Relations is that accurate information widely disseminated is a prerequisite to intel¬ ligent activity in the modern world. Acceptance of such a premise implies that this function is not and cannot be better performed by another form of organization. It is not pertinent to the subject of this paper to develop this thought beyond the mere statement that in certain fields of human relations in the Pacific at least the work of nationally oriented governments and private organizations - the latter being often further oriented in the direction of prejudiced interests - needs to be supplemented, and that in other fields of human relations in the Pacific little systematic study is being undertaken except by the Institute. Coordination and Initiation of Research and Education - Study of the^ affairs of the Pacific is a vast undertaking requiring all manner of investi¬ gations . Specialists are equipped to carry on research in a clearly defined direction. But, in as complicated a field of thought as the relations of the peoples of the Pacific, they are seldom capable either of formulating the problem for research adequately in its relation to other problems or in viewing the significance of their particular field; nor are they to be counted on to correlate and interpret correctly the total results of numerous investi¬ gations. The research worker in most cases is further limited by the very nature of his profession from estimating the applicability of his findings to the world of practical affairs, in which the current evaluations of truth are woefully modified by the limitations of modern societies. The research specialist, then, takes simply a few steps in a long journey. Other steps, in the Institute's activities, are covered by experts in the dissemination of information, whether through the agencies of formal education, adult education, or popular education as exemplified by the newspaper and radio. But here, too, the expert in education is helpless without the materials furnished by research; likewise he must not only shape his policies by intimate knowledge of the current attitudes of all types of individuals, but must also test his methods by constant reference to their effects upon the layman. The cooperation of the layman is therefore essential to the success¬ ful conduct of either research or education, just as the assistance of the research worker and educator is a necessity in the pursuit of business or public affairs. In the ordinary course of events, specialists in these fields cooperate haphazardly, or if not haphazardly, in respect to small fragments of human relations, A function of Institute Conferences is to give opportunity for the mutual consideration of comprehensive problems of the pacific area by individuals otherwise concerned with specialized branches of activity and with restricted subjects of thought. At these Conferences it is expected that the work of each member will be determined and tested in the light of the experiences and attitudes of the others. The result is intended to be clearer comprehension of the problems of the area, and of methods, within the scope of the Institute, of dealing with them.

The Round Table Method of Study - The document entitled A Guide to the Banff Discussions points out that' the Institute's round tables are care¬ fully planned gatherings of qualified individuals for the purpose^of con¬ sidering an agenda according to a scientific technique of discussion. The foregoing general considerations may, therefore, be applied to the round table process. The document just referred to described the Banff agenda as the culmination of many years of Institute activity in the study of Pacific problems, and as emphasizing the international economic relations which appear to be basic in relation to political affairs. The direct object of the round tables will be to progress towards understanding the causes and characteristics of these economic relations and to explore the possibilities of resolving the problems that arise therefrom. The indirect purpose will be to further the processes of research and the spreading of information m the light of this clearer comprehension of the factors involved. In pursuing its immediate purpose, round table procedure calls for three steps, usually to be followed in the order named: first, by drawing out all facts, attitudes, and opinions pertinent to the matter at hand, to locate the problem; second, on the basis of this evidence, to formulate and become more clearly aware of the problem or problems; and, third, to move as far as possible towards a solution. The method of proceeding through these steps is one in which each member of the round table contributes. It is intended that no one play the role of informer and no one that of mere listener. It is assumed that whatever results from a round table will be something quite_different from the ideas of any one participant or small group at the opening of the session - only as the thoughts which finally emerge are the result of many minds are they likely to have general validity. It is an axiom that the process of learning is vivid and lasting to^ an individual only just so far as he has intelligently and actively partici¬ pated in an experience, and in proportion to the intensity or quality of that participation. A by-product of the Institute's round ^able method then, is the understanding obtained by the members of the problems which they have been exploring. Such a result is directly proportional to the degree to which participation has been mutual and to which the problem under review has been successfully considered. The extent to which the agenda has been successfully explored, moreover, determines the contribution Conference members make to the problems of research and information and the effectiveness with which they can subsequently forward the organization's ultimate purpose of developing widespread intelligent public opinion on the affairs of the Pacific. The Improvement of Relations - Improving the relations of Pacific peoples-implies that the study ot' these relations has a defmite.end in view and suggests the possibility of acting upon the findings of study in order to achieve this end. Such an interpretation is correct only within limits which it is rather difficult to define. The very postulate on which the Institute is founded, that widespread information is a

prerequisite to intelligent action, points to the necessity not only for conducting research but also for disseminating information as widely and effectively as possible. On the other hand, the Institute refrains from performing a legislative function or anything remotely connected with such an immediate or practical activity, and it restrains round tables from passing resolutions or making recommendations in the sphere of public af¬ fairs. Two questions arise: first, where between these points of merely spreading information and. taking legislative action does the Institute's function cease; and, second, in these times when immediate solutions must be found for current difficulties, what justification is there for an or¬ ganization which refuses to affect contemporary affairs to the limit of its influence? Long-Term Considerations - The limits of the Institute's direct in- volvement in contemporary affairs, or, let us say, in international politics, must be determined by the long-term strategy necessary for the successful pursuit of its aims. The organization has three characteristics which condition its strategy: it is unofficial and cannot therefore act with authority in the political field; it is international and so must take into consideration a vastly more complex set of facts and criteria in determining a wise course of action than do nationally located organizations; it is objective in that it has no predetermined notions except the premise here¬ tofore mentioned, and in consequence has the entire welfare of the peoples of the Pacific (and by logical extension the peoples of the whole world) to consider in establishing values instead of the specified purposes of organizations with more limited scope and more immediate purposes. These points are illustrated by an example used in a previous essay on the Institute. It was suggested in a paper published in the 1927 volume of the Proceedings that the Conference of that year had possibly erred by moving too near the contemporary political field when it attempted to lay down certain principles which might guide statesmen in reaching sound de¬ cisions. That Conference discussed, among other subjects, the international implications of the Japanese population problem. Without making any specific recommendation, the members tended to endorse the Japanese contention that other nations should modify their own policies with respect to immigration and trade barriers in order to assist Japan in coping with its rapidly in¬ creasing population. While this principle may have been theoretically sound, events of the next few years indicated it to be entirely out of line with practical possibilities. Since 1927, rather than provide assis¬ tance to Japan which was in an obviously difficult predicament, other nations have increased the obstacles to a solution of that problem. There was further an implied theoretical fallacy in that the affirmation of the obligations of other nations in this matter might lead Japanese statesmen to rely too greatly on the possibilities of outside assistance in relieving a problem, the core of which was a matter for domestic measures of population control and distribution. The sound, long-term course for the Institute in this particular question might better have been restricted to a continuous study of the facts of the matter and constant effort to have the significance of the facts grasped by as large a section of the public as possible. It is doubt¬ ful whether the occasion arises more than rarely when the Institute's course

should be nearer the field of action. There are, nevertheless, certain affairs of the Pacific lying well on the periphery of politics where the indirect influence of the Institute may make itself felt in bringing about changes. In 1929, for instance, the organization's concern in the matter was partly responsible for a reduction in the rates charged for cabling news from Japan. The Institute is at present working on a project designed to help standardize the computation of trade statistics by the various countries of the Pacific. From questions of this sort to influencing alterations in American college entrance requirements with a view to in¬ creasing the value of Oriental studies or otherwise affecting the educa¬ tional curriculum, the Institute is operating in a legitimate sphere. But both the philosophy originally laid down for the guidance of the or¬ ganization and its own experience has shown the wisdom of avoiding action directed towards producing quick legislative results in the political field. Relation to Current Political Events - The question may appropriate¬ ly be asked": What justification has such an organization in times like these when immediate solutions are demanded for pressing difficulties? What use is an organization which, for instance, will do nothing immediately to affect the present conflict between China and Japan? A negative answer lies in the manifest superficiality of hurried decisions which in the political realm must so often be made on fragmentary information. The task of the Institute is through continuous study and deliberation to, lay the groundwork of knowledge on which a sound political structure may in the course of time be erected. It must be wary of pressing for action even in the most critical times. The writer previously referred to, sums up this difficult point by stating that the Institute is "not equipped to extricate governments from international crises, particularly when they arise from the faulty past experience of the Pacific peoples. It may and should help to create the inquisitive public opinion in the various countries of the Pacific which may prevent the precipitation of these ugly crises . . . but beyond that it will guard its conduct from being unreal, not by trying to contribute to practical political solutions, but by keeping, no matter what happens, the lamp of disinterested and thorough inquiry ablaze." It would appear that the function of becoming aware of activity in the Pacific area and the consequences of that activity by constant disin¬ terested attention and of imparting that awareness to as many citizens of the area as possible, is not only an important one, but is essential if recurring economic and political crises are to be eliminated from the future. In the light of the foregoing discussion the task of members of the Banff round tables will be to comprehend the international economic rela¬ tions of the Pacific, seeking that understanding needed to contribute to the specialized functions of research and the spreading of information, and to base resulting action particularly of a corporate nature upon lines determined by long-term considerations for promoting the purposes for which the Institute was founded.

II. THE CONDUCT OF ROUND TABLES The phrase "scientific technique of discussion" is used in connection with Institute Conferences to suggest not that the process of conducting round tables has been reduced to a science in the strict meaning of the word, but that, in comparison with a haphazard procedure, the Institute's round tables are the well-defined result of considerable analysis and ex¬ periment. It is recognized that there are several ways in which a group may consider a question depending upon the purpose of the deliberation, the personnel of the group, the subject under consideration, the amount of information available on the topic, and the experience in methods of group discussion. A group of college students studying the industrial revolution under a professor will clearly use a different technique from a meeting of representatives of capital and labor for the purpose of arbitrating a wage scale, yet each is a method of group exploration. Similarly, the board of directors of a corporation, meeting to make certain immediate decisions, will conduct its discussion in a manner quite different from a chamber of commerce gathering called to hear a prominent industrialist speak. Postulates of Institute Discussions In considering the conduct of round tables, therefore, certain as¬ sumptions having to do with purposes, subject matter, preparation and per¬ sonnel must be kept in mind. The objects of the discussions being compre¬ hension of the matter in hand with no immediate resulting action in the political field, the round tables will not endeavor to reach decisions calling for such action. They will subject the topic under consideration to a thorough analysis and move as far as possible along the road of synthesis. Documentation - The conduct of round tables is also conditioned by the elaborate documentation made available prior to the Conference. It is anticipated that every major subject of discussion will be fully supported with data from each of the countries concerned, and, further, that these data will be comparable for each geographical area. The discussions will be conducted on the assumption that each participant is familiar with^these data. There will thus be eliminated from the round tables the necessity^ for introductory statements of fact, for questions of fact, and, except in rare instances, for dispute over facts. The discussions will begin with the problems arising out of the skeleton of fact - with such matters as attitudes, opinions, interpretations, which cannot be successfully docu¬ mented - and then proceed to a formulation of the problem and subsequent synthesis. Previous Discussions - It has been pointed out in "A Guide to the Banff Discussions that the point of departure for round tables will be the accumulated experience of the four preceding Institute Conferences and the activities the organization has conducted in each intervening biennium. In that certain aspects of the international economic relations of the Pacific have been considered by previous round tables, members of the forthcoming Conference will be expected, in addition to being familiar with the Banff documents, to inform themselves of the earlier considerations of allied topics. The records of past Conferences may be found in the Proceedings published during the year following each of the Conferences.

The Secretariat will, moreover, attempt to summarize the pertinent parts of previous discussions in the syllabi which it will issue shortly before the opening of the Banff sessions. Participation as Individuals - A third premise of the Instituted round table discussions involves the capacity in which and the attitude with which members participate. It will be taken for granted that they take part as individuals, not as representatives of groups, and that they view the subjects to be discussed dispassionately. No opportunity will be given for "making a case" on behalf of this or that interest, group, or nation. The round tables will not be interested in defense as such. On first thought this characteristic may be regarded as making the round table discussions unreal, but this view results from a misinterpretation. There is a vast difference between arguing on behalf of some group and describing for purposes of understanding the characteristics of that group. By the former, understanding becomes secondary to propaganda; by the second, predatory and national interests are analyzed and taken into account as objective realities in a larger situation. Central Secretariat Documents - It may finally be noted, in sug- gesting the background of the round tables, that members will be assumed to be familiar with the three documents being issued by the Central Secre¬ tariat, in which the aims and activities of the Institute are fully discussed in relation to the Banff Conference. These are A Guide to the Banff Dis¬ cussions, the present paper, and a report on the work of the International Research Committee which will be issued shortly. Characteristics of the Institute's Round Tables The object of describing the purposes and background of round tables in the preceding pages has been to furnish a setting for a consideration of the special characteristics of the discussions the Institute has developed. In order to fulfill the purpose for which Conferences are held a certain type of round table procedure is considered most suitable, and its charac-* teristics are further determined by the attitude and knowledge of partici¬ pants . Group Discussion - Round table discussions are, in the first place, an occasion for group, as distinguished from individual, exploration of a subject. That part of study which can better be performed individually, such as ascertaining the known facts of the matter, is assumed to have been completed by each participant before the round table session begins. The object of the group discussion is to bring to mind a wide variety of reactions, attitudes and interpretations based on objective facts. These attitudes comprise as important a part of the study of a subject as the objective facts themselves. It is believed that the round table method is the most suitable one for revealing these attitudes. For a full under¬ standing of a question, moreover, individual opinions must be tested and the possibilities of harmonizing them with each other and with objective facts fully explored. The Institute's round tables, therefore, are quite different from either the lecture or debate methods. In the former an authority gives his audience his own interpretation of events. No opinions, other than

the lecturerfs, are revealed, and his are not subjected to critical analysis except in the individual minds of those who compose the audi¬ ence. A debate, or method of parliamentary procedure, furnishes an opportunity for presenting and defending two points of view. Its limi¬ tations as a method of study lie in the falseness of the assumption that there are merely two sides to a question, and in the necessity for defending a position once taken instead of modifying it in the light of new evidence. The purpose of a round table, on the contrary, is to bring out all relevant points of view, and in the exchange of ideas to further the understanding of the subject under consideration by all participants. Widespread Participation - A closely related characteristic of In¬ stitute discussions is widespread participation. Members of round tables are in no wise separated into two groups, those who are particularly well- informed on the subject under consideration and who monopolize the discus¬ sion, and those who sit in as listeners. The topics selected for discussion are comprehensive; each participant is a specialist in certain phases, only the group as a whole may be considered expert on the entire question. The consideration of tariffs, for instance, is not, in the Institute's view, a subject suitable only for the tariff expert. Although there is a function to be performed by tariff experts in studying this topic, it is not a primary purpose of an Institute Conference. The tariff question, regarded broadly, involves business, legislation, law, education, farming, industry, finance, and a host of other matters in addition to the technical aspects of tariffs as such. Study of the tariff question, to be socially valid, requires the cooperation of persons of diverse experience, each contributing his interpretation into the common crucible. Role of ''Experts" - These considerations lead to a further character¬ istic of the Institute's round tables, namely, the role of the so-called expert. It has been suggested in the preceding paragraph that in the dis¬ cussion of a comprehensive topic each participant is a specialist on certain aspects of the matter, and that only the group is competent on the whole question. The term "expert," however, is conventionally usod to describe those having greater knowledge of the facts than others. It is desirable to consider the role of this group. One of the purposes of the full documentation prepared for round tables is to render the role of the expert on facts in the discussions themselves of secondary importance to the part played by the comparative layman. In discussions where careful preparation is not expected of parti¬ cipants, it is customary to have opening statements of fact presented by recognized authorities. The ensuing discussion, frequently crowded into the latter part of the session, usually revolves around these statements. The Institute precludes the dominant part thus played by the expert by taking his function out of the discussions themselves and supplying it in the documentation presented before the opening of round tables. The entire session is thus kept free for the mutual analysis and development of the subject by individuals of diverse experience and attitudes. This is not to imply that the expert on fact has no part in the Institute's discussions; it is merely intended to view his role in a perspective which the Institute regards as correct.

Round table chairmen will find that discussions at times reach an impasse which can be broken through only by calling upon a recognized authority. Inevitably, the discussions will discover gaps in the factual background given by data papers, they will reach points where expert in¬ terpretation of facts is required, or they will demand the presentation of interpretive hypotheses. In such instances, the round tables will have to rely on authorities in the matter under consideration. The testimony of experts, however, will be subsidiary to the discussion, not in control of it. Composition of Round Tables - The point which has been stressed throughout this section, the matter of bringing many diverse experiences to bear on the study of a problem, suggests the importance of having a wide variety of individuals at each round table. The Institute endeavors to fulfill this by inviting to the Conference members who will represent a cross-section of the public opinion of each country and by assigning to each round table a group which represents the whole Conference membership. publicity - The type of round table which is here described implies a discussion which is continually moving towards comprehension of the matter at hand. The point of view of each participant, it is expected, will change as it is shared with many other opinions. It consequently becomes important to eliminate any obstacle which tends to fix individual interpretations. One such obstacle prevails in most official and unofficial public delibera¬ tive bodies, namely, individual publicity. The opinions of prominent persons are customarily broadcast through newspapers, resulting in apparent incon¬ sistency when these opinions change. By eliminating personal publicity, the Institute endeavors to encourage a continual change of opinion, a change which is a prerequisite to unprejudiced discussion. What publicity is pro¬ vided is given out impersonally in the name of the round table as a whole. Major and Minor Round Tables - It is customary at Institute Con- ferences for the' entire membership to consider the major topics of the agenda in four or five simultaneous round tables, each having from twenty- five to thirty-five members. Each table usually meets several consecutive days to consider a comprehensive topic. The course of discussion varies from group to group so that each round table is very likely to develop different aspects of the subject from the other. In order that the entire Conference may have the benefit of the deliberations of each table, all the round tables meet together for a short session each day, at which bnel summaries of the discussions are presented. The Conference agenda contains certain minor topics which are of interest to a small section of the membership, and other minor topics develop out of the discussion of the major questions. As the Conference proceeds, therefore, special round tables are set up for the consideration of these problems of less general concern. In some cases a minor subject is so designated because of the paucity of ascertainable facts and a con¬ sequent lack of background for general participation in the discussion A possible case of this sort at Banff is the practice of dumping, of which the exporters of many nations are accused. There is little accurate data on this question and even the concept, dumping, itself is ill-deimea. In other cases, discussions are restricted to a small group because of the specialized nature of the subject in contrast to a comprehensive problem

(appropriate for general study. It may develop at Banff, for instance that an outgrowth of the general discussion of tariffs will involve the complicated matter of setting up satisfactory indexes for the measurement of tariff levels. A detail of this kind could be considered only by a specialized group. The general discussion of comprehensive problems will be the main concern of the Conference; specialized round tables will be merely sup¬ plementary. The agenda for the Banff Conference includes three major categories: first the international economic relations of the Pacific area; and second and third, political and educational implications of these economic rela- tions. Although details for carrying out the agenda have not been determined at the present writing, it may be assumed that these categories will be considered seriatim and that three or four or five round tables will con¬ sider these matters simultaneously. The principal emphasis of the Conference, economic affairs, will likely consume considerably more time than either political or educational implications. Procedure - Regardless of the varying lines of thought taken bythe different round^tables, each group may be expected to proceed systematically as regards method. In an earlier section of this paper the steps in this procedure have been described as follows: first, the location of the prob¬ lem bv drawing from all members attitudes and opinions based on the /acts presented in the Conference documents; second, the formulation of the problem and comprehension by all participants of what the problem has been found to be- and. third, the movement towards synthesis, or solution. In a well- managed discussion, the third step should be tlie one on which most attention is concentrated. A successful pursuit of this process should register sig¬ nificant advances in the "study of the conditions of the Pacific peoples with a view to the improvement of their mutual relations. Informal Discussions - The study of the subjects indicated on the agenda will not, howe^irThe limited to round table sessions The daily schedule will be so arranged as to provide ample opportunity for less formal conversations and discussions. The Institute does not seek to establish round table procedure as the sole method of study during Con¬ ferences; on the contrary, it sets up organized discussions simply *s ^ most suitable framework for study and numerous other methods will be utilized to furnish the details. Round Table Administration - A word may be added in regard to the administration of the Conference as it relates to the round tables. The International Program Committee, composed of a representat^?/^?™o National Council, is charged with drawing up the agenda. This Committee announced the principal subjects for the Banff Conference in the fall of 1931 and subsequently issued a more detailed agenda. Shortly before the Conference it will determine precisely what the round table topics will be and it will draw up a schedule covering the duration of the sessions according to which the subjects on the agenda may, in its opinion, be most successfully studied. It will then appoint chairmen and «c^"» for the discussions and with the cooperation of the latter draw up outlines for each round table. These outlines will be designed to suggest, though

not direct, the course of discussion. Although the outlines mil undoubtedly Z useful to most of the groups, it will he left to each round table to de¬ cide in what way it wishes to discuss the topic under consideration. Chairmen and Secretaries of Round Tables Responsibility for the successful conduct of the type of round tables which haTe been discussed in the foregoing sections falls upon those in charge of the docmentation, those who draft the agenda and discus icn utlines, the participants themsel^s and particularly the ™™*^£ chairmen and secretaries. It is the latter who must see to it that the actuaTdiseussions make the fullest possible use of the information and personnel available, A round table chairman is first of all a manager of discussions and he is selected for qualifications in that direction rather than for e.ther expertness in the subject under consideration or prestige. It is his pri Sy task to facilitate the process of discussion; m so doing he must b«ar Tn mind the criteria cf a successful round table, such as, the vigor of the discussion, widespread participation on the part of members, ^ e*P^a- tion of the matter at hand, close adherence to the subject and £e»f"£* progress towards the resolution of opposing views. In order to fulfill tnis task hTmust not only have considerable familiarity with the sublet undo. discussion, but he must also know the characteristics.f.^.™^*^? round table, and, most particularly, have experience m the technique ot Institute discussions. He is assisted by a Secretary who is seleo*^ for similar qualifica¬ tions. Experience has shown that the task is too difficult for "•£"« and that the efforts of the chairman must be supplemented by a s^etary^ A fast-moving discussion suggests many premising leads all of whichcannot be explored at one session; the documentation is vo I™'*** Stable anf be kept in mind; many points cf view are represented at each round *£ble arm each should be drawn out as fully as possible, an outUne record of the dis cussion must be kept for purposes of summary, It is on matters such as these that the secretary can assist the chairman. It has been previously suggested that contributions to the subject Batter have been made in two ways before the round table takes it up. The documentation furnishes a lowest ccmon denominator of «£™£»«' ^0^1 agenda and its elaboration for specific round tables ia the fom of discus sion outlines points out directions along which the subject^wil 1 m°rt££ ably be developed. Participants in round tables ^e assumed to be familiar with these data and guides; chairmen, however haye the a agonal re spo n sibility of envisaging the potentialities involved m the *™"W°™ oi tn subject so as quickly to recognise and support a promising lead ^ggested by a member. Discussion outlines are merely a suggested framework which on prior thought seems most promising for the elaboration of «• topic, it is not mandatory that they should be followed. »ere a grcup <^eTA^^A^rall these outlines, however, the chairman will have to watch the "^°™ the mere clcseiy in order to ensure the coherent and systematic development of thought.

The quality of general awareness of the possibilities of a topic, n the part of chairmen, called for by the above considerations, is quite different from the quality of expert knowledge of some aspect of the subject matter. Persons with the latter qualification are not likely to be successful discussion leaders; they are too likely to play the role of a teacher who dominates the session rather than that of a chairman^who simply guides its course. A chairman is not expected to exploit his posi-^ tion to intrude his own ideas any more conspicuously than any other parties pant In the discussion. In view of these considerations it is evident that the positions of chairmen and secretaries demand definite qualities not necessarily asso¬ ciated with prestige or nationality. The chairmanship is not given in order to honor an individual or a national group, ^The sole consideration in making these appointments is successful discussion.

essay:div.essay:p: A RESEARCH PROGRAM IN THE PACIFIC AREA I. INTRODUCTION The constitution of the Institute of Pacific Relations defines it las an international body for the study of the conditions of the Pacific jpeoples with a view to the improvement of their mutual relations. Two jother papers issued by the Central Secretariat for the members of the Banff iConference. A Guide to the Banff Discussions and The Purpose and Conduct Jof Round Tables,' have suggested the various means which the Institute lemploys to achieve this aim and have stressed the interrelation of these [means. Conference discussions, researoh, the spreading of information, Und other methods utilized to bring about wide-spread understanding of the laffairs of the area mutually condition each other. Discussion reveals gaps lin the facts known which must be filled by research; research carries study to a point where, in order to bring it into line with actual situations, its [results must be qualified by attitudes, opinions and interpretations brought [out in discussions. The principles upon which the Institute was founded preclude it from reaching corporate decisions or taking corporate action in the field of international politics. To get understanding rather than designate policies, ito diagnose international controversies rather than prescribe immediate remedies, to study rather than preach, - these have been its constant aims. ! Being unofficial, it has had no responsibility towards special interests of any sort, whether governmental or commercial. It has steadfastly sought to eliminate prejudices and presuppositions in its study of public affairs, at the same time recognizing current attitudes as part of a complicated objective situation. The single premise upon which the Institute has con¬ ducted its activities has been that intelligent dealing with the problems ol ^the Pacific area presupposed widespread understanding of the forces at work. It is evident that research must play a conspicuous role in the ful¬ fillment of the Institute's aims. An attempt is made in the foilowing#pages to describe the way in which the Institute promotes research, the policies which guide these efforts, and the scope and emphasis of the research program. Each research project is the outgrowth of a need for accurate information determined by discussions or the educational programs, or previous research, and the entire research program forms an integral, not an isolated part of the Institute's activities. II. POLICIES AND PROBLEMS OF RESEARCH In carrying on research on an international scale the Institute has not been able to rely on the experience of others. Its policies have been shaped in the course of pioneering in a relatively new field. Research methods, once applied almost exclusively to the exact sciences, have in re¬ cent decades been used increasingly in the study of human relations -through the social sciences. For a long time, however, such research was limited to

local, domestic problems in individual countries - a characteristic which stiU prevails. Only under the impetus of the World War and of the acute international crisis since then has increasing attention been directed to- wardrthe international social, economic, and political relations of people. But researoh in international relations, - a point that has been eimhasized by an officer of a large American research organization -ms at first conducted by individual research workers, or ad hoc organizations motivated by the desire to solve an urgent political, economic or moral problem. The results were haphazard and concentrated upon crises^whion called for immediate solutions, thereby emphasizing abnormalities in national conduct. This method neglected the continual accumulation of information on the normal behavior of people and the systematic analysis and Interpretation of data. It neglected, in other words, the well-ordered scheme of study which must underlie any understanding of why people behave as they do when crises arise. The need of systematic research in the relations of the people of the Pacific area was recognized by the Institute in its early Conferences, but a technique for carrying it out was not at hand. tor*a» proles had to be laid down for later modification and development, and these *aro bten the directing policies Wider which an extensive program of investigation has been pursued. Limiting the Institute's Function The function of the Institute of Pacific Relations is essentially that of initiating and correlating the activity of other ^ganisatxons xn the direction of the Institute's aims. From the outset it has declined create an elaborate organization of its own. Applied to ^earoh, ^ policy has restrained the Institute from carrying on tavesti^tions itself and from maintaining a staff for that purpose. There exist in «**"££■» area numerous institutions qualified to undertake research into the problems of the region, there are others which with assistance promise to become qualified. The Institute has endeavored to stimulate and cor »!»*• ***?* of these organisations rather than erect a superstructure of its own which in the end would likely turn out less valuable results. A case in point is the study of land utilization which an early Conference recognized to be basic to problems of population P^-^i and migration. Successful investigation of this sub3ect invol^special information on the social and economic conditions of m «» ntion Sngmge China and Canada or the Philippines and Hew Zealand, not to mention language differences and varieties of dialects within the language groups. Tocreate a centralized research organization capable of undertaking ^tailed^ comprehensive studies into this question would have been •»"«1*£d°g£ siv^ and time-consuming, and it is doubtful whether ^results would^have been satisfactory. There were, moreover, a.number of ^^^A.^ several of the countries concerned in which studies of land utilization were planned or already under way and investigation by a new research body would have caused much duplication.

The Institute adopted the contrary method of using what resources^ 'or researoh were available in each area selected for investigation, limit- ng its own role to that of stimulation, coordination and financial assist¬ ance. In some instanoes, it was necessary only to bring work already under ray into line with a comprehensive scheme covering a larger area and relat- .ng to a wider group of social and economic questions. In others, it was accessary during the early stages of investigation to make provision for gaining a corps of workers to serve in more technical capacities during iater stages. There were a few cases in which the Institute had to seek >ut and persuade appropriate agencies to conduct the necessary studies. Jertain areas, finally, had already been adequately investigated and the Institute's task ms limited to applying their results to the comprehensive Itudy of the Pacific region. Selecting Researoh Agencies In entrusting projects to existing agencies two considerations have ruled; first, that research should be conducted by the best persons and institutions available, but that other things being equal, nationals of the Country in which the study is to be conducted should have priority; and, fsecond, rather than disperse funds widely, that a few research centers i^hould be steadily cultivated over a considerable period of years with a [Mew to developing able research staffs in various parts of the Pacific. Viewed over a long span, a program of research involves not only obtaining data on specified subjects but also in the course of securing that informa¬ tion training a body of investigators who will later be capable of conduct- 'jlng research themselves. It is conceivable that a particular project ifBould be carried out as well or better by foreigners than by nationals. put if the project is turned over to the former, the only lasting result will be the study itself. If the work is done by an institution of the lountry conoerned there will remain after the project is completed not only the report of that investigation but also a group the better prepared for further work. The same reasoning has suggested the wisdom of concentrat- ing the resources of the Institute upon a few institutions on the supposition that assisting these for several consecutive years would result in more permanent benefits than aiding more organizations for shorter periods. This policy has pertained particularly to a country such as China here social and political disturbances have placed well-nigh unsurmountable obstacles in the way of objective study. When the Institute initiated its program of research seven years ago there were, despite these handicaps, a few centers in that country which with the assurance of continued support Promised to develop strong research organizations. The Institute, conse¬ quently, set about strengthening these centers by entrusting to them long- term projects in land utilization, industrialization and migrations. The outcome has been, in addition to excellent reports on these subjects, the Establishment of well-equipped and well-staffed institutions capable of Carrying out a continuing program of research. In the pursuit of this policy of concentration on a few institutions certain disadvantages have become increasingly apparent. By strengthening a few centers, others have been neglected, and, to continue with the example of China, data and problems of the areas of the institutions selected have Wn studied to the partial exclusion of other regions. With the exception

nf a brief investigation into the problems of the southward migration of bhe Chinese, the Institute has made no contacts with universities in south China. This criticism applies also to the western interior of^ China. This has resulted in part from the apparent absence of promising research organizations in the social sciences in those areas and partly from the aforementioned policy of concentrating the Institute's ^ited resources. A counter tendency is at present in evidence among those charged with the supervision of the Institute's research program. It may be anticipated that the policy of concentration will be somewhat relaxed in an effort to cover a wider area and to stimulate research in a larger jnumber of organizations. Cooperative Research It has been suggested in the first paragraphs of this^ section that the Institute had in large measure to de^lop a technique of international research, there being few precedents to follow. One of the P^wPft3; f^" ficulties has been to work out methods whereby analagous Pf0^^0^^,^^ investigated simultaneously in the many diverse environments of the Pacific area, and comparable data secured from each. The technique of research in the international field which the ; Institute is developing is illustrated by the procedure adopted in studying the question of aliens. The need for research into the Pf*}^ ^^^^ out in round table discussions of extraterritorial jurisdiction in China. It Is soon recognized that considering the subject as unique to China threw it 21 o? proportion and eliminated the valuable possibility of bringing the experience and practice of other countries to bear on it. It ^S also realized that the problem of aliens was held in common by all the countries of the Pacifio and that only in its particular manifestations was it peculiar to any one. In consequence, each National Council of the Institute was requested to prepare a paper on the status of aliens ^ first limited to the legal aspects of the question) in its area. ™£ papers were completed in the intervening biennium before the next Conference, and during the latter they were reviewed by a subcommittee of specialists. An optimum standard was established by this group and preseatod to the authors of the papers with the request that they revise their papers accord¬ ingly. At the same time an authority was asked to undertake the co- orlination of these separate studies and the direction of the requestedr£ visions. In the latter task assistance was given by the Central Secretariat. The coordinating study, it is expected, will shortly ** *^e* *f *f fQ^ & close the legal phase of the status of aliens study. It may then be found that further studies in regard to the social and economic status of ^™ will be needed for a full understanding of the problems involved and in that case further cooperative investigations will be called for to be followed by another coordinating study. The procedure is not always so clearcut as the above description implies. In studying the tariff problems on the Pacific area, the Institute has had to proceed more slowly. It was found ^possible to se¬ cure comparable data from a series of decentralized studies, f°r ™ schedule of investigation could be drawn up which would produce correlated results. The Institute has consequently at the same time organized separate surveys of national tariffs and their effect on trade and a

^centralized study of the trade and tariffs of the whole area designed especially to set up criteria by which tariffs could be subsequently mea¬ sured in each country. Further steps in investigating this problem will depend upon the results of these studies now under way. Research and International Politics Study of the sort of human problems with which the Institute is con¬ cerned has created further problems in conducting research. Although the organization does'not'concern itself with bringing about immediate political results, it, nevertheless, keeps an eye on the practical world of current events. At Conferences, the discussions center on the phenomena ^underlying current, political manifestations, and they seek to throw light on the causes rather than on remedial details. The areas of these discus¬ sions, however, is close enough to subjective thought and activity and to matters which must meet at least a long-term pragmatic test to create dif¬ ficulties for scientific research. A task of research in the Institute is [bo study moot points which have arisen in previous discussions and to docu¬ ment succeeding Conferences. There is thus imposed upon the research program L connection with practical affairs with which researoh, as such, is tradi¬ tionally unaccustomed. It is not necessarily true, however, that the nearer research ap¬ proaches current events, that is, the more it is designed to effect change, the less it is scientific. The work of the entomologist is often determined Jby the immediate aim of improving crop yield, yet his investigations do not thereby become less objective. On the contrary, to the extent that he has allowed ulterior considerations to influence his studies his results lack usefulness to the agriculturist. In the social sciences the problem^is more complicatedi the study of human relations is not yet to be classed with the exact sciences. In the investigation of society it is altogether more dif¬ ficult to eliminate presuppositions. For this reason the research program of the Institute runs into danger in holding close to the area of practical affairs© The Institute cannot claim to have evolved a complete formula out of f'this difficulty. Certain of the policies described above, however, tend to |ensure scientific work. Decentralized investigations, at worst, would re¬ peal many opposing prejudices which in the process of coordination would be largely cancelled out. The constant testing of researches in Conference discussions provide a further check. The problem, moreover, is forced to (the point of the ridiculous when it is regarded at its worst, for, naturally, this contingency is eliminated by the selection of qualified research workers and institutions. The problem, nevertheless, remains and was summarized by the Jlnstitutets then research secretary for the Conference of Representatives of ^Institutions for the Scientific Study of International Relations in Paris, 11930, in the following words: "In the effort to combine thoroughness in research with practical needs., to deal adequately with fundamental systematic problems of description and analysis and yet provide the information necessary for discussion of immediate and changing issues, and to

maintain scholarly standards without ignoring those regions of social life for which established and quantitative research methods are not yet worked out and perhaps never can be worked out, the Institute as yet has made only very tentative and partial experiments» The humanizing of knowledge is a difficult process. It would be comparatively easy to initiate and administer a research program which would satisfy the social scientists of the Pacific. It is a much more difficult matter to find one which will satisfy both them and those who are interested rather in practical solutions of immediate problems of grave urgency. It is an open question whether the Institute of Pacific Relations will be able to hold the two points of view together long enough for a solution to be worked out." Since the above comment was made the Institute has partly eliminated the problem by drawing a sharper distinction between research projects and Conference data papers. The latter are for the most part not research, but either summaries of research already completed or surveys of data elsewhere available. Data papers are short statements of fact designed for the specific purpose of documenting the discussion of certain topics. Some of the projects oontained in the research program furnish material for data papers or even the papers themselves, others provide information for a future Conference. The research program is only partially determined by the agenda of the next Conference, but being directed towards international relations of the Pacific it inevitably contributes some data to each Conference. The distinction, nevertheless, remains clear that data papers are prepared specifically for Conference purposes and they may or may not involve research, whereas the research program has no immediate objective other than adding to the general body of information, Seleotion of Projects There remains for consideration the Institute's policy of selecting topics for research. These were determined early in the Institute's history by Conference discussions. In order to discover what facilities and investi¬ gators were available the secretary of the International Research Committee undertook a general tour of the Pacific area during the course of which and in consultation with established research centers he made additional recom¬ mendations. The suggestions made by the round tables had to be modified by the available facilities for research in the Pacific, and these together with the recommendations of the secretary were subjected to further scrutiny by experts called upon to advise the organization to which the Institute applied for funds. This way of inaugurating research was not conducive to a logical and systematic program. Even had it been possible to draw up such a program, which is doubtful, there would have been no way to carry it out. For these reasons the Institute's researches might be expected to have been unrelated and scattered. It is surprising to find, as the next section will indicate, that this was not entirely true and that the program revealed a fairly systematic grouping of projects around a few fundamental problems. In every case subjects were chosen for investigation which lay beneath the surface of events, in many questions the groundwork had even to be laid in regions apparently only remotely conneoted with practical affairs. This is perhaps an explanation of the degree to which in retrospect a correlated program is found to have been initiated, for the further investiga¬ tion pushes behind the everyday behavior of people the greater is the common

denominator of causation. Only in surface events does there appear to be universal disparity. The subsequent development of the research program grew out of later Conferences and out of the findings of earlier projects. As soon as discussion and research began mutually to support each other, a more systematic method of study became evident in both. Gradually, moreover, the Institute gained insight into the affairs of the Pacific area and with this came the ability to maintain a more coordinated scheme of investigation. In the minds of several of those in charge of the Institute's re¬ search the point has now been reached when further studies can be mapped out according to a general plan to which each project will have a definite relation. It is for this reason that the International Research Committee has announced its intention during the Banff Conference to keep itself free from administrative details in order to devote its time to a thorough survey of research in the Pacific with a view to establishing a systematic scheme for further studies. Valuable precedents for the planning of research have been furnished it by the Social Science Research Council. III. RESEARCH ADMINISTRATION The Institute's research activities are carried on by research com¬ mittees under each of its national units and by an International Research Committee composed of a representative from each of the local committees. The executive work of the international committee is attended to by a research secretary attached to the Central Secretariat. The International Research Committee, constitutionally, is advisory to the Pacific Council, the governing body of the Institute, and it merely makes recommendations to the Pacific Council which has the power to amend or veto. In fact, how¬ ever, the Pacific Council has traditionally accepted the recommendations of the International Research Committee without change. The Research Committees of the various National Councils are respon¬ sible for the initiation and approval of all research projects to be carried out within their territory. The projects may arise from suggestions by individual research workers, by applications for assistance from such bodies as universities or educational associations, or by the direct invitation of the Research Committee to such bodies or individuals. In every case the local Researoh Committee lias full initiative and power. It may recommend to its Council that projects be amended, dropped, or proceeded with in differ¬ ent ways. It may utilize funds available in its own country, request other research bodies to conduct investigations, or to recommend its Council to make grants. Every National Council has dealt with some part of its researoh program in these waysj but most Councils have asked for financial help for projects beyond their own resources. Such projects are sent on with the endorsement of the National Councils upon the recommendation of their Research Committees. The financial resources of the International Research Committee are obtained from an American Foundation on a yearly basis. Part of the grant is given the Committee outright, the remainder on condition

that two dollars for every one be raised from other sources for expenditure on the same projects. Beginning in 1934 the condition will be raised to a three-to-one basis. The International Research Committee, therefore, in making grants, imposes the condition that the recipient raise for the same purposes a similar amount from other sources. The more difficult requirements which will become effective in 1934 will be passed on to the recipients of grants. The effect of this condition is to enable the Institute to carry on a more extensive program than its resources would otherwise permit and also to encourage the maintenance of research centers by local funds. When projects have been recommended by the International Research Committee and approved by the Pacific Council, responsibility for their execution and for the expenditure of whatever funds are granted is put in the hands of a trustee institution, which may be one of the Institute's National Councils, or a university or other research body. The development of the project is closely watched by the secretary of the Committee, fre¬ quent progress reports and financial accountings being called for. The Institute has adhered as closely as possible to the policy of not making the administration of research a charge on its research funds. In so far as possible this fund is devoted exclusively to the research work itself, expenses incident to administration being met from the general funds at the disposal of the Central Secretariat. This policy, it has been felt, is consistent with the aim of limiting the Institute's functions to those of administration and coordination of work carried on by others. The distinction which is made between research and the preparation of data papers has been discussed in a preceding section. It was pointed out that data papers, for the most part, do not involve research but only the application of the results of research for Conference uses. The pre¬ paration of data papers, nevertheless, falls under the purview of research administration. Most of the initiative for these papers as well as the task of putting them through the press and distributing them is taken care of by the various National Research Committees, The International Committee, however, is responsible for obtaining from each area comparable data and for determining methods for publication and distribution which will be co¬ ordinated and efficient. IV. CURRENT AND PUBLISHED PROJECTS AND PAPERS It is premature to give a complete account of the subjects which have been studied in the Institute's program of research. Only a beginning has been made in dissecting and analyzing the phenomena underlying the rela¬ tions of the peoples of the Pacific area. Certain topics have been carried farther than others, the investigation of some has been postponed either for want of research vacilities or funds or until discussion and thought can more sharply define the problem. A complete account moreover, will more appro¬ priately be contained in histories, commentaries and surveys of the area yet to be written which will utilize - as Mr. Tawney has done in Land and Labour in China - all of the information made available by the Institute as well as by other agencies.

A topical discussion of the Institute's research program, moreover, would have to take into account a considerable number of studies in whioh the organization played a very inconspicuous part. In accordance with its policy of stimulating work through other institutions, much of what lies within its broad program has no apparent connection with it. At the other extreme are the studies which the Institute has published under its own imprint. Between the two is an indefinite fringe of studies and papers to¬ wards which the Institute made a greater or lesser contribution. The present attempt to describe the subjects in which the Institute has carried on researoh, therefore, is limited to listing the titles of pro¬ jects now under way and of those on which published reports have been made. Current Projects There are listed below the projects which are currently being carried on by the institutions designated and with funds granted by the International Research Committee. It is not possible at the time this report is written to give an accurate list of the papers on which the various National Councils are at work for the Banff Conference, In order to make this account of current projects comparable with the long list of published works, data papers for the forthcoming Conference should be included, "but inasmuch as full informa¬ tion is not available as to titles and authors, it is suggested that the authorized list of data papers which will be issued to each member at the Conference be appended to this report. 1, "Dependencies and Native Peoples of the Pacific": a cooperative inter¬ national study directed by Mr, F.
