essay:div.essay:p: CONFLICT AND CONTROL IN THE PACIFIC By W. L. HOLLAND INSTITUTE OF PACIFIC RELATIONS

CONFLICT AND CONTROL IN THE PACIFIC By W. L. HOLLAND A STATEMENT OF THE FRAMEWORK AND DEVELOPMENT OF THE BANFF CONFERENCE DISCUSSIONS Given at the opening meeting of the Conference Banff, August 14,1933. Institute of Pacific Relations Honolulu—1933

THE FRAMEWORK AND DEVELOPMENT OF THE BANFF DISCUSSION IN AN organization which has so little use for long public statements as the Institute of Pacific Relations, there is possibly some need to give reasons for the one I am about to make. Rightly or wrongly, it has been said that it is necessary to have as a starting-point an outline of the conditions responsible for the Banff Conference discussions, which will put the different 'Round-Table' questions into some sort of relation with the papers which have been sent to all the representatives. An attempt has been made to get most of these papers into the hands of the represen¬ tatives long enough before the start of the Conference to make it possible for them to have gone through most, if not all of them. I will, then, take it as certain that you have at least had a look at most of the papers, to which attention will later be given. In earlier meetings of the Institute, this sort of general statement has been less necessary and so has not been made. The reason for thi® was that most of the representatives at these meetings had a more or less clear idea of what was covered by the questions put down for discussion. It is true that these questions were not any of them simple; in fact most of them were very complex, and had their roots deep down in other questions which seemed completely outside the field of discussion. But though they were complex, all of them were of current interest, and all the representatives were conscious of the clear and important connection they had with the cheif international events of the time. How is it, then, that the present field of discussion is different from that of other conferences? It seems that the best answer may be given by reading part of the little book which Dr. Hu Shih and myself got out early in 1932. The statement is there made that in making plans for t'he 1933 meeting the Program Committee was giving an outlet to the opinions put forward by the general conference representatives! in the 'Round-Tables' which took place at the end of the China Conference. The feeling among a number of representatives in these discussions was that the time had come for the Institute to give more attention to those deeper questions which were internationally important and common to all ths chief countries of the Pacific, in place of giving most of its' time, asi it had done in the Third and Fourth Conferences, to questions in connection with one country or one special part of a country. The point of this decision was not so much that the Institute had any idea of giving up

its earlier system of having discussions' about the chief political questions of the time, but that a clearer statement was needed of the relations between these political questions and those slow-moving and frequently unseen forces in society and economic organization which are their causes. In this way, in the opinion of the Program Committee, the 1933 Conference would be able to make it clear that any one burning political question—such as the position of Shanghai, or the trouble in Manchuria— was in fact only one (though an important one) of a number of other questions of the same sort in other parts of the Pacific. It was hoped, in addition, that the new angle of attack would make it possible for countriesi other than China and Japan to give to the 'Round-Table' discussions much more of their experience than had been possible at past Conferences. So that you will not, any of you, get the feeling that the decisions about these discussions have been made without your knowledge and are now suddenly put before you at this late stage, let me quickly give you a rough outline of the steps in the working out of the plans which are responsible for this opening meeting. Most of you are conscious of the fact that the Banff Conference was started at the end of the Shanghai Conference. When the International Program Committee had come to a decision to take up the general question of 'Conflict (a) and Control', a letter was sent to all representatives who had been at the Conference and to all National Councils, giving a rough outline of the questions which in the opinion of the International Office would most probably come up for discussion. Two months later came a small book of forty pages put out by Dr. Hu Shih and myself, which was sent to all the National Councils. In this we made an attempt to give some sort of picture of the wider international economic, political, and more general interests which have to do with the coming discussions. At the same time we gave examples of possible questions and of suggestions for reading in the eighteen months before this meeting. Between then and last March the International Office was able to get the opinions of a great number of the Institute's supporters by letter, and in the light of these it was able to make the range of some parts of the first outline narrower, and to put some of the questions in a better form. After this there was a meeting at New York in September 1932, at which there were representatives! of five or six National Councils. After two or three days' discussion the group was able to come to an agreement as to the three chief fields of interest which have been put down in today's discussion outline. The general plan made by this group is the one which was later sent to all National Councils in the form of a short paper; and the greater part of it was printed again in the paper named 'A Guide to the Banff Discussions", which was sent out in May by the Honolulu office. Using this outline as a guide, the International office, in the middle of last July, made a list of the special questions which it seemed wise to put before the 'Round-Table'. These have been used in the week before the opening of the Conference by the International Program Committee in its meetings, and from them have come the lists of questions for discussion which will be given to you every, morning at

the Round-Tables. It is, then, unnecessary for me to give you any details of ttiis' outline; it is enough for me to say that the first heading "Economic Conflict in the Pacfic Area: Its Control and Adjustment" will give material for the greater part of the Banff discussions. It seems probable that the second heading about questions of educa¬ tion will be looked at more from a general point of view than in detail; and that these discussions will be taken chiefly as first steps in the direction of the 1935 Conference which will probably give more time to educational questions than to any other field. THE WARRING FORCES IN THE PACIFIC After these observations, let me now go on to the harder business of giving some account of the conditions at the back of the economic and political troubles about to come under discussion. There are a number of ways of attacking these questions and I have no desire to give you the idea that the angle from which 1 am looking at them is better than others. But it is simplest for me to see the warring forces all over the Pacific, in economic and political fields, and equally in the field of education, as caused by the fact that there is not a good adjustment between geograph¬ ical limits and the economic needs of the nations in question. The anthropologist may give a deeper account of it in relation to changes in ways of living; the political expert may give greater weight to the political signs of these warring tendencies; but my training has been in economics and you will have to let me make the attack from the angle which is most natural to me. Agi I see it, then, these bad adjustments are like a number of unequal forces acting on the different countries. The first of these is the unequal distribution of natural produce: that is to say, of food, of good farm land, or of materials for industry. This is common knowledge and it is unnecessary to say more about it. Japan, for example, is without enough coal (f) and iron (f) if she is looking forward to the development of her industries in years to come; Canada is dependent on other countries for cotton (f) and silk (f). Second, there are the effects of an unequal distribution of population. This is, in part, the effect of the first conditions: which I have been talking about, and in part the effect of conscious economic development. Then comes the fact that conditions of living are unequal; that is to say, not only is living cheaper in some countries than in others, but the deeper values themselves are different in different societies, so that ideas of material well-being are unlike. Fourth, there is the unequal distribution of political power in the Pacific. Some countries are politically dependent while, at the other end of the scale, others are great Powers. Because of these different levels of political power (some would say because of unequal military and sea-power) some countries' are more able to take care of their economic interests than others. And last, countries are put in unequal positions through the operation of time: in the sense that by chance or by design some countries have got a better position through having been first in the field of trade or in the development of industry; and looking at the other

side of the picture, countries now starting their economic development make the discovery that they are kept back and walled-in by competition with countries which have been longer in the field. What is even more serious, they frequently see that they are shut out from certain parts of the great markets because these have been made the private property of the first comers. Quite clearly, one side of this question is the way in which some of the most important colonies of the earth, such as Indo-China, Formosa, or parts of Africa, are walled off for the special use of the mother-country. Now for a long time these unequal forces inside the different countries were able to go on side by side simply because there had been little development of the connections between the different parts of the Pacific. It was as if there were a number of vessels full of different gases in different conditions of expansion and with different chemical properties, side by side but kept seperate from one another. But now, with the development of physical transport through railways, roads, and steamships, and the development of apparatus for the transport of ideas such as over-sea telegrams and radio, which are seen less but have even greater effects, it is as if the different vessels had been joined together by pipes. Some of the pipes are wide, so that the different forces quickly become equal. Others are small or are stopped up in some way, so that it takes a long time for a complete adjustment. But generally it is true to say that there is a tendency in the direction of some sort of levelling, and in so far as the gases were said to have different chemical properties, there is a tendency for reactions to take place between them, which may be more or less violent, and in which much heat may be produced. The joining together of the different parts of the Pacific was not a process taking place by itself. The very opposite is true: it was part of a great expansion of political, economic, and other forces from the west of Europe and North America. This is in fact the process to which we have given the name of "expansionism" in the outline of the present dis^ cussions. But for one or two details, we might say that it is almost the same as that process to which the supporter of Marx gives the name of "imperialism." It is a process which was possibly at its highest develop¬ ment between 1890 and 1900. The clearest and most surprising sign of it was the competition among the Great Powers of the West to be first in marking off for themselves great stretches of land in countries at a lower stage of development, or in getting important economic rights in 'countries which were not so strong, such as China, Persia, and South America. One example of it was the division of Africa, another was the Violent competition between England, Germany, and Russia to get special rights in China, while another was the way in which Japan got control of important colonies by taking Formosa and Korea. Sometimes it was a cause of open war: for example, between Spain and the United States or Russia and Japan; at other times no fight was put up against the process. Frequently the rewards were great, and there is no doubt that much of the driving-force in this expansion came from the desire to get

materials for industry, and specially the produce of colonies. Frequently, however, later history has made it seem very probable that the reward was not great enough for the trouble, and it is possible to give examples of competition for power which now seem surprisingly foolish. There was a time in the 1880's when the harbour at Apia in Samoa had in it the warships of four or five great Powers, all making attempts to get the support of the island chiefs. It is true that there were great economic tendencies at the back of this expansion of the Powers cf the West; but it isi important to keep in mind that there were in addition great political and other forces. In fact, it is probable that this expansion is best seen as a surprisingly complex knot of purposes, in which the hope of profit was mixed up with ideas of giving law and order to such countries' as the Philippines and China, and with the less self-interested desire to give the Christianity and education of the West to persons who seemed in the opinion of Europe to be living at a much lower level. And these mixed purposes are very far from being a thing of the past. Unhappily, one sees a number of signs of them in the political events of today. So that this "expansionism" was not simply an outburst of economic forces or the effect of a desire to get new materials for industry and control of new markets; it was equally an outgoing current of political ideas and ways of living. From another point of view it may be of use to see the complete process as one of motion. In some places populations themselves moved in an attempt to get away from the hard living-conditions in the countries of the West, where the development of industry came earlier. It was, in fact because they gave such outlets that certain forms of expansion through colonies were supported. In other places there was an outgoing current of money for investment and with it some of the ideas, inven¬ tions, and forms of organization which had come into being with the growth of industry in the West. Almost everywhere it took the form of trade witn other countries. This; is only another name for the distribution of goods and services. After a certain stage of development in the indus¬ tries of one country, these goods were produced in ever-increasing amounts which made new outlets into other countries necessary; and, on the other side, when these outlets: had been made, it was necessary to get control of new places overseas where the materials for industry were produced. Together with all this there was a current of ideas, some of which took root in the countries at a lower stage of economic development, and have later been used for ttie organization of those countries on the lines! of the West. Some were ideas about the quai rights of man which have taken root in new places and are producing strange fruit. Others were ideas about conditions of material well-being and the right to be free, which are causing great changes in the older forms of society still in existence in a number of Pacific countries. The outcome of all this is that today almost every part of the Pacific has been changed by outside economic and political control and new ideas of education. In almost all these places there are parts of the population

which come from other nations; almost everywhere business is supported by investments from other countries, or money has been sent out to other countri€s for business purposes: the lands which are not politically dependent on some oversea power are responsible for the government of some colony or dependent country. What is more, almost no land has gone through these processes without some sort of trouble. It is in this question that the Banff Conference will probably be chiefly interested. The trouble may or may not have taken serious political forms, though frequently it has done so. Sometimes the chief sign of it has been the existence of a generally unbalanced condition of the public mind, so that unimportant or chance events such as the putting to death of a military man or the punishment of a chief (for example, in a colony) have in a very short time been increased to the size of serious international troubles. To those outside the country this condition may possibly be seen as a wave of public feeling as if a serious attack was being made on the inter¬ national position of the country; while looked at from the inside it may seem to be simply an outlet for a nation's feelings, sometimes right and sometimes wrong, against an increasingly great weight of economic and other forces. Most of those who have given attention to the forces at the back of the changes in the government of Germany In the past year, or to the political conditions within Japan (1) which were responsible for the fight¬ ing in Manchuria, will be ready to give full value to these psychological developments which have frequently been given little attention. Whatever form the outburst may take, it is important to keep in mind the fact that its deeper causes may be a long way from the special point about which argument is taking place. It is in part for this reason that this Confer¬ ence is not simply giving its attention to two or three of the chief inter¬ national questions in the Pacific. Its experience in past conferences has made it clear that numbers of these international ills have their roots deep down in questions which are very different from those which are at present causing trouble — questions which are frequently not international in any sense, but have to do only with conditions inside the country. In such questions—and the discussions at our 'Round-Tables' will almost certainly put numbers of them before us—it is clearly a waste of time for discus¬ sion and suggestions to be limited to the international side only; that is to say, we will not go very far if we make a decision to keep out of the discussion all questions which are generally taken to be the private business of one country, with the old story that international discussion of them would be an attack on the rights of nations. Because of this belief that for a full knowledge of all the different forms which these warring tendencies may take in the international field it is necessary to give the fullest possible attention to the different forces at the back of them, the Institute has made a request to the National Councils to give space in their Conference papers to getting at the ways (1) See "Behind the Par Eastern Conflict," American Council Institute of Pacific Relations, p.p 14-20. i

in which the different group interests in a country may make use of their power over the government. In addition there has been a request for accounts of the ways in which these special interests—(Chambers of Commerce, organizations of business men, workers, producers etc.) — have become united for their common profit, or have been forced to come into an organization in the interests of public well-being. This observation may do something to make it clear to representatives at this Conference why an international group (such as this) is giving attention to such seemingly private questions as rice-control (f) in Japan or the organiza¬ tion of the sugar (f) industry in Hawaii, or the work of the National In¬ dustrial Recovery Board in the United States. The reason is that a number of the attemptsi at control inside a nation are faced with the same sort of troubles, on a smaller scale, as those which have to be overcome if attempts at international control are to be made. You will see a number cf examples of this point in the discussion-material (1): to give one only, it was not till special laws had been made in the United States giving traders the right to come together in an organization, that it was possible for the International or "World Copper Cartel" to be formed. There are some here who are able to give a picture of the trouble of getting Lancashire cotton (f) producers into the sort of working organi¬ zation which by common agreement is necessary for the development of a market for British goods in China. In the same way we have the example of the Stevenson system of rubber (f) control, which came to nothing because the Dutch government was unable in the end to keep control of the amount of rubber produced by the islanders in the Dutch East Indies. (2) There is another reason for giving attention to the trroup interests in different countries. Troubles of the sort which come to mind when we are talking about warring tendencies in international economic develop¬ ment are generally seen to be between groups and not between private persons. The private person only comes into the picture when his posi¬ tion is one of great power, so that he is more like a group than a private producer. This seems to me to be a good suggestion for testing how far, in the questions under discussion, there is truly a condition of economic v/ar and not simply one of normal competition. When any trouble has at the back of it some sort of group organization, then we have good reason for the belief that such a condition of economic war is present. This statement, naturally, is not complete without another, which I will give later. Possibly the best way to make my point clear is to take some of the examples of warring forces given in the discussion-material. Violent competition between producers within a country or even on an interna¬ tional scale is no new thing, and in a general way it is probably true to (1) See American paper "Introduction," p. 5. (2) See British paper "Raw Materials in the Far East and Pacific Dependencies," p. 17.

say that it is not a cause of serious trouble, because any one business in competition with others is only one small part of the complete organiza¬ tion. But when these units are joined into groups such as shipping conferences or producers' organizations, or even into great separate units like important oil (f) companies, then competition may well be given the name of war. Clearly, one reason for this is that a united group has a much greater chance of having some effect on its government, and of getting support for what it is doing. That takes me to the second rough test. It is that when the interests of a given group have got control of the political machine then there is1 good reason for a belief that the outcome of competition will frequently be economic war. One seemingly unimportant argument about trade com¬ petition under these conditions will then take on a political color and may be the cause of a protest from government representatives. The processes of business competition in this way become something like a test of power between two governments. Examples of this are common enough and will frequently come to your attention in the conference. Competition between the shipping companies of different countries has been sharp at all times; but it becomes a question for government protest and bitter argument when it is seen that competition has some connection with government support. The commonest examples of this are loans of government money to shipping businesses. This, and the other and more roundabout forms of support given by the Japanese Government to shipowners and pro¬ ducers is one of the chief causes of protest against the serious Japanese fcompetition which is giving so much trouble to English, Indian and American producers today. Those who have been against having normal relations with the government of Soviet Russia or making trade agree¬ ments with that country have made it a chief point of attack that Soviet overseas trade (because it is completely in the hands of the Government) may be, and has been, made use of politically. A good example of the complex international troubles which come from this sort of thing may be seen very near us in the way in which the wheat (f) and lumber (f) interests of Canada were able to get the governments of Canada and England to put an end to the Trade Agreement between England and Russia. This uniting of business with political designs is* at the back of al¬ most all the international troubles about tariffs (b) and has given numbers of examples of the sort of economic war I am attempting to give an account of; first, in the changes in U.S. tariffs in 1930, second in the agreements giving special rights to British countries at the Ottawa Con¬ ference, and third, in the attack on Japanese trade in the new Indian tariff. You will see in the outline of the discussions that this uniting of political powers with business interests has been put forward as a possible way of grouping the different sorts of warring forces. In this way the sort of trouble which takes place in competition in private business is put right by private agreements and would come into one group, while those which have connections with government and in which political

agreement is necessary would come in another; while a third group would be made up of troubles which go even deeper, needing special apparatus such as an international conference or an international committee of judges; and last there are the troubles on an international scale which are only ended by the use of force—as in boycotts and so on. FORMS OF CONTROL That is enough for the first heading. The Conference will not have much trouble in putting forward examples; but from the start it is neces^ sary to say quite clearly that doing this will have little effect if repre¬ sentatives are not ready to give serious thought to the question of working out possible forms of control. When I say this, I am naturally taking the view that some sort of control is needed. There may be some who are not of this opinion and are ready to say that these warring forces are simply the natural outcome of necessary business competition, and that it is an error or even impossible to do anything in the hope of getting them under control. However, one has to have some point of view and so for the purposes of this paper I am taking it as certain that we are able to keep these forms of economic war under control, and that there is a need for us to do so. One reason for this view is that we have at all times had some sort of control, in one way or another. At all times governments have made certain rules in connection with business opera¬ tions, and have frequently made a complete change in the business organization of a country by such things as tariff (b) laws and laws about working conditions and living conditions!. It is improbable that there has ever been a complete system of laissez-faire, (c) It is common knowledge that the Pacific is full of examplesi of control systems. If we take a look around the countries which have representatives here, we may well be surprised at the number of different forms of economic control which have been put into effect by the different governments. There is everything from the early attempts of the Jap¬ anese government to give its support to its industry and trade (1), to its complete control over the tobacco (f) and camphor (f) industries and the still wider government control of overseas trade in Soviet Russia. We may put among these examples the attempts made from time to time in New Zealand and some parts of Australia at government control of business. These were on a small scale and were not part of a general economic plan, but designed to meet the needs of the times. With these may be grouped the different forms of control over certain goods like the unhappy Stevenson system of rubber-control, the operations of the grain marketing combine in Canada, the system of rice (f) control in Japan, the support given by the government of Australia to producers of sugar (f) and butter (f), and the New Zealand (2) control over fruit, butter and (1) See Moulton, "Japan," Brooking's Institution, Washington, 1931. Ch. 17. (2) No. 2. Paper. Export Control Boards.

honey (f) produced for sale overseas. Even more important are the plans for wider economic control of the chief industries now being worked out by the American Government under the National Industrial Recovery Act. But all these are only representative of the more consciously planned forms of gcvernment control. At the back of them are the other forms of less planned control over economic operations, such as we see in tariffs, shipping laws, the control of immigration (d), the rules for keeping down the danger of disease from outside countries, laws con¬ trolling the quality of food, etc. These roundabout ways of control may be most important. They have frequently been the cause of greater international ill-feeling than the more open forms of government control. Such things as the parts of Canadian tariff law (1) which make it possible to put any fixed exchange rate on the money of other countries are instruments of economic war which may frequently be the cause of serious outbursts of ill-feeling. Special committes of the League of Nations have had to give attention to a great number of such causes of international trouble. Under the cover of rules to keep disease out of a country it has frequently been possible for governments almost to put a stop to some parts of the trade of another country, in the same way as the very elastic rules for the control of immigration into Australia make it possible to keep anyone out by making him undergo a writing test in any language. In the same way, when one country in Europe, say Denmark, has a desire to keep out cows from Switzerland, it does not make a law against letting Swiss cows into the country, but makes a complex ruling to the effect that no cows which are kept at a higher level than 5,000 feet for more than three months of the year may be taken into Denmark. In working out systems of control there is much to be done in the discovery of how to put a stop to these small and foolish rules which get in the way of international trade. When we come to the wider field of international economic control we again see that the Pacific gives examples of a great number of differ¬ ent system of control at present in existence. A short time back I said something about the system of rubber control attempted by the British government, which came to nothing. Another example of this sort is tlie system for the control of the output of tin (f), which is under the direction of a special international committee, and which has had better effects than the Stevenson plan. The details of its working are given in tbe British paper on "Raw Materials in the Pacific" (2). Less happy, it may be, but very important, are the shipping conferences which keep control of the rates for transport across the Pacific (3). Turning to those (1) Canadian Paper, 1933, p.p 28-29. (2) p.p. 21-27. (3) American paper "Regulation and Promotion of Pacific, Shipping," p.p. 21-36.

plans for which the agreement and support of governments is necessary, we come face to face with the Ottawa (1) agreements of last year Though from the accounts we have at present it does not seem very probable that the effects of these agreements on Pacific trade will be very great, it is important to keep in mind that the Imperial Economic Conference is one form of international control which may quite possibly have serious effects on the natural currents of trade in the Pacific, and that though it is on a much greater scale than the organization of group interests inside one country, it may have within it the same seeds of trouble, be¬ cause its chief purpose is not the well-being of all the Pacific countries but only a part of them. Possibly there is a parallel to the effects of Ottawa in the attempts of Japan to make a separate economic unit by a form of special control over the government of Manchuria (2). And if we give attention to this sort of system, we have, in addition, to take into account the other plan of international control which was put forward for Manchuria by the Lytton Commission, even though this seems to be farther away from current political ideas. We may go even farther and see what are the possible chances of forming special international com¬ mittees for the control of certain fields of international economic opera¬ tions. Of these, possibly the best example is Sir Arthur Salter's sugges¬ tion, which he put forward at the London Conference on The State and Economic Life and at other times (1), for a fixed committee which would have control of overseas investment, and in addition, his plan for a legular international trade committee, not for controlling trade, but for making rules for the better working of, and competition in, international trade. Coming nearer to the Pacific, we have, in one of the papers given out at this Conference, Mr. Lorwin's design for a Pacific development committee which would have the same purpose. You will see that it is only possible to give serious attention to plans such as these on an international scale if we come to the question with a good knowledge of the working of the same sort of control systems in the different countries. No argument is necessary to make it clear that the experience of, for example, the American Department of Com¬ merce or the British Empire Marketing Board, may be of great use in helping to get a good machine for international control. In the same way, the ill-feeling which was caused by the fact that the British Gov¬ ernment did not take into account the interests of the American rubber industrie si when it was working out its system of control in Malaya makes one see the dangers to keep away from in future attempts at limiting output or controlling markets. Before I come to the end of this part of my statement, may I put before you one important point about the present system of control. The (1) British paper "Economic Consequences of Ottawa in the Pacific Dominions." (2) British paper "Economic Consequences of Recent Events in Manchuria." (3) See "Recovery," Bell, London, 1932, p.p 292-294.

point is that most of them have been designed only in relation to the needs of the time, or in the interests of some special group in one country. In the same way, a number of other systems of control have come to birth only in bad times, and business groups have been united by such conditions as a great fall of prices or a loss of markets. Clearly there is great danger in having overmuch hope in the future of such systems of control. The trouble of shutting out outside competition in any plan for limiting output or controling prices even in one country is common knowledge. The dangers of the system are far greater when those who take part come from different nations!. Again, we might take the different wartime controls as examples of what might be done. But here again it is important to keep in mind that these controls were designed for pur¬ poses very different from those we have now. And last, I might say— though it is quite unnecessary for one to go into details in this company— that to make a chance selection from among the different and independent systems with little relation between them, would be a very different thing from working out a well-made system for international control. From what I have said it seems probable that you will see that the most important part of our discussions will have to do with control. If that is so, then it seems! to me that it is not possible to do much without having a clear idea of the ends, at least in our minds, for which this control is to be used. Possbily one such end may be enough: possibly more will be needed. But in my opinion it is necessary for usi to have some sort of purpose cearly before us in our discussionsi of control. The end in view may be to give all countries equal trading right: or the idea of a society in which all men are equal: or that of the greatest possible self-development of men and women. It is not necessary for this end to be fixed from the start, so that it may not be changed. Discussions started in that way do not generally get past the first argument which comes up. It is for this reason that the Program Committee has made a lequest to the round-tables not to come to the question with fixed ideas, but simply to give attention to the present systems of control, keeping any decision of ends till the last. THE POLITICAL SIDE OF CONTROL I take up now what will be the second part of the round table dis¬ cussions; that is, the question of international adjustment. It will be the work of the round tables when this question comes up to see how far the present system of international organization is of use for the control of the warring interests about which I have been talking; to see bow far political conditions in a country or the existence of agreements' be¬ tween countries may be a help or the opposite in getting a balance be¬ tween group interest; and last, to see what new appartus is possible, or what changes in the old, in the interest of peace and the good of society. Even if this was simply an economic conference—which it is not— it would be necessary to give some attention to these political questions, because economic forces are not acting in a separate field but through

the present forms of our political organization,—in fact it is frequently simply cnance which makes us say that a given trouble is political or economic. It may be dependent on how far the special business interest in question is ready to make use of normal business adjustments, such as price agreements, combines or the putting up of branch industries in other countries, or how far they make use of the power of the nation by forcing the government's hand, and so getting what is desired in more roundabout ways, such as tariff agreements, the limiting of markets, and the investment of money in other countries. I am pointing out that there are these two ways of making adjust¬ ments because you may then see that it is necessary for all forms of international adjustment to be made through governments. Cartels have made international agreements in which governments have had no part, and these are quite as important as trade agreements made by the usual government representatives in different countries. In the same way, the distribution of Far Eastern markets as worked out by, say, the Shell and Standard Oil Companies among themselves is an adjustment no less important than a government agreement undertaking to keep the "Open Door" in these places. In fact, it is possible that a number of interna¬ tional troubles might be put right more smoothly if agreements were made between the business interests in question, for example, between the Malayan rubber producers and the American tyre (f) industry, than by the much more complex process of government decision and protests. One thing which would give support to this view is the way in which there has been a tendency among American business groups to give greater value to the more elastic sort of adjustment which is possible in a private committee of judges than to the slower process of going to law. However that may be, we will do well to keep in mind that probably the greater part of all troubles and agreements between nations^—those which are said to< be economic no less than those which are political— are in fact put straight by the normal process of discussion between government representatives. For this reason, it is part of the first busi¬ ness of the 'Round-Tables' to see how well these normal processes of adjustments are working and specially, to see how far there is any hope that they will be of use for the special troubles of the present day which more and more take a complex economic form. Clearly one question which will come up here is that of how far the consuls and government representatives generally are in the right position to be responsible for this sort of discussions. The amount of special international apparatus which was put into effect after the war is a sign that the normal organi¬ zation is not quite what is needed for meeting the questions we are faced with today. In addition to the international agreements of which I have been talking, in which the government has no part, we have had a great number of international conferences taking place in connection with special questions. Some are on the scale of the World Economic Confer¬ ence in London; others are limited to smaller groups of nations, such as

the conference of the Danubian countries; others have to do with special goods of one sort or another, like the present conference of the wheat- producing countries. The World Court, the League of Nations, and the International Labour Office, are representative of another side of this apparatus for adjustment; and different again, is the international net¬ work of trade agreementsv most of which have some connection with the 'Most Favoured Nation Clause (e)'. The experience of the Conference on the State and Economic Life which took place in London in May gives one the idea that even a discussion of the effect of the existence of 'Most Favoured Nation' agreements in the Pacific countries will give much light on the question of how well the present organization of government rela¬ tions with one another is working out. (1). The Conference will no doubt be interested to get an opinion from the experts who are present as to why certain sorts of international agreements, such as those in connection with posts, radio and telegrams have been working more or less smoothly, while others have been hard to put into operation, or have even been dropped completely. In addition they will probably be interested in hear¬ ing why an adjustment committee working as part of the normal system, like the Canadian-American Border Commission, has a long and good record, while a suggestion as made at earlier Institute Conferences to have this sort of committee in connection with the same questions of adjustment in Manchuria has1 had no support from the political authorities. You will frequently see that the reasons why certain sorts of inter¬ national organization have not been of great use is not because there is anything wrong with the plans themselves, but because the conditions in one or more of the countries do. not make it possible for those countries to put into operation their part of the agreement. If this is so, it seems that one good line of discussion for the 'Round-Tables' to take up would be that of looking into those political conditions in the different Pacific countries which have a tendency to get in the way of plans for interna¬ tional adjustment. Some of these are common knowledge. The laws in the United States about forming business combines have for a long time made it hard for that country to take part in such an international agree¬ ment as the World Copper Cartel, and even now it is only possible for it to do so because of a very free reading of the Webb Pomerene Act. (2) The existence of state's rights, as separate from the rights of the nation as a unit is another fact which has kept back the development of these plans of international organization in the United: States, Canada and Australia. In a different sense the new relations between the countries of the British Commonwealth after the Ottawa Conference may keep them from taking part freely in outside international agreements, though how great the effect of this will be is still uncertain. The Manchurian trouble has given a clearer example of this point. On the one hand there (1) See the paper "The State and Economic Life," Institute of Intellectual Co-operation," Paris, June 1933. (2) American paper "Government Promotion of Foreign Trade in the United States," p.p 20-31.

is a school with the belief that because the Chinese government has so little control of certain parts of the country it is impossible to make international agreements with that country which will be of any use; and on the other hand, there are those who take the view that the organization of the Japanese Government under which the military is outside the control of the Cabinet is equally responsible for the trouble. If we go still farther into this question, it is possible to see that a great number of new points may come up because of the existence of a government which has not general international support, such as that of Manchuria. The normal answer, when points of this sort are made, is that these are private questions to do with the separate countries and that it is wrong to have international discussions on them. Clearly, if this was the general opinion about all such questions, we would be unable to go forward at all, and it would not be possible to make any international agreements of value. Happily, in a conference like this, the idea that special interests touching one nation are the business of that nation only will not have such general respect as it has in the Geneva meetings where government representatives take part, and there is some chance that suggestions of great value for the future may be made. . CONTROL AND EDUCATION I have said that economic forces are not limited to a special field but that their operation takes place within a given form of political struc¬ ture. For a completely true statement we will have to go farther and say that they are, in fact, a part of the very structure of society. In these days any attempt on the part of some business group to get special rights or on the part of the Government to put into operation some new instrument of political control, is dependent for its outcome on getting the support of public opinion. For this reason the education of public opinion is one question which has necessarily to come into any suggestion loi economic and political control. Here, then, is one reason for having in our discussion list a heading on education. Let me once more make it clear that these discussions are not simply a sort of side-line of the Banff Conference; and they are not put in simply to make a connection with the discussions of the 1935 conference. They are in fact an important part of our present discussion. Most of you will see that there will come to light in the first week's discussion in this Conference a number of examples of tendencies which aie out of harmony with one another in our general values or what might be looked on as the field of education. Sometimes it may take the form of two opposite ideas about education as seen, say, in the school system cf my own country. At other times, there may be a bad adjustment between current economic tendencies and current theories of education. And almost everywhere in our discussions we will see signs of the fact which had been so frequently noted, that public opinion and ideas of education are unable to keep up with the quickly changing conditions of economic development.

When I say education I naturally have in mind not simply the teach¬ ing given in schools and universities, but that wider and, possibly, more important education which goes on through the newspaper, the motion picture, the radio, and public statements. It is important to keep in mind the fact that these two ways of education may be very different and a great cause of trouble in this field because they have different theories at the back of them and are working to different ends. It seems unnecessary to give examples. In the teaching of schools and universities much weight may be put on the good effects of free international relations and the value of the arts and learning of other countries; while at the same time the full force of a nation's newspapers and other public opinion forming groups may be used to give the idea of "my country right or wrong." An example of this is that all the econ¬ omic experts of a nation may make protests against a new tariff law wihout having the least effect on what t'he government does. In discussions of such questions of education it has been the experience of the Institute that two different views quickly come to light in the round tables. On one side there are those—generally not teachers—to whom the question seems to be the way in which different business groups are attempting to get control of public opinion for their private interests. This group naturally sees the question as one of decisions! about the government control of news, or the degree to which the outlook of newspaper-writers is changed by their desire to get advertisementsv or the use of the instruments of public educationfor the support of one poitical group. To them the chief question seems to be the working out of some system for controlling these forces, which are against the general interests of society. For those who see the question from this angle, there will be much material for attention. It is common knowledge that there is control of news in the Pacific. Sometimes it is done openly by the government; sometimes by special business interests working in more roundabout ways. In some countries the great businesses have a very strong grip on the operation of news services, radio and telegraphs. The other line of attack is quite different. A number of persons, and among them most experts on education, see the process as> something much deeper than the conscious attempts at changing public opinion by businessi interests. In their view, what is important is the way in which the attempts at control are themselves changed because of the existence of the present framework of society and because of past history; and their interest is in seeing how these slower moving forces of education, which are forming the general outlook of the public may be used against group interests which are making attemptsi at forming public opinion; or, even better, to see that no profit comes from such attempts, because they are not able to get the attention and approval of society. It will be clear then, that these two lines of attack will have their supporters in the Banff Conference, and the two will, in fact, be used. If that is so, let us come now to the six questions which have been put

down as a rough guide to the discussions on education. Possibly the firsit which will come to the front is that of seeing how far the bad economic adjustments of the Pacific are made worse by the systems and theories of education in the different countries. How far, for example, would a suggestion for forming a sort of international marketing com¬ mittee be taken seriously in our country when, for years, an idea had been fixed in the public mind that it was impossible to let any outside nation have anything to do with the way our goods were put on the market. The second question puts before us a trouble which is very common— that of getting an adjustment between processes of education and the economic conditions of the time. The sort of wrong adjustment which is seen so frequently in the overproducing of "white collar workers" is one important part of this. It is seen not only in countries in a high stage of economic development, but equally (and possibly with more damaging effects) in colonies which are at a low level of economic development. In such places, though the government has the very best desire to help, thousands of persons are being given an education which will put them completely out of touch with their older beliefs and ways of living, and at the same time, give them no place in the new society, simply because there are not enough openings for the sort of work for which they have been trained. The other side of this same question might be put as the discovery of how far this need of a better adjustment in education might be put right by a changed system of education designed to keep in existence (at least for the present), a number of the old ways of working and living, which have been of economic value in the past. For example if it is impossible to get the right sort of work in great towns for all the young Chinese or Filipino men and and women who have had an education, it may be possible to give them some work by the development of certain farming or hand industries which have come down from the past. I make that statement without being certain that it would have much value, because unhappily most of our experience makes it seem that these attemptsi to keep old ways of industry and handwork in existence have had very little effect in the long run. And it is my opinion that the round-table representatives will be interested in working out the reasons why this is so, and in putting forward an answer which goes deeper into the causes of the trouble. In the field of education, as in that of economics, my belief is that no discussion of these questions will be of any great value till representa¬ tives have in their minds a clear idea of the form of society we are working for. If this is not done we have no certain way of measuring the different suggestions against one another. To put such a system of values into words or to come to a decision, say, on how far it is right for the private person to be the servant of a nation, or of a special group in a nation, or how far it is right for the new organization to be based on the free development of every man and woman, is work for which I have not the necessary training. But we are happy in having a number

of represientatives here who do have that special training. And so I will make my last point a request to the experts in education and in changing forms of society to undertake this work of making a clear statement on the sort of society we have in mind for the future when making our decisions here about the different plans. It is to those experts that we will go for an answer when this Conference cornea to an end: an answer to the question Why have we been doing all this? What are we hoping for anyway?

Land Utilization Investigations and Their Bearing On International Relations BY CARL L. ALSBERG DIRECTOR, FOOD RESEARCH INSTITUTE, STANFORD UNIVERSITY AND CHAIRMAN, RESEARCH COMMITTEE, AMERICAN COUNCIL, INSTITUTE OF PACIFIC RELATIONS INSTITUTE OF PACIFIC RELATIONS HONOLULU ~ 1933

FOREWORD The following essay on the relevance of land utilization studies to the Institute's program of research and to international relations may be regarded as an introduction to the task of coordinating land utili¬ zation studies in the Pacific area, entrusted by the International Re¬ search Committee to Dr. Carl L. Alsberg, a Director of the Food Research Institute, Stanford University. From the inception of its research program, the Institute has devoted major attention to studies in this field. The two largest projects, those in China and Japan, have extended over a six-year period; somewhat smaller studies in land utilization have been, or are being, carried out in Australia, New Zealand, the Philippines, and Korea. Related study projects in agricultural practices and policies, entrusted to the Stanford Food Research Institute with funds from other sources, are also under way. Certain countries not included in the scope of the Institute's land utilization studies, such as the United States, Canada, and the Netherlands East Indies, have already been adequately investigated by governmental agencies or other research bodies. With this extensive program of Institute studies in separate coun¬ tries and the investigations already completed by other institutions in other countries, the International Research Committee, during its meetings at the time of the China Conference in 1931, voted funds for a study which would coordinate into a comprehensive report the findings of these several inquiries. Delay in the completion of cer¬ tain national studies has suggested the wisdom of postponing the coordinating project until the results of more separate investigations are at hand. In the meantime, however, Dr. Alsberg has prepared the following paper in order to indicate the importance and relation of land utilization studies to the discussion of international economic relations. Although these pages are recommended for study in connection with the forthcoming Banff Conference, the Institute does not assume responsibility for statements of fact or opinion con¬ tained in them.

land utilization investiga¬ tions and their bearing on international relations IT IS not so long ago that most men saw no large role for agricul¬ ture to play in the shaping of national policy. When, in 1887, it was proposed to establish a ministry of agriculture in the United States, Attorney-General Garland prepared a memorandum on the subject for President Cleveland, in which the following passage occurs: "The Cabinet is in session, and after the usual call upon the officials for anything they wish to submit, the President says: 'Mr. Colman,1 have you anything to submit?' Mr. Colman: 'Yes, sir, I have quite a number of letters discussing the question whether it is best to plant potatoes in the dark or the light of the moon, and many inquiries as to whether the black land is better for cotton than the red sandy soil, and whether the South-down sheep is adapted down South or up North, etc' These now are about fair samples of the matters that would come before the Cabinet from that de¬ partment. Now, what on earth has the government to do with these?"2 And this was written at a time when agriculture in America was suffering so severely from low prices that farmers were joining mine owners in the campaign for the free and unlimited coinage of silver that led ultimately to the nomination of William Jennings Bryan for the presidency in 1896. In some countries, this type of attitude prevailed for a long time—indeed, in some of them, until the Great War compelled the establishment of ministries for agri¬ culture. Even today, the average man does not clearly understand the ways in which departments of agriculture may, and often do, contribute to the shaping of both internal and external national policies. Of these ways, none is more important than the investiga- 1 Colman was at that time U. S. Commissioner of Agriculture. 2 Garland to Cleveland, March (no day), 1887. Cleveland Papers. Cited in Allan Nevins, Grover Cleveland, A Study in Courage (New York, Dodd, Mead, 1933), p. 363.

tion of land utilization, which forms the basis for land-utilization policies. The purpose of this essay is to set forth the nature of land- utilization investigations and to show how the findings of such investigations may be used to influence the relations between peoples and nations. The term land utilization is rather new, although there is nothing new about the subject. Land-utilization studies of one sort or another have long been made. Indeed, the science known as agron¬ omy is really the study of the use of land in all its aspects, but agronomists have stressed primarily the technique of treating the land rather than the economic aspects of land use. In America, and in some other countries, the term agronomy came to be re¬ stricted to the more purely technological aspect of the subject. Later, with the rising interest in agricultural economics, the need was felt for a term that had not acquired a restricted meaning as the word agronomy had in America. Students began to use the term land utilization, or land use, which had not yet come to have any very definite meaning. Since, in America, such students were mostly interested in economic aspects of the use of land, these terms have come to imply the economic aspects of the use of land, just as the term agronomy had earlier come to be limited largely to the technological aspects of the use of land. The sorts of studies, then, with which we shall be concerned, are primarily economic studies of the use of land. However, land uses cannot be investigated without a good deal of consideration of the technological aspects of the problem, that is of agronomy; nor can clarity be achieved without regard for social and political conse¬ quences of the use that is made of land. Regard for these conse¬ quences controls the point of view from which land-utilization studies are made. They may take the point of view of the individual farmer, or of a given area, or of a nation as a whole. As a matter of fact, students are engaged upon all three types of inquiries, but not all types are classed as land-utilization investiga¬ tions. Some of them are known as farm-management studies; others, as studies in agricultural policy. The use of land on a particular farm or group of similar farms is studied for the purpose of indicating to the farmers how they, individually, may improve their economic position; however, in

America, such studies are not classed as land-utilization studies, but rather as farm-management investigations. Farm-management study is analogous to the study of efficiency in factory management. Both seek to improve the economic condition of individuals without con¬ cerning themselves with the question whether or not improvement in that condition is gained at the expense of other elements of the population. Since conditions in a given region, though varying somewhat from farm to farm, present certain uniformities of climate, topog¬ raphy, and soil, studies are also made dealing not with individual farms alone but with groups of farms. The purpose is to discover general principles applicable to the area as a whole. The problem is then conceived as the determination of the best method of utilizing a given agricultural area. This is the type of investigation that typically—at least in America—is regarded as the study of land utilization. For the most part, the objective is to improve the eco¬ nomic condition of an area or of a class of farmers; and students do not always concern themselves with the question whether or not the procedures recommended are in the interest of the nation as a whole. Land Studies and National Policy If the investigator's aim is the general economic welfare of the nation as a whole, he must view the varied uses of the nation's land as a whole. He must integrate all the separate land-utilization inves¬ tigations. He will soon realize that the uses of land in different regions lead to competition of these regions with one another. It will be clear to him that the uses of land greatly influence the welfare not merely of individual farmers, not merely of regional groups of farmers, but of all other elements of the population as well, whether they be engaged in industry, in commerce, in the profes¬ sions, or in the government services. He will search for those uses of land that promote the economic welfare not of individual farmers alone, not of specific agricultural regions alone, but of the people of the country as a whole. He will try to determine what agricul¬ tural policy is in the general interest and likely to achieve the greatest economic welfare, not of individuals, groups, or classes, but in the aggregate. In reaching his conclusions, he will take into considera-

tion not merely the interests of his generation, but also the interests of posterity. He will be guided by consideration of the conservation of natural resources. He is, then, studying certain aspects of na¬ tional agricultural policy.3 Thus, Gray defines land utilization as "that branch of land eco¬ nomics which comprises the study of the land resources of a nation or other geographical unit from the standpoint of their economic significance with a view to determining for what and how they may be most effectively employed."4 Land-utilization studies must be based upon farm-management policy on the one hand, and upon national policy on the other; the best use of land depends in part upon the character of the national policy for agriculture. Obviously, one must know how all the vari¬ ous sorts of land of a nation may be utilized, if one is to make an in¬ telligent choice of policy. There may be, and usually are, alternative uses for land, and it is necessary to make a choice among them. Nevertheless, many nations have evolved agricultural policies by dealing with each situation as it arose rather than by deciding in advance upon a well-defined plan based on land-utilization and other investigations; sometimes the country does not even realize that it has a policy. A policy thus arrived at need not be that most de¬ sirable in the general interest. One might take the Union of South Africa as an example of the dependence of policy upon alternative uses of land. The greater part of the country is semi-arid. Some of it is fit only for pasturage; some of it can be used for pasturage, for grain farming or for fodder crops. Some small portion of it is humid enough for fruit culture and mixed farming.5 The alternative uses of much of the land of the Union of South Africa would seem to be animal husbandry and grain farming. These alternatives limit the range of choice of 3 The term policy is here used, not to designate a short-term program, but in the sense in which it has been defined by Black, thus: "The term 'policy' implies a more or less carefully considered and fundamental course of action followed consistently for a period of years." John D. Black, "The Problem of Determining an Economic Policy for American Agriculture," in Conference on Economic Policy for American Agriculture at the University of Chicago September 7, 8, and 9, 1931, edited by E. A. Duddy (Chicago, University of Chicago Press, 1932), p. 1. * L. C. Gray, "The Field of Land Utilization," Journal of Land and Public Utility Economics, April 1925, I, 152. BCf. Hubert D. Leppan, Agricultural Policy in South Africa (Johannesburg, Cen¬ tral News Agency, 1931).

agricultural policy. It is obvious that the study of agricultural policy is based upon the study of land utilization, and that there is no clear line of demarcation between them. This is being recognized, as witness the recent creation in America of the National Land Use Planning Committee and the National Advisory and Legislative Committee on Land Use. Their objective is not to study the use of land from the viewpoint of individual areas or of individual farmers, but from the viewpoint of the welfare of the United States as a whole. The Land Utilization Survey of Britain, established in 1932, has similar objectives. Special Needs for Land Studies in New Countries Land utilization needs to be studied intensively, especially in new countries. Such studies are capable of preventing many mistakes, un¬ necessary hardships, wastes, and human tragedies that accompany the advancement of the frontier with its pioneer fringe. "If land always at once found the uses at which it has comparative advan¬ tage, there would be no need for any land-utilization studies."6 Often, land is not put to the most advantageous use, "because the utilizers of it do not know enough about its natural qualities, about the regions with which it must compete for a market, and about the nature of the demand of the various products to which it might be devoted; because they fail to foresee the changes that will take place in competition and demand; and because of the time it takes to shift to a new use even after it is recognized as needed."7 In old countries, by a process of trial and error extending over centuries, the most advantageous uses of land have usually been discovered. In a new country, this needs to be done by a speedier method than trial and error. Therefore, in them one turns to land-utilization research. In a new country with unoccupied farm land, no wise immigra¬ tion policy can be devised unless the potentialities of the land are understood, for these determine the conditions under which people can be induced to go upon the land and remain there. Few countries want immigration to their cities, for there the newcomer either un- 6 Research in Agricultural Land Utilization, Scope and Method, edited by J. D. A thorough study of its newer lands is required of every new country to determine how many immigrants, and of what sorts, may be admitted, and how they may be distributed.8 If the newer land is marginal, it can probably only be settled by immigrants willing to put up with a low standard of living. These are certain to be illiterate people not easy to assimilate. If such people are placed on marginal lands where they cannot hope to achieve a high standard of living, "the difference between their standards and the accepted standards of the country will be accentuated and perpetu¬ ated."9 A focus of discontent will have been created. Land Studies in Old Countries It would be a mistake, however, to assume that in old countries there is no place for land-utilization investigations. In them, also, there is interest in land utilization, but for different reasons. Old countries are commonly more or less densely populated, like Japan or Germany. They may not be producing all the food they con¬ sume, or they may be merely tending toward increasing importation of foodstuffs. In some of them, the old and tried methods of land utilization are no longer adequate to feed the people; food must be, or there is prospect that it will have to be, imported as population grows. Therefore, studies are made to determine whether new ways of using the land may not be more effective in producing food than the old, customary ones. Often, it is not merely a matter of using in improved ways land already in agricultural use, but also of bringmg waste land into cultivation either by irrigation works, or by drainage, or by con¬ trolling rivers to prevent overflow. The decision regarding the ad¬ visability of such public works is not merely a question of engineer¬ ing or finance; it is equally a question of land utilization and of population growth. Whether it is wise to bring new land into culti¬ vation depends, among other considerations, upon whether popula- 8 Isaiah Bowman, The Pioneer Fringe (American Geographical Society Special Pub¬ lication No. 13), 1931, p. 85. 9R. The economic, and espe¬ cially the agricultural economic, aspects of such proposals are too often neglected. For example, the cost of flood prevention on the lower Mississippi River will come to $50.00 per acre, and yet no economic study has been made to determine if this is warranted.10 Such an economic study, if made, would have to be based in part upon land-utilization study. Furthermore, the proper evaluation of great public works requires consideration of their effects upon the utilization of land. For example, the projected Great Lakes- St. Lawrence Tidewater Waterway admittedly will affect profoundly the way in which farm lands will be used; yet, so far as the printed record shows, neither the Canadian nor the United States government has made competent scientific study of this question. The only serious studies of this sort have been made outside the government services.11 Even in old, stable countries, well able to feed themselves at home, land-use studies are not out of place; they would be only in a static world or in one in which there is no world trade. In a world that is continuously evolving, that is opening up new lands, that is pro¬ gressing in technology with giant strides, that through its very progress is creating obsolescence in all the means of production, the farmer as well as the manufacturer must reckon with ever-shifting conditions. A system of farming that may have been advantageous in one decade may become disadvantageous in another, because of new inventions or changes in transportation or new competition from other regions or changes in social organization, etc., etc. In older countries, land-utilization studies become of prime importance in periods of rapid economic change. Whether a given piece of land is or is not marginal depends upon the standard of living of the farmer who cultivates it. He will farm it only if he is enabled thereby to maintain his standards. If his standards rise, as they are bound to do if the general standard of living of the country rises, and if upon his farm he is unable to maintain his standards at the now higher level, he abandons his farm. For him, it has become submarginal. In rapidly developing countries and especially in times of great social changes, maladjustments in the use of land occur for social as well as for technological reasons. The purpose of land-utilization studies is to remedy maladjust¬ ments in the use of land from whatever cause they may arise. It is not astonishing, therefore, that in the post-war period there has been greater interest in land-utilization studies than ever before; the war caused all sorts of maladjustment—in agriculture no less than elsewhere. The war led to an immensely sharpened post-war com¬ petition among farmers. In belligerent countries, agricultural pro¬ duction was reduced during the war, so that distant regions had to be drawn upon to make good the deficit. In consequence, agricul¬ tural production was stimulated in most of the newer countries, for they were at peace. One form this stimulation took was the sub¬ stitution of machines for draught animals, with the release of a large acreage for food crops that had theretofore been used for feed crops.
