When peace came and the war-stricken coun¬ tries were able again to turn to farming, they had the opportunity to rationalize their disorganized agriculture on a more effective basis than before the war. Indeed, they were compelled to change their agricultural organization to meet the changed conditions growing out of the stimulus the war had given to agriculture in the newer countries. These newer countries also found it necessary to give attention to their agricultural organization; for, as farming in the war-stricken countries recovered, the new countries found the mar¬ kets for their new expanded farming restricted. Competition was sharpened on all sides, and farmers had to become more efficient if they were to continue in commercial farming. But to become more efficient, they had to learn to use their lands to the best pos¬ sible advantage. To this end, land-utilization studies are basic. Hence, everywhere in recent decades, in old countries as well as in new, there has been growing interest in land-utilization investi¬ gations. South Africa—an Illustration It is obvious, then, that land-utilization studies furnish basic mate¬ rial without which it would be difficult to formulate wise new agri¬ cultural policies or modify old ones. Let us illustrate by a specific example, and for that purpose let us turn again to the case of the Union of South Africa, because it is perhaps the simplest to be found. As we have seen, much of the land, except certain limited humid areas along the seaboard, may be used either for the rearing of animals or for growing grain. Therefore, the question of policy for the Union of South Africa is: Should the country produce the maximum of grain possible or the maximum of animal products? If the former, then the humid regions should be devoted to fruit culture for export and to mixed farming, the dry regions to grain farming principally and to animal husbandry only in so far as grain farming is not practicable. The government would favor grain growers by tariffs or otherwise, and would take all feasible steps to encourage dry-land farming. Its land policy would discourage the holding of very large tracts, but would encourage the holding of land in tracts of moderate extent, such as would furnish farms of optimum size for dry-land farming. It would favor the settlement

of immigrants upon such land as is suitable for grain crops. Its road- and railroad-construction policy would be to build a network sufficiently fine-meshed to furnish transportation to market to as many grain farmers as possible. If, on the contrary, the policy adopted is to produce the maximum of animal products, then the humid regions would be devoted to growing fruit for export and concentrated feeding stuffs to "finish" for the market the livestock produced in the more arid regions. The semi-arid regions would be devoted primarily to pasturage and to the growing of fodder crops. The government would not expend large sums in irrigation works. It would not raise tariffs on maize, wheat, or other dry-land crops. It would not place obstacles in the way of holding land in tracts large enough for stock ranges. Its policy in regard to road and railroad building would be adapted to the needs of a very extensive form of agriculture. Its scientific work would be directed rather toward the improvement of pastures, of feed crops, and of the breeds of animals, than toward the improve¬ ment of food crops.16 If the Union of South Africa is to become a grain-exporting coun¬ try primarily, her place in the world's economy will be other than if she is to be an exporter of animal products. Her tariff policy will be different, obviously. Her immigration policy and her treatment of the native will be different also, for grain growing requires more labor than animal husbandry. In short, her orientation toward the rest of the world, at least so far as her agricultural activities influence that orientation, will be profoundly influenced by the agricultural policy she adopts, and this policy depends in large measure upon the use of land. Land Utilization and Foreign Policy It must now be obvious to the reader that agricultural policy is one of the determinants of a country's foreign policy. Conversely, for¬ eign policy is one of the determinants of agricultural policy and, in consequence, of land utilization. For example, if a country seeks to be self-sufficient, clearly this policy must largely influence its agricultural and land-utilization policy; but the policy necessary to 16Leppan, op. cit.

achieve self-sufficiency with respect to agriculture will be different according as the country is densely or thinly populated. Thinly populated countries, like the United States, Canada, and Australia, are usually exporters of foodstuffs and raw materials. Their interest in land utilization is not based on the desire to be self-sufficient in regard to food; as a rule, they are not merely self- sufficient but producers of surpluses beyond their own needs— except for special products, such as tea, coffee, sugar, spices, and the like. They tend to erect tariff barriers only against some of the agricultural raw materials in respect to which they are importers— and they do so for the purpose of encouraging production at home. Or they encourage domestic production by bounties and other sub¬ ventions. The main objective of their land policies is to produce at low cost so that they may compete with other exporting countries in the markets of the world. Their efforts are not directed toward bringing into cultivation the greatest area possible, but rather to specialize in the production of such crops as can be produced at suffi¬ ciently low cost to compete successfully on the markets of the world. Their problem is rather to restrict the production of export crops to such lands as are capable of producing these crops at low cost and to find uses for the other lands on which the export crops can be produced only at costs too high to compete in world markets. The problem is to find domestic uses for such land, since its high-cost product cannot compete on world markets. This involves the use of such land for grazing or for the growing of timber. But such coun¬ tries are always tempted to deal with the situation by artificial means. Agricultural tariffs help little, since these countries export agricultural products. They are tempted to keep marginal land in the production of crops for export by one form or another of subsidy, such as bounties, export premiums, and the like. Land Utilization and Population Pressure Densely populated countries are of two types: those with a highly developed economic structure and those with a more or less primitive one. Those of the first type, if they do not seek to b>e self-sufficient, may encourage the importation of agricultural products in order to be in a favorable position to manufacture for export. If, on the contrary, they seek to be self-sufficient with respect to their food

supply, they tend to erect tariff barriers or to grant subsidies in order to keep high-cost producers of foodstuffs in production. Their use of land seeks to effect the maximum volume of product, which often seems to them more important than to produce at low cost. They tend not to concentrate upon those agricultural commodities that can be produced at low cost, but to attempt to produce foodstuffs and to bring under cultivation the last possible bit of land. They tend to erect tariff barriers against the food and other agricultural products they produce domestically, in order that their price level may be high and that, in consequence, the maximum amount may be produced at home. Thereby, they tend to raise the cost of living and, therefore, the level of money wages (though not real wages) and to make it more difficult for their industries to work for export. The second type of densely populated country, that with a primi¬ tive economic structure, practices subsistence farming, and, there¬ fore, is self-sufficient with regard to agricultural products. Such countries may be regarded as neutrals, in so far as their agriculture has an influence on international relations. In subsistence farming, each family or village produces all or nearly all that it needs. The commodities produced are sold only to a very slight extent, though they may be bartered locally for other produce. In such a com¬ munity or country, there is but little division of labor or specializa¬ tion. Here, there is no apparent need for land-utilization studies. The subsistence farmer produces everything that he needs. He seeks, of course, to produce with as little effort as possible, but since he does not sell, he does not compete with other farmers; and it is, therefore, less important to him whether his costs are high or low. Efficiency in production is low, for it lacks the efficiency that comes from division of labor and exchange of products. Standards of living, in consequence, are low. In such communities, development of division of labor results, of necessity, in the production of an in¬ creased quota of wealth, with the possibility of a more extensive satisfaction of wants and a rise in the standard of living. With the development of division of labor, subsistence farming gradually is replaced by cash-crop farming, in which the farmer produces for sale, whether in the domestic or in the world market. It involves the production of whatever can be produced at lowest cost, and its exchange, through the medium of money, for other commodities

produced by other farmers who can produce those commodities at low cost. Land-utilization studies, then, become more important. Land Uses in Tropical Dependencies Many of the tropical dependencies of advanced countries are, so far as the indigenes are concerned, in the state of subsistence farm¬ ing. The policy of the controlling power has made for specialization, but not by natives. It is characteristic of most of these countries that, when they first came under the sway of the colonizing power, they were relatively thinly populated. There were large stretches of arable land which had not been brought under the plow at all. Spe¬ cialization in agriculture, therefore, took the form of creating plan¬ tations on these wild lands. There were, of course, exceptions to this policy, for example in British West Africa and in Java in the days of the Dutch East India Company and for some decades after its liquida¬ tion. As a rule, in countries in which the plantation system is intro¬ duced in the manner above outlined, the native does not for a long time specialize or practice division of labor to any marked degree. He remains a subsistence farmer; he continues to grow his food crops whether or not his land is better suited to the production of some other crop which he might sell for more than enough to cover the purchase of his needs. The native, then, in a country in which division of labor has been achieved and an export market developed by the establishment of plantations with European management, tends only slowly to raise his efficiency and productivity through spe¬ cialization which has been at the bottom of most forms of material progress in the last century or more. He is ordinarily unable to produce a surplus for sale, and in consequence has nothing left over to raise his standard of living, except, possibly, what he may achieve as a worker upon nearby plantations. His condition is the direct result of the land-utilization policy of the colonizing power. It is often urged that the native is too unintelligent and backward to see the advantage of specialization in agricultural production. That this is, in fact, true is very greatly to be questioned. The native is quite as quick to see where he can make a profit as anyone else. Very generally when he refuses to change his ways it is because he fails to see the benefit to him in such a change. Or, it may be that the change involves capital outlays or, what comes to the same thing,

the storage and holding of products which he, practically lacking capital, is not in a position to make. The principal credit system for the peasants of Java is the government pawnshop; the average loan is less than five guilders ($2.00 gold) . The cooperative village banks on Java average loans of less than 25 guilders. If it is said that the native is improvident and does not save and accumulate capital, one must have in mind the psychology of saving. Saving means present sacrifice and foregoing the satisfaction of a want or need with the expectation, thereby, of satisfying a need in the future. Therefore, whether or not anyone—white, black, yel¬ low, red, or brown—saves depends on the felt intensity of the present need in comparison with the future need. It is this ratio which, though imponderable, determines whether one saves. It follows that, the lower the standard of living of the individual, the less is he likely to save, for the simple reason that his present wants will be the more intense the less he has at the moment. The Malay who, with his family, is never quite full-fed, when through some good fortune he finds himself in possession of a few cents, can hardly be expected to lay by for a rainy day. Perhaps, he hasn't had anything but a little rice and a little fish and a bit of fruit to eat for months. It would be quite unnatural if he did not use his windfall for a feast, and buy, perhaps, a can or a part of a can of California sardines. With the introduction of the plantation system into the thinly- settled undeveloped countries, and with the establishment of peace and order, a rapid increase in population follows. Since the native does not specialize in production but practices subsistence farming, he does not produce a surplus with which to raise his standard of liv¬ ing. He lives as before, and multiplies as before. If he were able to raise his standard of living materially, there is every reason to believe he would ultimately lessen his rate of increase, for this has happened, or is happening, wherever the standard of living has become fairly high. The time, therefore, soon comes when the native and the plantation between them occupy and till every foot of arable land. The problem the colonial power then has to face is how to feed the growing numbers. It is soon confronted with the need of expropriating the land of the plantations and turning it over to the native. This is agricultural revolution—in principle no

different from that which has been forced in many places and many periods by revolts of the peasant, the peon, or the serf. The subdivision of estates is but a temporary solution, for the native uses the additional land for more subsistence farming which is incapable of rapidly raising his standards of living and checking his increase. The result must ultimately be that the colony is devoted almost wholly to the production of food for the native, and the export of raw materials theretofore produced on the plantations ceases. The effects upon the commerce and industries of the home country are obvious. In the long run, therefore, it is to the advan¬ tage of the home country to teach the native specialization in agri¬ cultural production in order that he can produce that which can be produced most efficiently. Such products may then be sold on the markets of the world for enough, and more than enough, to supply subsistence for the native. The surplus beyond this he will employ in raising his standard of living, and this means purchase from abroad of manufactured goods. The commerce and industry of the home country will thereby increase and not diminish. Both the colony and the mother country will profit; but to bring about such a happy outcome is possible only through the adoption of a suitable land-utilization policy in the colony. It is obvious, then, that land utilization lies at the bottom of some of the most important colonial problems. At present Japan supplies sixty per cent of raw silk offered to the world market, ranking first in the world. . . . "When political unification in China is completed and scientific methods are applied to such industries, the Chinese producers will become formidable rivals of the Japanese on account of the larger 22 Ibid., p. 254.

territory, the larger population and, most of all, lower wages. Should the Nationalist Government's ideal for peace and unity materialize, this forecast will become a reality menacing Japanese sericulturists. . . . "On the other hand, we have some reason to suppose that in skill in sericulture, particularly in reeling, the Chinese will not excel the Japanese for some time to come. As far as Japanese raw silk remains superior in quality to Chinese, there will be little need to fear Chinese rivalry. "However, in the event of Chinese raw silk improving in quality up to the Japanese standard, the lower cost of production of the former cannot but affect the latter seriously. It is necessary, there¬ fore, for the Japanese people to formulate a suitable plan to meet such an eventuality before it is too late. Indeed, some Japanese sericulturists have already begun to prepare for possible competition with China, as may be seen in such new devices as feeding silk worms on mulberry branches or outdoor feeding, for which special technical skill is required, although the management does not need so great an amount of labor as in the case of previous methods. "The remarkable development of the rayon industry is another fact that requires our careful attention on account of its future rivalry with raw silk."23 ". . . If this [sericulture] most important part of agriculture is ruined, and no other profitable substitute is found to take its place in the farmers' activities, we must anticipate very serious difficulties while the population-embracing capacity of agricultural land will be reduced to a considerable extent. . . . "Through special circumstances, however, a diminution of the area of farm land may take place without any lowering of the stand¬ ard of living. The planting of fruit-trees and vegetables, for in¬ stance, using scientific methods, would constitute an example of this. . . . "On the other hand, we must know that any future extension of arable land will be the result of the development of less fertile land, and also that there is a tendency to an elevation of the living stand¬ ard among the farmers due to the trend of the times. Taking all these circumstances into consideration, we come to the general con- Ibid., pp. 255-7.

elusion that there will probably be little increase in the capacity of arable land in Japan to support a farming population per unit "24 area. ... 'A . . Everything considered, we can hardly expect to see 40,- 000,000 farming population on the home land of Japan, however the land utilization may develop in the future. On the contrary, we should be grateful for Japanese agriculture if it will succeed in maintaining the present rural population."25 The Need for Organized Research Admitted, it may be argued, that investigations in land utiliza¬ tion are of fundamental national and international importance, is it not the duty of governments and other public agencies to undertake them? Why should private institutions, universities, research in¬ stitutes, associations like the Institute of Pacific Relations devote any of their resources to them? Why should such non-profit-making organizations concern themselves with the problems of the land, when they do not concern themselves with the problems of com¬ merce and industry? The truth is that they have concerned them¬ selves with commerce and industry. Professors of economics, for example, have long concerned themselves far more with the problems of commerce, industry, and finance than with the problems of agriculture. However, even if they had not, there would be far greater justification for research in agriculture by private founda¬ tions and universities (and by governments) than in commerce, in¬ dustry, or finance. Merchants, manufacturers, and bankers are com¬ monly strong with respect to capital; the units they control are large; their numbers are relatively small; and they are usually well or¬ ganized in trade associations of one sort or another. They are well able to do for themselves without the help of private or governmental agencies the sort of research that corresponds to land-utilization in¬ vestigation. The farmers of a country, on the contrary, taken as a whole, have little free capital at their disposal; the production unit each controls is small; the number of farmers is relatively great; they are highly individualistic; and they are rarely united in effective organizations. If others do not carry out land-utilization investiga- Ibid., p. 260. Ibid., pp. 261-2.

tions for them, such investigations will never be done at all. This is the justification for governments and for private organizations sup¬ porting research in the uses of land. It would be unwise to leave the conduct of such studies wholly in the hands of governments, be¬ cause governments cannot from their very nature have a scientific at- tude toward any research, whether in the use of land or in anything else, if the results of research have a bearing upon national policies. Governments are ordinarily committed to very definite policies. In undertaking investigations, they tend to search not for truth as such, but for the particular truth—more often half truth—that can be used as an argument to support government policy. Private organi¬ zations are under no pressure to search for any particular truth and to be blind to others. The Uses of Land-Utilization Studies Nations, of course, are rarely, if ever, unanimous in their choice of policies. Usually policies have been, perhaps always will be, the resultant of a number of forces acting in different directions. Where a single interest, usually an economic one, has been overwhelmingly powerful, it has determined the policy. Where no one interest has been stronger than a group of other interests acting more or less in concert, the policy has been a compromise. Indeed, a people, and even its statesmen, are seldom conscious of adopting a policy when they are in the very act of doing so. Policies are usually mosaics adopted piecemeal; and only after they have been long in force does the pattern they make become apparent. It is the dream of students of land utilization that, if the facts concerning the utilization of land are made known and if the consequences of alternative uses of land are made clear, agricultural policies may, in some measure at least, be adopted with clear consciousness of their significance and in the common interest rather than in that of a class or geographic group. But more than this is necessary: the ultimate end needs to be kept clearly before the mind's eye. Often the end formulates itself in the minds of statesmen no more concretely than that they want their country to be powerful and prosperous. It remains to be seen whether in these days of much loose talk—and writing—about na¬ tional and even international planning statesmen will stop to think what sort of a world they propose to plan for. Obviously one cannot

draw the plans for a ship unless one knows whether it is to be a surface vessel or a submarine. One cannot plan for a nation or a world unless one knows what sort of nation or world one wants. And this raises the question: what is the end to which an agricul¬ tural policy is directed? The answer obviously is, toward the attain¬ ment of the greatest possible general welfare. But who is to deter¬ mine the direction in which welfare is to be sought—the farmer or the factory worker, the capitalist or the proletarian, the artist or the scientist, the clergyman or the philosopher? We have here to deal with spiritual values not susceptible to scientific assay. A people may chose to work toward a given end for spiritual reasons, even though it is demonstrable that this end cannot possibly yield the maximum of material welfare. For example, there are those who, while admitting that a benevolent, all-wise dictatorship is likely to yield the maximum of material welfare, nevertheless prefer the per¬ sonal liberty possible in some forms of democracy, even though this entails a lower standard of living. These are the people who prefer laissez-faire to a planned economy. Thus, a nation may deliberately elect to have a large proportion of its population live on farms, be¬ cause it believes, rightly or wrongly, that rural life is; better than urban life. To bring this about, it may subsidize farming in one way or another. It will, then, produce agricultural materials at higher cost than it would have to pay to purchase from abroad. The re¬ sult may well be a lower per capita real income and, therefore, a lower standard of living than might otherwise be attained. And yet, the nation may prefer a lower standard of living and rural life to a higher standard of living and urbanization. Or a nation may prefer the country to be densely populated with a low standard of living than to have it thinly populated with a high standard of living. It is not the business of the economist or the political scientist or the sociologist to say which of a pair of alternatives of this sort a country should choose, for into the making of such a choice many factors besides reason enter. However, it is their business to point out the probable consequences of alternative choices, and, once the choice has been made, to point out the various methods by which the chosen end can be achieved, and to compare the relative merits of these methods. Whoever may make the decision and whatever sort of world he

may choose, one thing is certain: among the factors that must enter into his considerations is agricultural policy, and agricultural policy cannot be determined rationally without weighing alternative uses of land.
