MARTIN Memorandum communicated by the International Labour Office, Geneva, to the Fifth Biennial Confer¬ ence of the Institute of Pacific Relations, to be held at Banff, Canada, August 14th to 28th, 1933 INSTITUTE OF PACIFIC RELATIONS HONOLULU —1933

THIS is the first of two memoranda which the International Labour Office has been generous enough to prepare for the Fifth Bienniel Conference of the Institute of Pacific Relations, to be held at Banff in August, 1933. The subject of the memo¬ randum bears so directly on the program of discus¬ sions planned for that conference that the Secretariat has no hesitation in strongly recommending it for study by all conference members. While the Secre¬ tariat has undertaken the publication of the memo¬ randum, the Institute itself assumes no responsibility for statements of fact or opinion contained in it. These remain as much the personal expression of the author as if communicated orally. Price 40 cents Copyright, 1933 Institute of Pacific Relations PRINTED IN THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA

Some Social Aspects of World Economic Planning ECONOMIC planning is far from being a new conception. It is at least as old as socialism; and many of the Utopias and ideal republics of earlier times contain the germ of the idea. But while dating back some centuries, perhaps, economic planning in its present form is essentially an outcome of modern technology and the forms of organisation of production, of marketing, of the medium of exchange, and of the division of the product of industry that this technology has developed. In the last few years it has attracted special attention, due mainly to the concurrent existence of an abnormally severe depression in the whole of the capitalist world and a spectacular experiment in the central organisation of economic activity in Soviet Russia. Within the last few months significant steps in the direction of economic planning have been taken in a number of countries, notably the United States. At present the term is commonly applied and misapplied to the most varied proposals—anything, in fact, from the total abolition of the price system, and all that goes with it, to the haphazard inter¬ ferences with the principle of laissez-faire which are at present taking place in most countries. Furthermore, lending itself as it does to exaggerated statement, economic planning tends at the moment to fall into disrepute among the more sophisticated. For these reasons it would seem that a discussion of its international and social impli¬ cations, to be of any value, must necessarily be preceded by a brief review of certain of the factors in present-day economic life which would appear to make economic planning necessary; and some ex¬ amination of the problems which such planning would be called upon to solve. THE FACTORS WHICH MAKE ECONOMIC PLANNING NECESSARY The factors which make economic planning necessary may be roughly divided into two classes:—those predominantly psychologi-

cal which, for all that they cannot be expressed in quantitative terms, exercise a powerful influence upon events; and those which are in the nature of more or less objective economic facts rendering the present position of modified laissez-faire practically untenable. THE PSYCHOLOGICAL FACTORS First among the psychological factors, at least so far as present public opinion is concerned, must be placed the striking contrast between experience in the capitalist countries and experience in Soviet Russia during recent years. The indexes of production in the various countries over the period of the last decade shew this con¬ trast in high relief.1 It may be said with some assurance that if this difference in movement persists for any considerable length of time —that is to say if the present depression continues more or less unabated, and the Russian experiment does not completely break down—the tendency towards some form of economic planning in the capitalist countries is likely to become marked. Closely related to this illuminating comparison are two or three considerations relating to economic organisation in the capitalist countries, sufficiently broad and self-evident to exercise a powerful influence upon public opinion. There is unquestionably a wide¬ spread feeling that a system in which production to meet the needs of the world is in the nature of a by-product of the pursuit of indi¬ vidual gain is unlikely to prove permanently satisfactory. Certain of the consequences of this system have particularly impressed the public mind. That it should be possible to have supplies of raw material, factory facilities to convert these materials into finished goods, man-power to produce these materials and to operate these machines, and a wealth of idle capital looking for investment, all present in manifest excess, while on every hand men and women are destitute, producers are going bankrupt and Governments are unable to pay their way, is a fact which has done more than anything else, perhaps, to persuade the present generation that human ingenuity should be able to devise a better economic system than that at present obtaining. 1 See League of Nations: Supplement to the Monthly Bulletin of Statistics No 5 May, 1933, Diagram VI. '

Second only to this is the evident absurdity of the economic rela¬ tionships between nations. The refusal of creditor nations to receive the payment of their debts in goods; the tariff barriers and subsidies by which nations endeavour to ensure that, as far as possible, their own people shall pay heavily for goods, while the peoples of other nations shall be able to buy the same goods at the cheapest possible rates; the wholesale destruction of wheat, coffee and other foodstuffs and materials, when these foodstuffs and materials are grievously needed in other countries, and in many cases even in the country where the destruction is going on: these, and similar aspects of present-day economic life under the influence of depression have necessarily influenced the public mind in the direction of planning. Along with these two phenomena, peculiar in the main to a period of acute depression, the more permanent feature of economic in¬ equality, as it occurs in the modern industrial state, and the gradual awakening of a social conscience are factors of evident potency in reinforcing the view that the present system is not one of lasting validity but merely a transitional stage. More fundamental than any of these factors, inasmuch as it is more general, more insidious and more lasting in its effect, is the influence of modern industrial technique upon habits of thought. Men and women accustomed to the planned and organised methods of factory production are prone to extend these methods into wider and wider areas, until they embrace all, or nearly all, of the various aspects of the making and marketing of goods. In a world of small producers, of agriculture and handicrafts, laissez-faire was more or less appropriate, both as a method and as a way of thought. In a world dominated by machine technique, and the organisation which such technique necessarily involves, economic planning tends to become inevitable. THE ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL FACTORS The economic and financial factors making for the development of planning are of even greater significance in the present context, inasmuch as they indicate to some extent the direction in which planning is likely to be guided by the logic of events. Three at least of these factors require to be examined if the necessity for some

measure of economic planning is to be correctly evaluated. These are the breakdown of the international monetary system, the break¬ down of the system of international trade, and the breakdown of the mechanism of adjustment of prices and costs. The breakdown of the international monetary system. For well over a century the gold standard has been the monetary system par excellence. At a time when the developing world community re¬ quired above all else a single monetary standard, and a relatively stable one, it supplied that need. With its aid an expansion of world commerce unparalleled in history was rendered possible. Its tem¬ porary abandonment during the war period, far from lowering its prestige, served but to stimulate a universal determination to restore it with the shortest possible delay. By 1925 the return movement had begun in earnest; by 1928 it was virtually achieved. The world was a gold-standard world more completely than ever before. Three years later the system so laboriously restored was in ruins. At the time of writing, four countries only can be considered as applying the gold standard—France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Switzer¬ land. The remaining countries have either definitely abandoned it or have imposed such regulations upon the free movement of money across their respective frontiers that the system is in more or less complete abeyance. The reasons for this breakdown are many and confused; but the fundamental factors responsible are now fairly clear. The pre-war gold standard, though international in scope, was based on no specific international agreement. It was able to survive, and to function successfully over an extended period, chiefly because the policy which suited Great Britain—the outstanding industrial, financial, trading and creditor nation of the time—was conducive to the maintenance of gold as a world currency. Throughout the ten or twenty years preceding the World War, Great Britain at any moment, by calling in her foreign investments, could, in theory, have drawn into her coffers the great mass of the world's stock of monetary gold. In point of fact, she followed precisely the opposite policy. While selling abroad in large volume, she permitted the free entry of goods in exchange. Furthermore, British investors were always ready to

seek increased profit abroad, so that the balances that would other¬ wise have tended to accumulate within the country were regularly lent overseas. Under these circumstances, the "automatic" gold standard was in fact not so much an international system as a British system applied internationally; and, as such, it worked. Since the World War the United States and France have shared with Great Britain the privilege and burden of the international application of the gold standard; but both in their tariffs and in their investment policies these two countries follow radically different lines from those followed in pre-war Britain. They do not permit the free entry of goods, and they do not consistently invest abroad on long term to the full extent of their resources. Consequently, their position as creditor countries, notably on reparation and war debt accounts, has led to a flow of gold into their reserves at the expense of the reserves of other countries. Roughly speaking, each of these countries now holds about a third of the world's monetary gold, leaving the other fifty or more countries just over a third on which to do their business. A second and closely related factor tending to make the "auto¬ matic" gold standard unworkable in the post-war world is that it is no longer permitted to have its "automatic" effect. According to the classical theory of the gold standard, a country which is living beyond its means—typically, importing more than it is exporting2— will sooner or later have to make good the difference by paying away gold. This will bring about a monetary stringency in the country in question, which, by forcing down money incomes, prices and costs, will discourage its import trade and encourage its exports. Conversely, the countries receiving the gold will expand their monetary circulation; and the consequent increase in money incomes, prices and costs will tend to encourage their imports and discourage their exports—this process continuing until imports and exports find a new equilibrium. There is some doubt whether this system has ever worked strictly according to theory, but there is no doubt that of recent years posi¬ tive steps have been taken in various countries to prevent it from 2 Including invisible items as well as merchandise.

working. An efflux or an influx of gold is not permitted to have its full effect upon the monetary system of the country concerned. Furthermore, the monetary system itself no longer dominates the price and cost position. In this way, contrary to the whole theory of the "automatic" gold standard, one country may lose gold without any marked effect upon its economy, while another may accumulate gold rapidly and merely hoard it away. Under such conditions it is only a matter of time and circumstances for the system to collapse. There is, moreover, a powerful factor, come into full operation only during the past few years, making such collapse far more likely and far more sudden than it would otherwise be. Under modern conditions the transfer of capital from one country to another can be easily and rapidly effected, so that a mere rumour may result in progressive sales of securities and withdrawals of short-term bal¬ ances, leading in turn to a large-scale expatriation of capital, against which the most massive gold reserve in the world is powerless. It should perhaps be emphasised that in thus drawing attention to the phenomena fundamentally responsible for the breakdown of the "automatic" gold standard, there is no intention either of condemn¬ ing or of approving the policies followed by certain of the leading countries in this whole question; indeed, attempts to apportion responsibility are for the most part beside the point. The essential fact that requires to be brought out is that, quite apart from whether these various policies were right or wrong in themselves, they were not compatible with the "automatic" gold standard. If this standard is to work creditor countries must use gold, not hoard it; gold movements must be permitted to have their full effect upon the monetary mechanism; and prices and costs must be made to respond. Whether under these conditions the "automatic" gold standard is worth the working is, of course, another question. But to endeavour to work it with one hand and to prevent it from working with the other is obviously a policy doomed to failure. Particularly is it not practicable when, as in recent years, there are a number of special features—trade restrictions, reparation pay¬ ments and war debts being among the most important—putting an additional strain upon the mechanism. Without these special features the restored gold standard might have lasted more than the three

years it actually endured. But while this is true, it cannot be too strongly emphasised that the defects in this system, as it is now applied, are not accidental and temporary but—unless the countries most concerned are ready to make drastic changes in their financial economic and social policies—fundamental and permanent. The re-organisation of an international monetary standard is thus likely to be one of the first measures in the direction of large-scale economic planning that facts will tend to force upon the world. The breakdown of the system of international trade. Along with this breakdown of the international monetary standard there is the partial breakdown of international trade. World trade at the present time has declined to approximately one-third of its money value in 1929.3 This decline is explained, to some extent, by the fall in prices during recent years; but not by any means entirely. There has been a massive diminution not merely in the value but also in the physical volume of international trade.4 In evaluating this movement, more¬ over, it is necessary to bear in mind that already in 1929 world trade was impeded by a multitude of barriers of all sorts, so that the pres¬ ent decline is in effect a decline from what, under freer conditions, would appear as a decidedly low level. The falling off in international trade is undoubtedly due, in large part, to the artificial obstacles put in its way: exchange restrictions, prohibitive tariffs, quotas, licences, prohibitions and other like mea¬ sures. To a certain extent this interference with international trade is the outcome of attempts, not always well conceived, to inaugurate some measure of national economic planning. But for the most part the actuating motives are more questionable. Chief among them, in all probability, is the influence of extreme nationalism. Here, obvi¬ ously, a remedy must be sought in the political rather than the eco¬ nomic sphere. Apart from this, the present monetary difficulties, dealt with in the preceding section, are responsible in large part for much of the immediate trouble, particularly the restrictions upon exchanges. Among other major factors in the situation, certain illegitimate forms of international competition have been especially 3 Cf. op. cit., Diagram III. 4 Cf. op. cit., Table II and Diagram.

noticeable during recent years as leading to inhibitions upon interna¬ tional trade. They may conveniently be referred to as "economic dumping", "exchange dumping" and "social dumping" respectively. By economic dumping is meant the granting of subsidies, direct or indirect, so as to promote exports. Exchange dumping is the pro¬ motion of exports by an unduly depreciated foreign exchange rate. Social dumping is the name sometimes given to the unfair competi¬ tion promoted by abnormally low wages, long hours, or otherwise unsatisfactory conditions of labour. The setting up of factories on a large scale in countries where labour is plentiful and cheap has made this social dumping of special importance during the last few years. Finally, the fact that except at rare intervals the market for goods in general is inadequate, and particularly so in times of depression, necessarily inclines countries to take measures to protect their home market in the attempt to retain at least that outlet for their products. The breakdown of the mechanism of adjustment of prices and costs. Less obvious upon the surface, but fundamentally the most important of all the economic and financial factors making for economic planning, is the breakdown of the mechanism of adjust¬ ment of prices and costs. The monetary and economic system which grew up in the nine¬ teenth century, and which, in a modified form, still prevails, permits of large variations in the total volume of effective demand for the product of industry. At times the volume of demand is not merely sufficient but more than sufficient to enable the total volume of goods being offered for sale to be disposed of at remunerative prices. At other times the volume of effective demand—the amount of pur¬ chasing power actually being used to buy goods—is definitely not sufficient to enable these goods to be sold otherwise than at a loss. When such a deficiency of active purchasing power makes itself felt, industry tends to slow down, since it is no longer profitable to pro¬ duce. In the past, such a situation was met by an adjustment of prices and costs, and this process of adjustment, sooner or later, permitted production to be resumed. Under present-day conditions, the fluctuations in the volume of effective demand continue to occur —on a wider scale than ever—but the price and cost mechanism no longer works effectively.

Fluctuations in effective demand. The fundamental reasons for the larger fluctuations in the volume of effective demand are two in number. In the first place, the modern credit system is much more elastic than the monetary system preceding it, and elastic not only in expansion but in contraction also. This means to say that in times of deep depression the total quantity of currency and credit in circu¬ lation may be much more considerably reduced than was the case under nineteenth century conditions.5 On top of this, and even more important, the capacity to hold purchasing power idle (i.e., to reduce the velocity of circulation of money) is very great.6 The "free mar¬ gin" in the hands of individuals and of organisations—the purchas¬ ing power which need not be expended but can if necessary be held on one side—probably constitutes a far larger percentage of the total income than in the past. Moreover, with present-day facilities for inter-communication, it is probable that the influence of mass opti¬ mism and mass pessimism is more drastically effective than ever before in causing purchasing power to be used more rapidly or less rapidly as the case may be. As a consequence of these two factors of reduced quantity and reduced velocity, the sum total of active pur¬ chasing power—of money actually being used to buy goods per unit of time—is susceptible of large reductions, with correspondingly violent pressure upon the price-and-cost mechanism. Reductions in prices. This mechanism still retains a certain amount of resiliency—more so in some countries than in others—but, taking the world as a whole, it can no longer be looked upon as a universal shock absorber unfailingly adjusting the economic system to the uncontrolled vagaries of effective demand. When the volume of purchasing power being used to buy goods fails to keep pace with the volume of goods in general being offered for sale, prices tend to decline—but not with the precision and regularity that the occasion demands. Where the nature of the product permits, and where the financial resources of the corporations concerned are adequate, goods are held off the market—thereby (a) preventing the prompt price 5 Cf e g United States Federal Reserve System: Total volume of loans by member banks, 1929: $22,517 million; 1932: $15,267 million—a reduction of approximately one-third in a period of three years only. 6 Cf. op. cit., Diagram XXV.

decline that would otherwise occur, (b) tending to keep the market more or less permanently depressed owing to the possibility of stocks being unloaded upon it at any moment, and (c) bringing about a catastrophic decline at some later stage if and when the provision for holding stocks collapses. On this account, therefore, the price decline resulting from a general deficiency of purchasing power tends to be "patchy'A Other influences present in modern industry tend to make it still more so. Where there is a monopoly or quasi-monopoly of some particular product, those in control may choose to restrict output rather than reduce prices.7 Even where monopoly conditions do not obtain, the process is still of importance so far as certain large groups of commodities are concerned. In particular, whereas a manufacturer working on a profit-and-loss basis will tend to restrict production to the point where his losses are a minimum, the independent farmer will often attempt to make up for lower prices by increasing produc¬ tion. There is thus liable to be a wide difference in the movements of prices of manufactured goods and of agricultural goods respec¬ tively; although here again the presence or absence of monopoly conditions and the possibility or otherwise of holding stocks may at times introduce modifications in the general process. So much for the unequal development of the price movement so far as the supply side is concerned. On the demand side, the falling off in the total volume of buying likewise tends to bring about a number of price disequilibria. Certain types of goods, basically necessary to life, continue to find buyers in approximately the same volume as before. Other types—durable goods and, above all, equipment for making goods—find the springs of demand almost completely dried up. As a consequence, there is yet another factor making for unevenness in the rate of decline of commodity prices. Thus, the price reductions consequent upon inadequate effective demand, while in one respect a first step towards possible re-adjust¬ ment, under conditions of modern industry are liable to be at the same time a pregnant source of future difficulties, inasmuch as special circumstances make the rate of decline in the prices of the various 7 Cf. op. cit., Diagram XXII.

products exceedingly unequal. The cost reductions which should accompany these price reductions, if the mechanism is to work according to theory, are even more uncertain and liable to lead to disequilibria of various sorts. Reductions in costs. Taking industry as a whole, there are three main ways of reducing costs: introducing labour-saving devices; reducing overhead expenses; and reducing wage rates. Labour-saving devices introduced in time of depression, while advantageous to the individual undertaking, are by no means un¬ mixed advantages to industry and the community as a whole. A firm which, finding itself unable to cover expenses, introduces a labour-saving device or speeds up work so that the same output is achieved with less men than before, reduces its labour cost and in this way manages to continue in operation when otherwise it might have to close down. This is all to the good; but the men thrust out of work are not likely to find employment again, so long as the depression lasts. It is true that the firm in question will need less working capital than before, and theoretically this should be avail¬ able to provide employment. But in practice the firm will ordinarily use it to reduce its indebtedness to the bank, and during depression the credit thus extinguished is not likely to be renewed elsewhere. Again, the reduction in costs may enable it to increase sales, so that after all it can keep the whole of its labour force employed; but such an increase in sales is likely to be at the expense of some other firms, since in time of depression it is very rare that an increase in the total consumption of any product takes place; which means in effect that the technological unemployment due to the labour-saving device has merely been transferred to the firms whose sales have been reduced. Such a situation has two major consequences, tending to intensify and prolong depression. For one thing, the unemployment benefit, unemployment relief, or whatever other aid may be given to the men thrown out of work, normally carries with it an increase in taxation. For another, the fact that these unemployed men and their families will necessarily be restricting their purchase to a minimum tends to keep effective demand inadequate. In this manner the

application of labour-saving devices in time of depression, while helping to revive business from the standpoint of the industrial firm making the change, is liable to give rise to further depressive influ¬ ences, making for, rather than reducing, the prevailing stagnation. This, of course, is in no way to contradict the self-evident proposi¬ tion that in the long run labour-saving devices tend to improve the general standard of living. The point here is that they do not necessarily tend to bring about industrial revival but, to a certain extent, have the reverse effect. So much for the reduction of costs by improved methods. In many firms and industries, means of saving labour to the extent necessary to offset the decline in price are either not available or are financially out of the question in time of depression. Particularly is this the case when the price decline is of the present magnitude. Under such circumstances, if production is to be made remunerative at the abnormally depressed price level obtaining, recourse must be had to reduction in overhead expenses, or reduction in wage rates, or both. Under present-day conditions, reduction in overhead expenses is exceedingly difficult to bring about. It is these costs, above all, that fail to meet the requirements of the cost-and-price mechanism of adjustment. As the statistics of the United States Census of Manu¬ factures shew, it is overhead charges rather than labour costs that tend to make production unremunerative. The following table8 is eloquent in this respect. Average Average Selling Cost of Labour Materials Average Over¬ head Costs plus Profits 100 108 95 The reasons why overhead expenses are thus recalcitrant are well known. In the first place, such costs represent for the most part long-term commitments and contracts—rent, insurance and so forth. In the second place, the huge increase in manufacturing plant— which incidentally tends to be financed more and more by fixed- 8 National Bureau of Economic Research: Bulletin No. 45, February 20th, 1933.

interest-bearing securities rather than by equities—results in a large increase in the overhead element. (Thus, in the United States, while the overhead plus profit element in total costs per unit of product amounted to 18 per cent in 1919, it was as high as 25 per cent in 1929). In the third place, when the production of a factory is restricted during depression, the overhead expenditure continues in great part unchanged—so that, with the diminished output, each unit of product has to support a larger fraction of the total over¬ head cost. On the whole, therefore, reduction in overhead charges to corre¬ spond with the fall in prices is exceedingly difficult. The possibility of reducing wage rates to meet the situation would appear to be equally out of the question, both in theory and in practice. Leaving the ethical and social considerations involved completely on one side and examining the question from the point of view of what is feasible, in the narrowest sense of the term, three major considera¬ tions require to be taken into account. In the first place, in a depression as profound as that in process, wage rates in practice cannot be cut to the extent necessary to reduce costs to the level required. Trade unions, unemployment insurance, charitable relief, public opinion and the philosophy of the employers themselves are among the main factors making such a course impossible. In the second place, supposing wage rates were reduced to the extent required, there is good reason to believe that in a depression of the present magnitude the immediate effect would take the form of such a drastic reduction in active purchasing power as to make matters worse rather than better. In the third place, if wage rates were made to bear the brunt of the depression it is greatly to be doubted whether the mass production industries, which rely in great part on working class buying for their prosperity, could be successfully revived. In sum, therefore, the reduction of costs to meet the reduction of prices is a hazardous and uncertain business. As seen above, labour- saving devices, if and when they can be applied in times of depres¬ sion, while helping individual undertakings, give rise at the same time to difficulties for the community and industry as a whole. Over¬ head costs are recalcitrant in the extreme and of growing importance.

Wage rates in practice cannot be rapidly reduced, and if they were would be likely in circumstances such as obtain at present to aggra¬ vate rather than alleviate the depression. Altogether, the price-and-cost adjustment mechanism, whatever it may have been in the past, can now no longer be regarded as a trustworthy instrument calculated to sustain a reasonably high level of business activity under unstable conditions of total effective de¬ mand. Modern monetary and financial organisation make the pos¬ sible fluctuations in effective demand much greater than they were in earlier times. The fall in prices resulting from inadequate effective demand are "patchy" and productive of disequilibria of all sorts. Finally, if such a fall in prices is allowed to go uncorrected the reduction in costs necessary to make output remunerative in many cases cannot be effected and if it could be effected would be pregnant with danger to the whole economic system. It has appeared necessary to consider certain of the factors making for economic planning in some detail because otherwise it is impos¬ sible to estimate the strength of the forces tending to make economic planning a natural outcome of the present world situation, and equally impossible to foresee what general direction the various forms of planning are likely to take. In the ensuing review of some of the main problems which economic planning may be expected to encounter, attention is concentrated more particularly upon those features which the foregoing analysis would seem to indicate as being of especial importance.

THE PROBLEMS OF ECONOMIC PLANNING THE problems that economic planning is likely to encounter may be conveniently considered under four main heads: the organisa¬ tion of production; the organisation of trade; the organisation of the medium of exchange; and the organisation of the division of the product of industry. the organisation of production In some respects the organisation of production is less in need of planning than the organisation of trade, of the medium of exchange, and of the division of the product of industry. The outstanding economic difficulty at present is not to increase production, but to enable the goods produced to find a market. On the other hand, while not the most immediate task at the moment, the effective organisation of production is fundamental to the maintenance and improvement of the standard of living, and is unquestionably sus¬ ceptible of vast amelioration. Such amelioration would have to proceed along a number of lines, including particularly the conserva¬ tion and economic use of natural resources; a certain amount of control of investment, thereby determining the manner in which the community is to be equipped; the standardisation of products wherever and to whatever extent such standardisation is possible and desirable; broader bases of exploitation, and the concentration of production in the more efficient enterprises; and a system of remuner¬ ation, and of employment generally, securing the maximum co-oper¬ ation from those engaged in production. This last point concerning remuneration may be most conveniently considered in connection with the organisation of the division of the product of industry. Of the remaining measures the most immediate would appear to be (1) the provision of investment control, (2) organisation on the basis not so much of the individual enterprise as of the whole of a given industry, and (3) freer trade between the various countries. The degree to which such control and such organisation may be carried, while highly important, is a matter

irrelevant to the present discussion. The main point, which is hardly likely to be disputed, is that so long as a large proportion of the savings of the community are liable to be wastefully directed—waste¬ ful from an economic point of view in many cases, and still more often from a social point of view—production cannot be looked upon as planned; so long as the making of goods and the rendering of services is more or less a by-product of an internecine war between individual producers in which the inefficient, in the slow process of elimination, are able to undercut the efficient and make production unremunerative; there can be no effective organisation of produc¬ tion; and so long as the uneconomic conditions that the progressive erection of trade barriers is at present making inevitable are allowed to persist, the general level of productive efficiency, taking the world as a whole, is unnecessarily low. THE ORGANISATION OF TRADE The organisation of production is intimately bound up with the organisation of trade. In an economy where the consumer is given a wide freedom of choice as to the manner in which he will expend his income, it is evident that production must be directed by market¬ ing, and not vice versa. The all too common practice of making goods and vaguely expecting to be able to dispose of them at a remunerative price is economically wasteful, and in a planned econ¬ omy must as far as possible be eliminated. This is to say that by some means the rate at which the many thousands of types of goods are being produced must be adapted to the probable demand for those types of goods. This calls for far better, fuller and more timely information on production, stocks and sales, than is at present available. It involves the control of the rate at which the capital equipment for making any particular product is being increased, a point already referred to in the preceding section. Above all, it necessitates the control of the rate at which any particular product is being turned out. Concretely, what this would appear to involve is central marketing agencies, keying in with the organisation of production on an industrial basis. Together with this, some organisa¬ tion of international producers' agreements would appear essential if world production of certain basic commodities is to be equated

approximately to world demand. Finally, for marketing agencies to function at all efficiently, much more stable conditions of inter¬ national trade are absolutely essential. Such changes of tariff, quota and exchange restrictions as have taken place in recent years upset the whole process of scientific marketing, and result in industries equipped to meet a world demand being reduced to working far below their possible capacity, with the consequent great waste of capital equipment, and even more of skill and labour power. THE ORGANISATION OF THE MONETARY MEDIUM The organisation of the monetary medium calls for three main lines of action. The first of these concerns— The maintenance of active purchasing power. As already seen in the analysis of the factors rendering some measure of economic planning necessary, the volume of effective demand for goods in general is sometimes excessive and sometimes deficient. With the cost-and-price mechanism incapable of making adequate adjustment, permanent means must be available for sustaining effective demand and, on occasion, of preventing effective demand outrunning indus¬ try's capacity to produce. More explicitly, there must be the necessary organisation for reinforcing the volume of buying of goods in gen¬ eral (producers' goods as well as consumers' goods) whenever effec¬ tive demand tends to become deficient; and on the other hand, of restricting the volume of buying when such restriction is required. It is important to note that measures of this type are in no sense "artificial", as is sometimes alleged by apologists for the system current in the nineteenth century. The fact is that the system then in operation was radically defective, inasmuch as the total volume of demand was subject to wide and, on occasions, catastrophic fluctua¬ tions. This defect was to some extent hidden by the flexibility of prices and costs. With this flexibility a thing of the past, the defect shews up in its true light, particularly in the event of effective de¬ mand falling short of the volume required to keep industry active. In view of its central importance, particularly at the present time, the general lines which measures for maintaining active purchasing power might follow may usefully be outlined:

The means most readily available, under existing circumstances, for directly reinforcing the volume of effective demand is to use money otherwise lying idle (or if necessary to create new money) for the purpose of financing public works. In this way the idle or new money is put into the hands of public works contractors who use it, for the most part, either to buy producers' goods or else to pay the men they employ, who, in turn, use it in the main to buy consumers' goods. By this means a direct increase in effective demand, both for producers' and for consumers' goods, is brought about. Such reinforcement of active purchasing power, moreover, is a net reinforcement, inasmuch as the public works themselves— arterial roads, waterways, public buildings, etc.—are not, for the most part, put upon the market for sale. Without some such net increase in effective demand it would appear impossible in time of depression, or of threatened depression, for the mounting stocks of commodities to be liquidated and for the unused equipment of pro¬ duction to be brought back into operation. In the event of active purchasing power becoming excessive, the restriction of effective demand can be most readily secured by action on the part of the Central Banks, in raising the discount rate and withdrawing purchasing power from circulation by means of open market sales of securities—supplemented, if necessary, by Govern¬ ment action tending to reduce the volume of active purchasing power. These particular methods, it should be said, are given as examples of the type of action required rather than as concrete proposals. As with the other measures involved in economic plan¬ ning, experiment rather than dogma is necessarily the only appropri¬ ate basis for effective action. As will be noted, this aspect of the organisation of the monetary medium is a necessary counterpart of the organisation of trade dealt with above. The chief measure, so far as the organisation of trade is concerned, is to adjust the supply of each particular product to the demand for that particular product. With the organisation of the monetary medium, the main object is to adjust demand for goods in general to the possibilities of the supply of goods in general. These two lines of action are complementary and mutually necessary, the one to the other. If the production of each particular type of com-

modify is adjusted to the demand but no provision is made to keep the volume of buying of goods in general adequate, then production will necessarily be cut down to the deficient demand, and in being so cut down will tend to make demand still more deficient, involving a further restriction of output and so on, in the vicious downward spiral of declining production and declining demand, leading to industrial stagnation and decay. If, on the other hand, effective demand for goods in general is kept adequate, but the various types of goods are not being produced in their right relative proportions, the price system is liable to become badly disorganised, and the efficiency of production, the employment of labour, and the standard of living all suffer as a consequence. The adjustment of production to consumption, and the adjustment of consumption to production, the first applying to each particular commodity, the second to com¬ modities in general, are the two essential processes fundamental to a planned economy. Stabilisation of the price level. The second aspect of the organisa¬ tion of the monetary medium concerns the value of money in terms of commodities. It is obviously undesirable that the value of money should fluctuate as widely and erratically as it has done throughout the industrial era. Such fluctuations tend to disorganise the whole economic and social system. A rapidly rising price level destroys the value of savings and discourages thrift, automatically reduces real wages, and leads to great social and industrial unrest. A rapidly falling price level increases the burden of debt, handicaps all enter¬ prise, and forces countries and business undertakings into suspension of payment, bankruptcy and default. On the other hand, while wide and erratic fluctuations of com¬ modity price levels are admittedly undesirable, it is not generally agreed what direction control of the value of money should take. There are advocates of a steadily rising price level, the main argu¬ ment in favour of such a course being that this would tend to restore business prosperity and, by gradually reducing the value of money, would progressively lighten the weight of the "dead hand" of indebtedness upon industry. There are advocates of a price level falling as productivity (output per man-hour) increases, the main reason for holding such a view being that otherwise the reduction in

costs and consequent increase in profits would result in profit infla¬ tion and undue development of industry. The third course is for the price level (by which is usually understood the commodity price level at wholesale) to be held approximately stable. The points in favour of such a proposal are that an approximately stable price level represents the closest approach to justice in monetary matters, neither defrauding creditors (as would be the case with a rising price level), nor giving them an unearned increment (as would be the case if money progressively increased in value) ; that an approximately stable price level is the most likely to result in stable business condi¬ tions, conducing neither to the excessive activity liable to accompany a rising price level, nor to the depressive effect of a falling price level; that the possibility of profit inflation arising from increasing productivity could be met by an appropriate wage system, ensuring that wages rose as productivity increased; and that, from the point of view of international co-ordination, approximately stable price levels in the various countries are to be preferred to price levels moving upwards or downwards. This, incidentally, does not neces¬ sarily imply that approximate price stabilisation should be at the present level. The question of the value of money would necessarily have to be integrated with the question examined above, of sustain¬ ing effective demand. In particular, at a time such as the present, it would be necessary first of all to reinforce active purchasing power to the extent required to bring about a resumption of business activity, and only when that was accomplished to aim at approximate price stability henceforward. Exchange stability and an international monetary standard. The third aspect of organisation of the monetary medium concerns the setting up of an international monetary standard. If, as would seem probable, the "semi-automatic" gold standard is no longer adequate to the needs of the industrial and commercial world, some alternative system requires to be devised, ensuring the ready transfer of purchas¬ ing power from one country to another, at approximately stable rates of exchange. Along what lines this new system is likely to be framed it is difficult to say, but certain of its main features may perhaps be foreseen. In the first place, it may be taken as fairly certain that gold will be retained as an international monetary medium. As the

"small change" of world commerce, it has a valuable service to perform. On the other hand, it is never again likely to exercise the predominant influence upon monetary policy that it had in the nineteenth century. The essential basis for exchange stability in the future would appear to be an international agreement among the more important industrial, commercial and financial countries to follow the same general price policy—in all probability that of approximate stabilisation of their respective commodity price levels at wholesale. Such exchange stability as might be obtained by these means would be likely to range between considerably wider limits than the "gold points" of the semi-automatic standard, and might at times call for re-adjustment in respect of some particular country whose position on the world market had definitely changed. But while thus open to criticism at certain points, no other practical means of securing approximate exchange stability, permitting at the same time of the maintenance of active purchasing power and the control of fluctuations in the price levels of the various countries, would appear available. Lastly, among the countries entering into an agreement to hold their respective price levels approximately stable, some arrangement would be necessary by which each signatory State was guaranteed against a "flight" from its currency, so long as it proceeded in accordance with the terms of the agreement. Failing some such measure as this, the success of any form of international monetary standard would appear doubtful. ***** These three aspects of the organisation of the medium of ex¬ change, relating to the maintenance of active purchasing power, the control of the value of money, and the setting up of an effective international monetary standard respectively, have been examined in rather more detail than the other main divisions of economic plan¬ ning, not because they are inherently more important, but because they happen to be more important under the conditions of the present era. The organisation of production, while falling far short of what it might be, is nevertheless relatively efficient in the sense that far more can be made than can be disposed of under existing conditions. The organisation of marketing is at a more primitive stage than the

organisation of production, and consequently demands more atten¬ tion; but the loss occasioned by disproportionate production of particular commodities is relatively small alongside the economic waste arising from the intermittent general deficiency of active pur¬ chasing power, the fluctuations in the commodity price level and the failure of the international monetary mechanism consequent upon the breakdown of the gold standard. It is the organisation of the medium of exchange—in particular the maintenance of active pur¬ chasing power—that would appear to be at the centre of economic planning at the present time. THE ORGANISATION OF THE DIVISION OF THE PRODUCT OF INDUSTRY The organisation of the division of the product of industry, with wage questions as its most important element, cuts across the three fields of economic planning already examined. In the first place, it materially affects certain aspects of the organisation of production. As already noted, a wage system which enlists the co-operation of, and secures an optimum output from, the workers is an essential element in efficient production. In the second place, the wage policy followed determines to a great extent the proportion of the pro¬ ceeds going to profits; and abnormally high or abnormally low profits necessarily influence the volume and direction of investment. The organisation of trade is likewise influenced to some consider¬ able extent by the wage policy followed. Differences in wage rates tend to affect international competition, and hence the whole ques¬ tion of tariffs and trade barriers generally. Again, it is the wage earners who constitute the great majority of buyers of mass-produced goods and services, so that the maintenance of the buying power of this section of the population constitutes a highly important feature in the effective organisation of the marketing of these products. Furthermore, it is this working class element in buying which comes least into the "area of caprice", the great expansion of which, during recent decades, makes anticipation of the direction of demand of especial difficulty. Here also, therefore, the maintenance of the buying power of wage-earners would tend to simplify the marketing problem very considerably.

The organisation of the division of the product of industry like¬ wise affects the organisation of the medium of exchange. Where an unduly large proportion of the national dividend goes to rela¬ tively few people, who tend to invest a major part of their income in producers' goods, a relatively large part of the national effort may thus be directed to the making of equipment, and a relatively small part to the purchase of the goods made by this equipment— with uneconomic results in the way of unused capital resources. Similarly, people with large incomes are able if they wish to hold a considerable volume of purchasing power idle, thereby reducing effective demand and making for business depression; from which it may be inferred that a less unequal distribution of income would tend to have a beneficial effect upon the maintenance of effective demand. Furthermore, a wage system that enables the remuneration of labour to advance with increasing productivity is a necessary part of any planned monetary system involving approximate stability of the price level, since otherwise such increase in productivity is liable to give rise to profit inflation and so lead to an unbalanced economic situation. Thus, quite apart from the social considerations involved, the organisation of the division of the product of industry, centring around wage questions, is of many-sided importance in economic planning. Along what lines the present haphazard system of wage payment is likely to develop it is, of course, impossible to predict, but the main features of a more satisfactory method may perhaps be distinguished. A wage system giving reasonably satisfactory results from the economic as well as from the social point of view would have to meet four main conditions. It would have to conduce to efficient production; it would have to be of such a nature as to obviate as far as possible "social dumping" by countries with low wages and poor conditions of labour; it would have to ensure that the remuner¬ ation of labour advanced as productivity increased; and it would have both to be and to appear reasonably just. In order to meet these conditions, some system along the following general lines might possibly be found appropriate. At the basis of the system there would need to be a minimum wage (which was a true minimum

wage and not a disguised maximum), representing the irreducible cost of labour in the various occupations. This would have to be accompanied by some system of sharing the surplus remaining once this prime cost of labour had been met, and in such a manner as to secure that an equitable share went to the workers. Furthermore, such a system, while operating necessarily on a national (or regional) basis, would require to be adopted internationally in order to give reasonably satisfactory results. A wage system along these general lines, having a minimum wage as its basis coupled with some form of surplus sharing, would appear capable of meeting the four essential conditions laid down above. In the first place, it renders possible forms of remuneration calcu¬ lated to secure the co-operation of the workers, thereby making for efficiency of production. In the second place, it would appear to lend itself better than any other system to international agreement on minimum standards, and the prevention, at least to some extent, of "social dumping". In the third place, it is likely to prove more effective than the present system in maintaining the buying power of workers as a whole and, in particular, would enable wage earners to share in the increasing productivity of industry. In this way, it would both make for a fairer division of the product and tend to prevent profit inflation. Finally, by coupling it with measures (already in operation in a number of undertakings) by which the various types of work are graded as regards remuneration, so as to take into account skill, experience, previous training and other quali¬ ties required, a reasonably fair adjustment of rates as between differ¬ ent occupations would appear possible. ***** The above cursory description of some of the problems economic planning is likely to encounter is necessarily hypothetical to a very large extent. It tacitly assumes that a considerable element of pri¬ vate initiative and private enterprise is likely to be retained, the role of the State being to facilitate industrial self-government, to adapt the monetary system to modern requirements, to secure the necessary international co-ordination of the various measures adopted, and to ensure that the economic advance obtained is put to effective social

use. For the rest, the survey of the problems made here is very far from being complete, a number of exceedingly delicate and difficult questions—such as migration—being left completely on one side; while those actually treated are dealt with only in their more obvious manifestations. On the other hand, it would seem that the problems thus briefly referred to are among the most immediate that economic planning must tackle, and furthermore, that these problems are for the most part so inter-connected that one can hardly be dealt with unless the others are taken into account at the same time. For this reason, an attempt, however imperfect, to get a general view of the field, with the more urgent measures placed prominently in the foreground, has appeared essential to any examination of the inter¬ national and social aspects of the matter.

THE INTERNATIONAL AND SOCIAL ASPECTS OF ECONOMIC PLANNING AS with the factors making for economic planning and with the ^A-problems economic planning is likely to involve, the interna¬ tional and social aspects of the question cannot be more than sug¬ gested here. But while considerations of space make detailed treat¬ ment impossible, it would seem necessary to emphasise very strongly that these two aspects of the question are of the utmost importance. Unless adequate account is taken of the international aspect much of the planning conceived on a purely national basis will inevitably tend to defeat itself; and failure to give due attention to the social impli¬ cations of economic planning is to lose sight of what must necessarily be its ultimate purpose. the international aspect Economic planning may be on a purely national basis, on a purely international basis, or on a basis partly national and partly international. The purely national basis of economic planning has, superficially, much to recommend it. Decisive action is undoubtedly more pos¬ sible within the narrower boundaries and under the relatively homo¬ geneous conditions of a single State. But against this there are more than counterbalancing disadvantages. The objections to purely national planning are, in the first place, that the process of attaining the national economic isolation involved would entail a period of great disorganisation, even for the countries most favourably placed in this respect; while for other countries—particularly the smaller ones with highly specialised industries—it is practically out of the question except as a very last resort. In the second place, over and above these difficulties of initial adjustment, the benefit derived from the international division of labour would be lost, with an inevitably adverse effect upon the standard of living. In the third place, such a policy of national isolation would be likely to lead to grave politi¬ cal difficulties, endangering the whole economic, social and political structure, both of individual countries and of the world as a whole.

At the opposite extreme, a purely international basis for economic planning cannot be looked upon as feasible at the present time. The planning of the world as a single economic unit is an ultimate aim which requires to be clearly helcT in mind, but the view that such an aim can or should be immediately attained is hardly likely to prove a useful basis for practical action. There remains the intermediate course of national action supplemented by international co-operation, which, in a rather uncertain fashion, the various nations are at present attempting to pursue. It is clear that the great majority of the problems considered in the preceding section, while calling essentially for national action, demand, at the same time, a considerable measure of international action if reasonably satisfactory results are to be achieved. Thus, so far as the organisation of production is concerned, the control of the volume and direction of investment has obvious international impli¬ cations. Again, from the point of view both of the efficient organisa¬ tion of production and of the efficient organisation of trade, the problem how, and to what extent, international trade shall be con¬ trolled is of outstanding importance and manifestly calls for a high degree of co-operation between the different countries if it is to be satisfactorily dealt with. In the same field of organisation of trade, the problem of adjusting production to consumption for the various types of products necessarily entails international producers' agree¬ ments, at least for certain of the basic products, particularly in agri¬ culture. The organisation of the medium of exchange necessitates international action in all three of its main features. Co-operation between the various countries in sustaining effective demand is neces¬ sary in order to ensure that the maintenance of active purchasing power on the home market of each country shall be accompanied by the maintenance of active purchasing power on the world market also. Stability of the price level in any one country is exceedingly difficult to attain if, outside that country's borders, prices are fluctu¬ ating widely. The achievement of exchange stability, with which the problem of price levels is linked, is even more inevitably an inter¬ national problem. Finally, the organisation of the division of the product of industry, at least so far as wage questions and "social

dumping" are concerned, is an international problem of the first order, and one which so far has barely been touched. THE SOCIAL ASPECT The social aspect of economic planning may most conveniently be considered under the several heads of standard of living, unemploy¬ ment, wage questions, hours of work, conditions of labour, industrial disputes, and the general conception of social justice. Standard of Living. The average standard of living is necessarily governed by the numbers engaged in full-time production, their productivity, and the proportion of this production taking the form of consumers' goods finding buyers. At each of these points there is room for considerable improvement. Under present circumstances, the number engaged in full-time production, as compared with the number that would wish to be so employed, is exceedingly low and, except at rare intervals, tends to remain low. The actual output of those engaged in industry (using the term "industry" in its widest sense) is likewise relatively small as a result of preventable mis¬ direction, irregularity of production and industrial waste of many descriptions, due to lack of adequate planning. To some extent also, particularly during periods of profit inflation, there is liable to be an excessive proportion of capital equipment in the total production —resulting, at least temporarily, in the standard of living being lower than would otherwise be the case. Finally, the volume of goods made but subsequently wasted or deliberately destroyed for lack of buyers at remunerative prices, is not inconsiderable. For all these reasons, but principally the first two, the average standard of living falls far short of what would appear attainable under con¬ siderations slightly less chaotic than those at present obtaining. A second, and in some ways even more important factor from the social point of view, is that the inequalities in the incomes of the various classes of the community result in certain sections having a standard of living bordering upon, or actually falling below, the bare subsistence level. This is particularly true of the large numbers on the margin of employment who, under present circumstances, cannot reckon upon reasonably sustained periods of full-time work.

Economic planning would appear likely to improve the standard of living, both as regards the general average and as regards the levelling up of the lower categories. So far as raising the general level is concerned, the direct improvement in the organisation of production is important; but what is most necessary at the present time is the maintenance of adequate effective demand tending to keep industry reasonably fully employed. Provided this were done, the waste of manpower, of equipment and of materials, inevitable under existing circumstances, would be obviated at least to some extent. This same measure would be of the utmost importance also in bringing about a less unequal division of the product, since it would not only reduce the numbers at present upon the fringe of employment but, by keeping the demand for labour more nearly equal to the supply than at present occurs, would tend to increase the bargaining power of labour—particularly the lower categories— and so bring about an improvement in their earnings. The organisa¬ tion of the division of the product of industry, by way of better methods of wage determination, would likewise not only tend to result in a larger total product, but also ensure a more equitable and less unequal distribution among the various sections of the community. Unemployment. The effect of economic planning upon unemploy¬ ment would come principally from the organisation of marketing, on the one hand, and the organisation of the medium of exchange on the other. For industry as a whole to keep reasonably fully em¬ ployed, it is necessary that the production of the various types of goods should not be allowed to proceed at a rate far exceeding the possibility of disposing of those types of goods at prices making production worth while. Still more essential is it that the total volume of active purchasing power shall be continuously adjusted, so as to secure that the effective demand for goods in general shall be adequate but not excessive. Provided these two major conditions are fulfilled, unemployment could be reduced to such minimum of wastage as is inevitable in a changing economy. If, on the other hand, these conditions, particularly the second, are not fulfilled, there must inevitably be periods when for a variety of reasons par¬ ticular types of goods are produced disproportionately, with the

consequent reaction upon employment; and there must inevitably be periods when, whether through monetary, psychological or other causes, the total volume of demand becomes grossly excessive or grossly deficient, as the case may be, and the whole mechanism of production and employment is thrown out of gear as a consequence. So long as the process of price-and-cost adjustment could be relied upon to work with a fair degree of efficiency and rapidity, the unem¬ ployment so brought about, while important, is not disastrous. Under present-day conditions, with price-and-cost adjustment erratic and uncertain, either there must be conscious planning along these general lines, or there is reason to believe that, with the rapid changes in the direction of demand for particular products, the wide fluctuations in total demand, and the rapid rate of technological advance, unemployment may prove a permanent problem and one of growing seriousness. Wage questions. As with the standard of living, almost all of the various forms of economic planning considered in the preceding sec¬ tion have a profound influence upon wage questions. In the first place, a more efficient organisation of production is, of course, funda¬ mental to an increase in real earnings. In the second place, as with unemployment, the adjustment of production to consumption for the various types of goods, and the adjustment of consumption to pro¬ duction for goods in general, are alike essential if the goods made are to find an adequate market, thereby enabling regular and full- time wages to be earned. The approximate stabilisation of the price levels in the various countries is yet another aspect of the organisa¬ tion of the medium of exchange closely affecting wage questions, since by no other means can money wages be enabled to keep a fairly constant value. Finally, the establishment of principles of wage determination, both nationally and internationally, would be likely to have far-reaching social consequences, affecting both the relations between different sections of the community and the relations between countries. Hours of work. The question of hours of work presents a rather special case of economic planning. The chief matter at issue is, of course, to what extent the increasing ability to produce made possible

by technological advance shall be taken in the form of material goods, and to what extent it shall be taken in the form of leisure. This is the major aspect of the question in the long run, but there is also the shorter-run problem arising out of the rapidity of techno¬ logical advance. In one manner or another it is necessary for the economy of each country and of the world as a whole to be adapted to the changes brought about by labour-saving devices; and one of the possible methods of adaptation is obviously a reduction in hours of work. It is not necessary to enter into the substance of these questions here. The point that requires to be brought out is that any reasonable decision on these questions calls for some measure of planning, inter¬ nationally as well as nationally, the blind press of competition being altogether inadequate to furnish an economically and socially satis¬ factory solution. Conditions of labour. The improvement of general conditions of labour, such as those concerning night work, child labour, social insurance, apprenticeship questions, health and safety, etc., depends in the main upon three essential factors: the degree of organisation of the various industries, industry's ability to sell its goods at remunerative prices, and the ability of labour to insist upon high and improving standards. The first of these factors is manifestly con¬ nected with the organisation of production, in particular the indus¬ trial integration of individual enterprises, thereby controlling to some extent the otherwise inevitable percentage of "bad" employers to be found in every industry. The other two factors depend in the main upon a right relationship being maintained between consump¬ tion and production. Provided industry is able to dispose of its products at remunerative prices, the essential basis for improvement in labour conditions exists. Similarly, provided the demand for goods in general is kept adequate, the consequent adequate demand for labour to make these goods tends to place in the hands of the workers the power necessary to secure the adoption of suitable labour conditions. In this, as in other spheres, economic planning is the essential basis for social advance. Industrial disputes. Economic planning along the lines sketched out in the preceding section would be likely to affect industrial

disputes and social unrest generally in a number of ways. Of these, the most important are that, with effective demand fairly consistently sustained, the difficulties, economic and psychological, arising out of fluctuating industrial activity would be eliminated in large part; the fluctuations in the price level, with their effect upon real wages, would likewise cease to play the important role they now have in disturbing industrial relations; and the establishment of principles of wage determination would go far towards preventing a large number of actual and potential disputes—some two-thirds of the total number of strikes and lock-outs in most countries being directly ascribable to wage questions. Needless to say, economic planning does nothing in itself to alter the combative element basic to indus¬ trial disputes; but by eliminating a number of factors which at present complicate industrial relations it would tend to some con¬ siderable extent to prevent disputes arising unnecessarily. Social justice. The relationship between economic planning and social justice is far too wide a question to be dealt with here in any detail. At the same time, it cannot be passed by unnoticed. Two major aspects in particular would appear to merit attention. The better adjustment of consumption and production, by the organisa¬ tion of marketing on the one hand and the organisation of the medium of exchange on the other, would tend to bring about a levelling up of some of the grosser economic inequalities which at present characterise industrial civilisation. In particular, by reducing unemployment to a minimum the large mass of people at present on the fringe of employment would be placed in a position to earn a relatively regular living. The other outstanding influence of eco¬ nomic planning upon social justice arises from the increased power that adequate demand for goods in general is likely to put into the hands of the workers. In so far as it is true that justice is seldom done unless those demanding justice have the power to enforce their demands, it is probably not too much to say that the effective attain¬ ment of some closer approximation to social justice than at present exists depends essentially upon adequate measures of economic plan¬ ning which, by keeping industry and labour reasonably fully em¬ ployed, would give those engaged in production the means of having an effective voice in the shaping of the community of the future.

CONCLUSIONS THE necessarily superficial and incomplete survey attempted in the foregoing pages does not permit of any very positive con¬ clusions being reached, except such as border upon the platitudinous. Nevertheless, certain of these are not altogether without their im¬ portance, given that they are as yet far from being universally accepted. The first of these conclusions is that the sheer pressure of facts behind the movement towards economic planning is calculated, sooner or later, to force a large measure of planning upon the more important industrial countries. Muddling through as a permanent policy is incompatible with the modern mentality, is abhorrent to the social outlook and, with the mechanism of adjustment of prices and costs more or less completely out of commission, is no longer capable of giving even moderately satisfactory results. The second outstanding conclusion is that economic planning is fundamental to social progress. Under modern conditions, impro¬ vised and haphazard methods cannot be relied upon to deal with such basic questions as unemployment and the provision of an adequate living wage. "Economic facts" are not what they were once considered to be—iron boundaries narrowly circumscribing the possibilities of social advance. On the contrary, these "facts" are now the hope of the future. The prospects opened up by economic planning, in conjunction with modern technology, are such as to bring much that was once pure idealism into the realm of the prac¬ tically possible. This is not in any way to subscribe to the extrava¬ gant prophecies of those who generalise over-hastily from recent technological progress in some particular sphere. But there can be little question that, given the necessary organisation, modern indus¬ trial technique makes possible a rapid advance in living and labour standards; and it is no less certain that the essential aim of organised society—maximum individual satisfaction at minimum social cost— can find its achievement only through planning consciously directed to this end.

The third major conclusion is that many of the measures, to be satisfactorily put into action, must be international in scope. This does not necessarily carry with it the guarantee that the requisite international co-operation will be forthcoming; but the need for such action is sufficiently obvious. In the marketing and in the monetary spheres, in particular, international co-operation is both urgent and essential. The fourth conclusion to which the foregoing analysis would appear to lead is that conscious measures aiming at the adjustment of production to consumption so far as individual products are con¬ cerned, and of consumption to production so far as concerns goods in general, are fundamental to the whole of economic planning. Such a programme involves scientific marketing in combination with industrially integrated production, on the one side, monetary mea¬ sures combined with appropriate government action, on the other. Unless and until positive action is taken along these general lines, the breakdown of the mechanism of adjustment of prices and costs is likely to have catastrophic consequences. Finally, it must be recognised that some of the most important of the conditions making satisfactory economic planning possible lie outside the economic field. The relations between countries and between different sections of the world community must shew a radical improvement before many of the most necessary features of economic planning become practicable. This in turn involves a widely different outlook upon the part of the individuals of which these countries and sections are made up. Whether and how rapidly the pressure of facts can bring about this changed outlook necessarily depends upon forces the future influence of which is unpredictable.
