PROOF EDITION UNEMPLOYMENT AND PUBLIC WORKS POLICIES IN PACIFIC COUNTRIES Memorandum communicated by the International Labour Office, Geneva, to the Fifth Biennial Confer¬ ence of the Institute of Pacific Relations, to be held at Banff, Canada, August 14th to 28th, 1933 INSTITUTE OF PACIFIC RELATIONS HONOLULU —1933

THIS is the second of two memoranda which the International Labour Office has generously pre¬ pared for the Fifth Biennial Conference of the Institute of Pacific Relations, to be held at Banff in August, 1933. It describes and compares in a very helpful way the use of acceleration and retardation of public works in several countries of the Pacific as one means of government control of economic processes, and thus directly implements one section of the Banff agenda. While the Secretariat has undertaken the publication of the memorandum, the Institute itself assumes no responsibility for statements of fact or opinion contained in it. These remain as much the personal expression of the author as if communicated orally. Price 30 cents Copyright, 1933 Institute of Pacific Relations PRINTED IN THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA

EVOLUTION OF IDEAS CONCERNING PUBLIC WORKS THE PROBLEM of public works in relation to unemployment was one of the questions considered by the International Labour Organisation at its inception. At the first International Labour Con¬ ference, held at Washington in 1919, a recommendation was adopted to the effect that each member of the International Labour Organisa¬ tion should "co-ordinate the execution of all work undertaken under public authority, with a view to reserving such work, as far as prac¬ ticable, for periods of unemployment." The terms of the recommendation are wide in scope. The phrase "all work undertaken by public authority" not only means work carried out directly by the central or local government authorities, but includes all work operated by private bodies under statutory control, such as railways, road transport, gas and electric supply, etc. The object of the recommendation is obviously not to give work to the unemployed when a depression has already developed. What is mainly aimed at is to provide a stimulus to economic organisation as a whole in times of industrial depression, by utilising funds accumulated in preceding periods of boom. This recommendation must be regarded as a landmark in the evolution of the idea of public works as a means of combating unemployment, since it involves an important new principle in the organisation of public works schemes. Throughout the nineteenth century and the first decade of the present century, the construction of local public works was in vari¬ ous countries a customary practice for alleviating unemployment in periods of depression. An experiment in Lancashire during the cotton famine caused by the American Civil War was, as is often cited, one of the early attempts to undertake public works on a large scale in order to give relief to those who were thrown out of work. With a loan granted by Parliament in 1863, street improvements in cotton towns were carried out by the Lancashire authorities. The scheme was well administered, but the result was very limited from the point of view of mitigating unemployment.

In pre-war days, relief works similar to the Lancashire experiment were often resorted to in many countries during recurring periods of depression. However, public works proposals hurriedly formulated only when the situation had already reached a point of crisis could not be otherwise than limited in scope and unproductive in result. At the end of the nineteenth century, when it was seen that the economic system was subject to cyclical fluctuations, a new idea was put forward, namely, advance-planning of public works with a view to bringing about the stabilisation of the demand for labour over a period of years. This new principle of public works as a means of reducing unemployment has secured many adherents; and the probable effectiveness of the idea has given rise to considerable discussion among economists and legislators. The earliest measure based on the idea of advance-planning is to be found in France in 1897, but the policy was not consistently pur¬ sued, and it is probably in Sweden that the most thorough examina¬ tion and application of this policy among European countries has been made. In Great Britain, both the majority and the minority report issued by the Royal Commission on the Poor Law of 1909 favourably recommended similar measures. The Development and Road Fund Act, 1909, provided for the establishment of a Develop¬ ment Commission with powers to plan public works in relation to the general unemployment situation, but owing to changed economic conditions no practical results ensued in this respect. Since the recommendation on unemployment, to which reference has already been made, was adopted by the Washington Conference of 1919, the idea of advance-planning for remedying unemployment has been definitely established as an international principle, and this was reaffirmed by the International Labour Conference of 1926.1 In the United States of America, the movement for adopting the principle of advance-planning as a means of industrial stabilisation had its origin in the crisis of 1921-22. At the close of 1921 a bill was introduced into the United States Senate for the first time, enabling the Federal Government to exercise a stabilising influence 1 Problems of public works are the subject of continual study by the International Labour Office. A complete survey of the question is made in Unemployment and Public Works, International Labour Office, Geneva, 1931.

on cyclical fluctuations of business by postponing or advancing the execution of public works. Later efforts to pass Federal legislation on the subject of advance-planning of public works culminated on February 10, 1931, when the Wagner Act was approved. The Act, which is called the Employment Stabilisation Act, provides for "the advance-planning and regulated construction of public works, for stabilisation of industry, and for aiding in the prevention of unem¬ ployment during periods of business depression." Further development has recently taken place in the conception of public works. Some eminent economists have shown the importance of associating public works policy with a suitable monetary policy, as this is believed to be the most effective method of restoring purchasing power, and thereby industrial activity as well.2 In his pamphlet entitled "The Means to Prosperity," Mr. J. M. Keynes makes a proposal for the use of large-scale public works to be financed by means of loans, national action along these lines to be co-ordinated internationally and combined with world-economic measures of controlled reflation. Using the best calculations obtain¬ able, Mr. Keynes points out that in Great Britain expenditure on public works of £150 would result, directly and indirectly, in putting an unemployed man to work for a year, and that between one-half and two-thirds of this disbursement would be recovered by the Government in savings on unemployment benefits and increased re¬ ceipts from taxation. He argues, therefore, that an expenditure amounting to £150,000,000 per annum would result in putting at least one million men back to work. Moreover, Mr. Keynes holds that the only satisfactory method of bringing about an upward move¬ ment in the prices of commodities as a whole is to increase expendi¬ ture more rapidly than the supply of commodities on the market, and that such an increase in expenditure can be expected in present circumstances only from the initiative of public authorities. Private enterprise will not expand until profits begin to recover, nor can banks be expected to increase working capital until output increases. 2 Some representative works on the question are as follows:—P. W. Martin, The Problem of Maintaining Purchasing Power. A Study of Industrial Depression and Recovery, London, 1931; Sir Arthur Salter, Recovery, London, 1932; J. M. Keynes, The Means to Prosperity, London, 1933; J. E. Meade, Public Works in Their Inter¬ national Aspect, with an introduction by Mr. H. B. Butler, Director of the International Labour Office, London, 1933.

To bring about a rise in prices, not merely in a single country but in the world as a whole, concerted international action in increasing loan-expenditure is most desirable. As Mr. Keynes indicates, the proposal represents not only his personal view, but the opinion of a group of influential people. In the light of this interesting evolution in the underlying prin¬ ciple of public works for dealing with unemployment, an examina¬ tion will be attempted in the following pages of public works policies in Australia, Canada, China, Japan, New Zealand and the United States of America;3 and some important problems which have arisen from the experiences in these countries will also be considered. Each step in the evolution of ideas concerning public works has increased the importance of their international aspect. SURVEY OF MEASURES PROPOSED AND ADOPTED FOR PUBLIC WORKS IN SOME PACIFIC COUNTRIES RECENT economic history suggests that the Pacific countries are very sensitive to recurring industrial depressions, and demon¬ strates that they were the first to experience the effects of the two post-war depressions of 1920-22 and 1929-33. One of the conspicu¬ ous features of the post-war depressions seems to be that at the outset a big fall takes place in the prices of foodstuffs and industrial raw materials.4 Many Pacific countries, whose industry consists mainly in the pro¬ duction of primary products, from the very beginning of the present depression found themselves in a very unfavourable industrial posi¬ tion in comparison with other parts of the world. For an account of the present crisis, see League of Nations, The Course and Phases of the World Economic Depression, Geneva, 1931, and Review of World Trade 1931-32 (first half), Geneva, 1932.

There is no single method of dealing with unemployment. The organisation of public works, however, is generally considered one of the most effective immediate methods of combatting unemploy¬ ment. It has been extensively resorted to in the Pacific countries; therefore, a survey of the public works' policies pursued in some of the representative industrial countries bordering on the Pacific Ocean is given in the following pages. AUSTRALIA In Australia, public authorities, and in particular the Common¬ wealth and State Governments, have played a large part in the development of the resources of the country by the construction of public works, mainly out of the proceeds of loans. Foremost among the works undertaken by the State Governments have been the con¬ struction of railways, the improvement of harbours and rivers, and the construction of water supply and sewerage works. The Common¬ wealth Government has assumed the responsibility for construction of telephone and telegraph services, the trans-Australian railway, and certain other undertakings. From the outset of the current depression, the decline in national revenue consequent on the heavy fall in export prices, together with the cessation of over-sea borrow¬ ing, made it difficult to raise funds for expenditure on public works. No statistics are available showing the total expenditure on public works, but the decline in the amount of expenditure on public works by the Commonwealth and State Governments from the proceeds of loans during recent years may be seen from the following table: LOAN EXPENDITURE ON PUBLIC WORKS IN AUSTRALIA, 1926-27 TO 1930-31 7 £ (ooo's) Year All States Commonwealth 1926-27 33,319 9,404 1927-28 35,562 8,662 1928-29 31,873 8,244 1929-30 24,974 5,294 1930-31 12,664 1,991 7 Commonwealth Bureau of Census and Statistics, Official Year Book of the Commonwealth of Australia, No. 25—1932, Canberra, 1933.

In 1928, the Development and Migration Commission investigated the problem of unemployment and industrial stabilisation. It rec¬ ommended that the Commonwealth and State Governments adopt the policy of regulating expenditure on public works according to the principle of advanced planning. This recommendation does not appear to have been carried into effect, except that some measures have been adopted against seasonal unemployment in various states. In general, the rate of expenditure on public works appears to have been strongly influenced by the facility with which loans could be raised abroad—or, in recent years, within the country—for such purposes. The control of public works is divided between the Commonwealth and the various states, but it is interesting to note that in 1927, as a result of an agreement between the Commonwealth and the states with regard to the co-ordination of public borrowing, an Australian Loan Council was established. All loans are now arranged by the Commonwealth in accordance with the decision of the Loan Council, which determines the amount and the conditions of borrowing. The Commonwealth and the various states submit annual programmes indicating the amounts of loan money desired and the amounts expected to be made available for repayment. Only by a unanimous decision of the Council may a state float loans on its own account outside Australia.8 During periods of severe unemployment, efforts are generally made by the state authorities and local bodies to expedite public works with a view to relieving distress among the unemployed. In order to meet the consequences of the present depression, special measures designed to relieve unemployment have been adopted in various states. In New South Wales, Queensland and Victoria, unemploy¬ ment funds have been set up, financed by the proceeds of special taxation on wages, salaries and other incomes and, except in the case of Victoria, by grants from the general revenue of the state. The funds are used in various ways for the relief of unemployment, including the payment of sustenance allowances and the execution of relief works. For example, in New South Wales the expendi- 8 New South Wales, The Official Year Book of New South Wales, 1930-31, Sydney, 1932, p. 682.

ture from the unemployment fund during 1930-31 amounted to £4,357,000, of which rather more than one-half was spent on various relief works. In South Australia and West Australia, too, special bodies have been set up to undertake measures, such as public works, for the relief of unemployment.9 CANADA In Canada, public works policies have been considered mainly as a means of providing relief for the unemployed, and such works have until recently been the principal relief measure in the country. In October, 1921, when an acute unemployment situation prevailed, an Order in Council was issued, providing that Federal aid to the extent of one-third of the cost would be granted in respect of work undertaken by municipalities during the winter for the purpose of re¬ lieving unemployment. By Orders in Council of January, 1922, and March, 1926, this system was continued with certain modifications. At a special session of Parliament in September, 1930, called to deal with unemployment, an Unemployment Relief Act was passed, and provision was made for the execution of public works and the extension of cash relief to alleviate unemployment. Other Acts dealing with the same subject were passed in 1931 and 1932. Accord¬ ing to a report made by the Minister of Labour in the House of Commons, February 24, 1933, on activities under the relief legisla¬ tion of 1930, 1931 and 1932,10 under the 1930 Act, the Dominion Government contributed to public works a total of $14,396,000, and to cash relief $3,547,000. In August, 1931, the Unemployment and Farm Relief Act, 1931, became effective, and its operation con¬ tinued until May, 1932. Under this Act, by agreement with the various provinces of the Dominion, the Federal Government agreed to contribute $34,008,000 towards the works carried out by the provinces, municipalities and Federal departments, the total cost of such works being approximately $81,000,000. On the question of continuing the public works on a full-wage basis with joint contributions from the Dominion Government, prov- 9 Cf. International Labour Office, Unemployment Insurance and Various Forms of Relief for the Unemployed, Geneva, 1933, pp. 203-4. 10 Labour Gazette (Ottawa), Vol. XXXIII, No. 3, March, 1933.

inces and municipalities, a practically unanimous opinion was ex¬ pressed by provincial representatives at a conference of Dominion and Provincial Government representatives, held in April, 1932, that this would place too heavy a burden upon the provinces and the municipalities. The Federal Government also was feeling the financial strain; the conference therefore put an end to the whole public works' policy, and cash relief became the chief measure for relieving unemployment throughout Canada. After the conference, however, the Dominion Government launched a policy of land settlement in co-operation with local authorities. Families are selected from among those dependent upon cash relief and placed on the land, where they have a chance of becoming self- supporting. The estimated cost of supporting them by means of cash relief is advanced to help them in establishing themselves. The maximum amount of each advance is set at $600, to be shared equally by the Dominion, provinces and municipalities; not more than $500 is to be paid in the first year, $100 being reserved for the second year, in case of necessity. The total contribution of $200 by the Dominion is not recoverable. CHINA There is a paucity of information concerning public works in China. However, at a meeting of the Committee on Chinese Rev¬ enue, held on November 29, 1921, during the Washington Confer¬ ence for limiting naval armaments, a suggestion was put forward by a member of the Committee to the effect that increased revenue from Customs duties might profitably be expended on building railways in China. In reply to this suggestion, it was stated by a Chinese delegate that public opinion in China and the Chinese Government desired that such revenue should be devoted to productive public works. This policy appears to have met with many practical difficulties; but the Chinese Government has not abandoned the hope of employ¬ ing the increased revenue from Customs duties for constructive pur¬ poses. Some of the important schemes of public works which the Chinese Government proposes to carry out as soon as the necessary funds are available, are as follows: (1) the completion of the

Canton-Hankow Railway—280 miles of the line remaining to be completed; (2) the conservancy works of the Hwai River; (3) rail¬ way construction and irrigation in the Ordos Region, and (4) miscellaneous projects, including harbour improvements, reforesta¬ tion, the establishment of schools, experimental stations for develop¬ ing agriculture, etc.11 JAPAN In order to remedy seasonal unemployment, the use of public works was urged in instructions issued by the Minister of Home Affairs in April, 1919; and instructions to the same effect were issued at later dates. It was not, however, until 1925 that the Government took more active steps to encourage this policy. In August, 1925, the Government formulated a scheme of public works with the aim of giving relief to unemployed persons. Under this scheme, state financial aid amounting to half the labour costs of public works were granted in six large industrial cities, namely Tokyo, Osaka, Kyoto, Yokohama, Nagoya and Kobe, and the adja¬ cent districts. Further, the Government helped in carrying out these works by facilitating the floating of loans. Since the main object of these works was to give immediate relief to unskilled manual workers, only those public works the labour costs of which exceed 30 per cent of the total cost of the works were entitled to receive the state grant. The works were usually commenced in December of each year and continued until the end of March in the following year, which is the end of the fiscal year. This policy was continued without much modification until 1929. In the summer of 1929, a change of Government occurred; and the new Government, with Mr. Inouye as Minister of Finance, adopted a policy of retrenchment. In spite of the deflationary policy to which the Government committed itself, however, great progress was made with public works for the purpose of relieving the unem¬ ployed. Some of the important changes made in the public-works policy were: (1) the Government decided to extend the state aid to other parts of the country, in addition to the six industrial cities, 11 Based on Constructive Measures, prepared originally for the special Customs Conference held in Peking. Documents have been communicated to the International Labour Office by Dr. W. W. Yen.

whenever such a step became necessary; (2) public works were to be undertaken for relieving unemployment among intellectual work¬ ers—for example, this class of workers could be employed in making a social survey, in indexing, etc.; (3) the Government set up central and local regulation boards which came to be known as Unemploy¬ ment Prevention Commissions. This Minseito Government fell in December, 1931, and was suc¬ ceeded by the Seiyukai Government, the financial policy of which was the exact opposite of that of its immediate predecessor. This Government's policy was definitely inflationary: the gold standard was abandoned, sinking fund payments were suspended, and a budg¬ etary deficit was met by borrowing. These financial policies, as well as a large programme of public works formulated by this short¬ lived Government, were taken over by the present Government, which came into power in May, 1932. The scheme of public works requires five years for completion, and the total cost is estimated at 356 million yen. Further, in Dr. Seki's view the works have in most cases been carried out uneconomically and have benefited only casual workers.14 NEW ZEALAND In New Zealand, as in Australia, the state has played a large part in the economic development of the country, by the construction not only of roads and bridges, but also of railways and telegraphs, and the carrying out of other developmental works. Municipal and other local authorities also have carried out a great deal of work of this kind. The part played by private enterprise in the construc¬ tion of works of public utility has, in fact, been a very minor one; and the experience of New Zealand in this respect affords a striking contrast with that of other countries, such as Canada and the United States, where private capital and organisation have been of primary importance. Before 1870, the responsibility for public-works construction was in the hands of the provincial and local authorities; but in that year the Dominion Government took over the function formerly exer¬ cised by the provincial authorities in this connection, and set up a Public Works Fund to develop public construction. The activities of the Department of Public Works since that time have been on such a scale as to command much attention and constitute one of the major elements of Governmental policy. A Public Works Statement, containing detailed accounts and statistics, is presented by the Depart¬ ment to Parliament each year. During the period from 1870 to 1932, the total net expenditure from the general funds of the Department amounted to 121 million pounds. Approximately one-half of this total was spent in the con¬ struction of railways, 17 per cent on roads, 9 per cent on telegraphs, "Hajime Seki, "Shitsugyo Kyusai Jigyo (Works for Relieving Unemployment)" Shakat Setsaku Jiho, November, 1932, pp. 20-58.

9 per cent on public buildings, and the remainder on miscellaneous services.15 In addition to these expenditures from the general funds of the Department of Public Works, there have been expenditures on public works from various accounts under the control of other departments, and considerable sums have been spent by local authorities. During the period of unemploy¬ ment in 1914-1915, about one hundred cities carried out different kinds of public works—such as road-making, drainage, building, etc.—but the results were not very satisfactory. It was not until the depression of 1921 that serious efforts were made to promote works in order to relieve unemployment. In that year, President Harding called a conference to study the problem of unemployment. The conference recommended the launching an an extensive pro¬ gramme of public works, and the Federal Government made a grant to the states for increasing road construction, Congress voting 19 New Zealand, Unemployment Board: Report, 1932, Wellington, 1933, p. 9.

$75,000,000 for the purpose. The grants required the voting of an equal amount by the states concerned. The result was that 6,261 miles of roads were built at a total cost of $250,000,000, and the expenditure provided employment for about 200,000 workers during 1922. In the spring of 1923, when a shortage of labour was experi¬ enced in the building industries, President Coolidge applied to Mr. Hoover, Secretary of the Department of Commerce, for advice as to the time when it would be opportune to put in hand Federal con¬ struction works. In reply, Mr. Hoover recommended that the differ¬ ent divisions of the Government initiate no new work that was not necessary, and that there be a slowing down of the work in progress until there was a relaxation in private demands for labour. The effect of this letter was the postponement of a large amount of construction work until 1924, when a business recession took place. At the end of 1929, when the present depression started, President Hoover asked the Governors of various states to inaugurate an exten¬ sive public-works policy in order to mitigate unemployment; and at the same time he held a series of conferences with representatives of finance, trade, industry, agriculture and labour for the same purpose. In 1930, the Federal Government increased the amount of Federal aid to the states for highway construction from $75,000,000 to $125,000,000 a year, for a period of three years. Besides, the Federal programme for building post offices and other structures throughout the country was considerably increased. Thus, unusual efforts were made by the Federal Government to reduce unemployment by means of big schemes of public works, but these schemes do not appear to have been very effective. One reason for this may be that state and municipal expenditures on public works did not keep pace with Federal expenditure. CONCLUSIONS NATIONAL POLICIES RELIEF WORKS AS HAS been seen, construction schemes in Australia, Canada and -^A. other Pacific countries have been carried out by public authori¬ ties as an alternative to distributing cash relief. This policy has not been abandoned, but the experience of the countries which have adopted it seems to be that it is not possible to relieve the unem¬ ployed during a long depression in this way, owing to the cost, and that direct cash relief has to be given. It would, however, be a great mistake to underestimate the utility of this kind of work. A great deal has been done; and in particular the efforts made in some winters during and after the crisis of 1920-22, and also during the present depression, were of consider¬ able value in remedying seasonal unemployment and in helping dis¬ tressed workers to tide over a difficult period. ADVANCE-PLANNING With the exception of the United States, no country has yet adopted legislation embodying the idea of advance-planning. But efforts have been made in a number of countries, particularly in Europe, to apply such a policy in practice.25 The general tendency in Australia, Canada and New Zealand has been to proceed with public construction on a large scale during periods of prosperity, while in time of depression expenditure on such works has been much curtailed, consequently aggravating the decline of purchasing power. In the Far East, "measure income and regulate outlay thereby," which is an old Chinese axiom, is still regarded as the first principle for balancing revenue and expenditure within the fiscal year; and it appears that this is a strong obstacle to the introduction of a budgetary system which takes due account of economic fluctua¬ tions. In the United States, the advantage of advance-planning has 25 See, on this subject, International Labour Office, Unemployment and Public Works, Part I.

long been recognised; but the practical results have not been as satisfactory as might be expected. The total expenditure on public works, as it has been pointed out, has shown a decrease during the present depression. This is said to be due to an imperfect co-ordina¬ tion of policies among the Federal, state and local authorities; and a large proportion of post-war public construction in the country was closely associated with the movement of population from rural to urban areas during the boom.26 Thus, the principle of advance-planning has not yet been given a fair trial in the Pacific countries. However, the difficulties seem to be mainly of a technical character. If certain administrative and financial reforms could be introduced the success of the scheme of advance-planning of public works would be assured. In their report, published in 1930, the Committee on Recent Economic Changes of the President's Conference on Unemployment, accepting Mr. Leo Wolman's estimate that about $3,500,000,000 are expended every year on public construction in the United States, and that about 900,000 men are annually employed, pointed out that this public expenditure on permanent improvements formed about 35 per cent of the total volume of expenditure on all private and public con¬ struction.27 An intensive study on the construction work of the Municipality of Philadelphia shews that approximately one-half of this expenditure can be advanced or retarded.28 These investigations clearly suggest the possibility of considerable results from the adop¬ tion of a policy of advance-planning; if a certain part of this big expenditure is deferred during periods of prosperity and incurred in periods of depression, the purchasing power thus distributed would do much to compensate for the decline in private business activity. Reliable data are essential to estab¬ lish any satisfactory plan for spreading a public-works programme over a period of years. Above all, it is of great importance to have adequate statistical information concerning the state of the labour market. No country in the Pacific area seems to have introduced thus far a satisfactory system of compiling unemployment statistics; and considerable difficulty is experienced in forming an exact idea of the trend of seasonal and cyclical unemployment in these countries. It has already been noted that the United States Employment Stabili¬ sation Board is required by law to study various kinds of statistics in preparing suggestions for the President. In order to be able to deter¬ mine the volume of public works to be put in hand, and the most suitable time of execution, correct knowledge of the employment conditions in a wide area and in as many industries as possible must be acquired. Therefore, too much stress cannot be laid on the need for unemployment statistics. In most of the countries, trade union returns of unemployment and the employment exchange records are available, but these statistics are not usually adequate for measuring the volume of unemployment in the whole of a country. The most accurate unemployment statistics are undoubtedly those based on a national scheme of unemployment insurance. Moreover, statistical information about expenditure on public works does not, in most Pacific countries, exist in a form accessible to everybody; and there is an urgent need to establish a central source of information on the subject. In certain countries, individual investigators have undertaken special enquiries into the question of expenditure on public construction. The results of these studies are very illuminating, because from them we can learn how payments for construction purposes have been made in relation to employment conditions in various countries.29 29 Cf. For the future, the most desirable arrangement would seem to be that each Government should be responsible for the compilation and publication of statistics of expenditure on public works incurred by different departments and other public agencies, together with any useful information relating to the matter. Further, an international agreement should be reached on the method of compiling these statistics, so that as far as possible they may be on a comparable basis. The need for administrative co-ordination. One of the practical difficulties with which the.public-works policy in the United States and elsewhere has had to contend in the past has been the multiplicity of authorities responsible for planning and carrying out such works. As has already been pointed out, the tendency of public construction in the United States to decline during the present depression is chiefly due to the policy pursued by the state and municipal authori¬ ties. It is also the universal experience in almost every country that several departments of the central Government undertake public works without any deliberate co-operation in determining the time of execution, and that there are many local authorities which are very likely to inaugurate public improvements whenever the necessary funds become available, and curtail the work as soon as a depression arrives. An extreme example of decentralised administration, accord¬ ing to Dr. Wolman, is to be found in the City of Chicago and Cook County, where about 415 independent or semi-independent local governing bodies have the power to levy taxes and borrow money for the purpose of public works.30 The situation becomes more serious when we realise that the aggregate capital expenditure controlled by local or municipal bodies far exceeds that of a central government. For example, in the United States, Federal construction work usually represents less than one per cent of the total amount in the country as a whole. How¬ ever, the creation of the Federal Employment Stabilisation Board in the United States, and the proposals for establishing State Boards of a similar character will undoubtedly do much to remove the greater part of the administrative difficulties. In Japan, the lack of administrative co-ordination connected with public works has largely been removed by the creation of a govern- so Leo Wolman, op. cit., p. 162.

ment commission to which all public-works projects initiated by local municipal authorities must be referred for examination. Without the approval of this commission, public authorities are not allowed to float loans for the purpose of carrying out public works. In this connection, it may be recalled that reference has already been made to the activities of the Public Works Department in New Zealand and the Loan Council in Australia. Methods of financing. The advance-planning of public works must always be based on a somewhat elastic method of financing. Necessary funds may be raised either by taxation or by loans, but the most important point is that the system of financing should be so flexible as to allow concentrated spending in times of depression. The creation of a special reserve fund is often suggested as an effective means of giving the necessary elasticity to the method of taxation. Thus, it has been proposed that, when money is voted for a public-works scheme, a portion of the annual appropriation should be reserved in order to vary annual expenditure according to general industrial conditions prevailing at the time. By adopting this kind of measure, a heavy increase of taxation for the purpose of public works may be avoided during a depression, but no country has so far introduced such a system of financing on a considerable scale. When industry is actually suffering from a serious depression, a considerable increase in taxation is very difficult from the practical point of view. Moreover, there is theoretical doubt as to whether or not a reinforcement of active purchasing power, which is essential for industrial recovery, can really be brought about by means of public works financed out of taxation. On the other hand, many economists believe that loans should be raised for public-works pur¬ poses in times of depression. Another point which merits particular consideration is the special situation of debtor countries. In Australia, Canada and New Zeal¬ and, for example, a large amount of foreign capital was introduced before the present depression for settling people on the land, and for developing public construction. The prices of export products of those countries having fallen most severely, the payment of inter¬ est on existing debts has become very difficult. Since creditor coun¬ tries are not inclined to lend more capital, and debtor countries

cannot continue to export gold, these countries have felt obliged to resort to drastic economic measures, such as serious retrenchment in public expenditure, higher tariffs, exchange restrictions, currency depreciation, etc., thus giving rise to grave economic complications. It would seem from this that the financing of public-works schemes in debtor countries is a problem which needs a special solution. Since the war, the United States has become a great capital-export¬ ing country. A considerable part of American capital invested abroad in recent years was used in promoting public construction in Europe and in South America. Germany, in particular, borrowed heavily from the United States between 1925 and 1930, and the funds were used to a large extent by states and municipalities for various schemes of public development. No doubt can be enter¬ tained as to the part played by American investment in economic reconstruction in Central European countries, but it has been sug¬ gested that this has contributed to the creation of a rather unsatis¬ factory situation there. In the realm of international finance, laissez- faire was, up to recent times, the guiding principle, and the flow of capital from one country to another was only regulated by the prospect of earning a higher rate of interest. But at present this principle does not seem to work, either in theory or in practice. An early return to the free operation of international lending and bor¬ rowing is often proposed as a method of escaping from the present depression; but there is also considerable support for the idea of setting up machinery for the purpose of controlling international loans. There can be no doubt that such action is of importance in the financing of public works.81 INTERNATIONAL ASPECTS The description and discussion of the public works policies in Pacific countries would be incomplete without some reference to the international aspects of the subject. The above survey shows that the Pacific countries have had a great deal of experience in applying public works for the relief of unemployment, but it seems that there has been no positive action directed towards the co-ordina- 31 Sir Arthur Salter, op. cit., pp. 86 to 121.

tion of national schemes of public works for a common purpose. It is true that some of the Pacific countries are large enough to be regarded as to some extent economically independent, especially in comparison with most of the European countries; but the present world-wide depression has shown that isolated national efforts are not sufficient for coping with serious unemployment. It has already become a platitude to speak of the interdependence of nations. If it is clear that no country can any longer be entirely master of its own fate, and that its economic welfare is always dependent upon the conduct of other people, each country must be prepared to recognize and accept the fact and should co-operate in establishing an appropriate system of common action. The International Labour Office has, since the end of 1930, con¬ centrated its attention on the possibility of carrying out national and international public works capable of appreciably decreasing the number of unemployed. During the last year of his life, Mr. Albert Thomas, the first Director of the International Labour Office, devoted himself to a plan for securing concerted international action in the promotion of public works. Very recently, at the session of the International Labour Conference held in Geneva in June, 1933, a resolution was adopted in favour of taking up the problem of public works as one of the subjects for discussion at one of its next sessions. Moreover, the World Monetary and Economic Conference, which is sitting at the time of writing this report, has on its agenda the question of public works considered as a means of reinforcing effec¬ tive demand and so making for business revival and an increase in employment. If, as a result of the resolution of the International Labour Con¬ ference mentioned above, the Governing Body of the International Labour Office places this question on the agenda of a future session of the Conference, attention will be concentrated on the framing of a permanent international policy to which the Governments will be invited to adhere. It would be altogether premature for us to attempt here any detailed examination of what that policy should be; but it seems likely that it will embody the principles of advance planning and of some permanent means of co-ordinating national policies on this matter.
